—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I ask: what is the outcome of the inquiry conducted by the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security into whether there was intelligence warning of the terrorist attack in Bali on 12 October this year?

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr HOWARD
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Fadden for his question, which I know covers a subject of interest to all members of this House. The House will recall that on 16 October an inquiry to be conducted by the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security, Mr Bill Blick, was requested by me to determine whether any warning of the Bali attacks might have been possible from the intelligence material available to the government. The terms of reference for the inquiry, conducted under the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Act, were set out in a letter to Mr Blick from me on 23 October. They were: to review all relevant intelligence available to Australian intelligence and security agencies and associated intelligence assessment processes, to establish whether there was any information that warned of the bomb attack in Bali on 12 October 2002 and to propose relevant recommendations in the light of Mr Blick's findings. It was subsequently agreed that Mr Blick would also review Australian Federal Police information, in addition to intelligence reporting, to establish whether this might have provided any warning of the attack.

answer.para: Mr Blick wrote to me yesterday, on 9 December, to report the results of his inquiry so far. Mr Blick noted that he had extensively reviewed the intelligence records of the relevant agencies to identify information of possible relevance to the inquiry. His initial report notes that it does not cover some foreign language intelligence material collected in the period shortly before the Bali attack that needs more detailed examination. In Mr Blick's judgment this material is unlikely to contain relevant information, but to exclude this possibility the inspector-general will examine the material in detail. This will take some time and a second and final report will be provided when this process is completed. I table two unclassified extracts from the inspector-general's report. The first is the introduction and a summary of his findings. The second is an annex containing intelligence agency responsibilities. I offer the Leader of the Opposition a briefing on the full report and a personal opportunity for him to read that report in full. Parts of the report are highly classified and include the original text of key intelligence reports.

The core conclusion of the inspector-general's inquiry, subject to the further work I have mentioned, is that there was no intelligence warning of the 12 October terrorist attacks in Bali. As I indicated to the parliament on 16 October, and as Mr Blick notes, one intelligence report obtained from foreign liaison sources mentioned various places, including Bali, as possible locations of terrorist activity. Such activity was dependent upon certain specified circumstances. Those circumstances did not eventuate in the time between receipt of the intelligence and the attack in Bali on 12 October.

The inspector-general goes on to observe that he has been advised that it is clear from the Bali investigations that these circumstances were not relevant to the Bali attack. The report further notes that no other intelligence was received that specified Bali as a likely or possible location for a terrorist attack. Indeed, the inspector-general concludes that, even with the benefit of hindsight and knowledge of possible and likely perpetrators, the inquiry could not construe any intelligence, even intelligence not mentioning Bali, as possibly providing warning of an attack. As I indicated earlier, I also invited Mr Blick to propose relevant recommendations in the light of his findings. Mr Blick has indicated that he does not believe any recommendations are necessary.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Would the minister inform the House of recent developments in the peace process between the Free Aceh Movement and the government of Indonesia?
—The Minister for Veterans' Affairs—the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr DOWNER
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —Things aren't going so well for me today, Mr Speaker.
—You are a veteran foreign affairs minister; you're very good.

—A veteran foreign affairs minister; that is right. Thank you, Prime Minister. I thank the honourable member for Curtin for her question. She is the chair of the government's backbench foreign affairs committee and obviously has a great interest in issues within the region.

answer.para: It is hardly surprising that the government warmly welcomes the peace agreement between the Indonesian government and the Free Aceh Movement, which is known as GAM. The agreement is an important step forward, we hope, in bringing to an end the hostilities that have plagued Aceh now for very many years. The agreement does provide for the cessation of hostilities, an international cease-fire monitoring group and participation in the 2004 elections in which GAM members will be able to run for election. Australia would urge all leaders and their communities to embrace this new chance with the optimism it deserves. Clearly, we are not sure, but we very much hope that the agreement will prove to be the success that it deserves to be.

I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate the Indonesian government: in particular, President Megawati; Bambang Yudhoyono, the coordinating Minister for Political and Security Affairs; and Hassan Wirayuda, the foreign minister, on their extraordinarily hard work; and also the Henri Dunant Centre for its valuable work in bringing the parties together. The Australian government will do what it can to assist this peace process. We will contribute $2 million towards the implementation of the peace agreement at this stage. Our contribution will help fund an international cease-fire monitoring group. The group will have a key role in monitoring the adherence of the parties, the Indonesian government and GAM, to their undertakings under the peace agreement. Foreign Minister Wirayuda has written to me already thanking Australia for its contribution and noting his government's continuing commitment to ending the conflict in Aceh.

We are pleased to be part of an international effort which is supporting the excellent efforts of both parties as they move towards reconciling the conflict that has affected so many people for so long. Let me just reiterate, in conclusion, the commonly spoken position of the Australian government that we support Indonesia's unity, we support Indonesia's territorial integrity and we support its efforts to resolve its internal difficulties through both dialogue and negotiation. The peace agreement and the special autonomy law for Aceh are important steps towards securing a durable political solution but within the framework of something that we strongly support—and that is a united Indonesia.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Science. Would the minister inform the House of the areas that will benefit from today's announcement of funding for the cooperative research centres?

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGAURAN
talker.role: Minister for Science

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for Dobell for his question. He numbers amongst those with scientific or engineering qualifications in this place; hence his special interest in all things science and innovation. Following on from the Prime Minister's announcement last week of national priorities, the government announced today a record amount of funding for the cooperative research centres program of $480 million for 30 cooperative research centre grants. Especially important is the fact that this new funding flows from Backing Australia's Ability, the government's innovation strategy. It is an unstoppable bandwagon and the opposition would be well advised to jump on board, and we would welcome them.

answer.para: The CRCs, cooperative research centres, bring together universities, research agencies and industry in a cooperative way for material outcomes for commercialisation of intellectual property—

talk.start.para: —The member for Blaxland and the member for Brisbane!

—and allow Australia to maintain its competitive leading edge technology, and provide businesses with opportunities to work with research institutions and to focus on research relevant to Australia's needs. This round of funding will benefit a wide range of sectors, and a number of ministers have been supportive and have encouraged applications for funding from within their areas of responsibility. The environment sector will receive more than $145 million; medical science more than $80 million; and mining and energy more than $68 million. The member for Dobell, who has been involved in the invention as a designer of high voltage switch gear, will be particularly interested in the boost to energy technology. He has also been involved in their manufacture. Information and communication technology will receive $46 million and manufacturing technology will receive $15 million.

answer.para: Amongst all of the worthwhile cooperative research centres announced today was $110 million for a bushfire national research centre, into which the Commonwealth will inject $25 million. This is the first time that dispersed researchers in universities, CSIRO and state agencies will come together and work in total collaboration with the end users—the firefighting agencies. Every state and territory is represented and has invested very heavily in this new national bushfire research centre. Importantly, because the profile of the fire researchers is ageing, up to 40 postgraduate students will work with the centre over the next few years and get a degree in fire research.

I wish to thank all of the researchers both in government agencies and in universities who have joined with business partners to make applications and succeeded. They are adding to the social and economic prosperity of our nation. I close with a thank you to Dr Geoff Vaughan, chairman of the CRC selection committee, and his colleagues for their hard work and their application in this demanding task. When the Prime Minister made the announcement on national priorities last week, he said that it was evidence of the government placing science and technology at the crossroads of all government activity and of the supreme importance we attach to science and innovation. Today's announcement gives effect to those words.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer. Would the Treasurer advise the House of the results of the business surveys released today by the National Australia Bank and the Australian Industry Group? What do the results indicate about the performance of the Australian economy? How does this compare with international experience?

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr COSTELLO
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for Hinkler for his question. When you think of the challenges the Australian economy faces these days with international weakness, with the threat of terrorism and war, and with a very severe drought, it manages to show considerable resilience. Today the NAB monthly business survey reported that business conditions remained resilient in November. The National Australia Bank said that the survey is reporting levels of business activity that are still considerably north of four per cent annualised growth in the non-farm sector—which I think members will welcome—and that the non-farm sector is showing considerable resilience, notwithstanding a very severe drought, which is detracting from overall growth and leading to declining farm incomes.

answer.para: In addition to that, the Australian Industry Group survey of manufacturing for the December quarter found a strengthening in manufacturing activity, with a net balance of 24 per cent of firms reporting higher production, which was the strongest result since 1994. So manufacturing continues to show resilience as well. I think people on both sides of the House will welcome that.

About a fortnight ago, I was at a meeting of the G20—the 20 countries systemically important to the world financial system—in Delhi. Anne Krueger, the deputy managing director, was interviewed after that meeting. She said this—a very interesting observation:

quote.para: I keep telling people the world economy is not as bad as they think. They look at Japan, the US and Europe and forget some of the small industrialised countries such as Australia and Canada which are doing well.

answer.para: So we have the deputy managing director of the IMF now saying that maybe Japan, Europe and America are not doing so well but the bright spot out there is the Australian economy.

We had the national accounts last week, which also confirmed, notwithstanding drought, resilience. I note that the Labor Party are yet to ask a question about the national accounts which were released last week and are yet to ask a question about the mid-year review which was released the week before. I guess nothing could be a greater testament to the resilience of the Australian economy than the fact that the Labor Party have fallen silent in asking questions in relation to it.

I thought that the House might be interested in the Economist magazine and the forecast that it has this week. The Economist poll forecast Australia to lead the growth stakes in 2002 and 2003. Seeing as this is an important cricket day, I know the Prime Minister will welcome this statement. The Economist magazine said this week:

quote.para: Australia is doing well not just on the cricket pitch but in the growth league: it heads the table of all 15 countries both this year and next.

answer.para: I think in all fairness we could say of the British that their economy is doing better than their cricket team, which was 8-150 a short time ago. The British economy is strong by European standards, forecast to grow at 1.6 per cent in 2002 and 2.5 per cent in 2003. So Britain is certainly stronger than most of the European economies, but Australia is leading not only in cricket but also in terms of growth.

Having said that, it is a difficult period. The drought in particular is of concern to Australian growth prospects. But the non-farm GDP continues to show resilience and part of that is the changes that this government put in place over the last seven years, in particular the new tax system, which was the best thing to happen to the manufacturing industry because we took the indirect tax burden off manufacturing and gave manufacturing a much better go. We recall that the Australian Labor Party said tax reform would ruin the Australian economy. We recall the member for Hotham with his Hockey Bear pyjamas and his salads in plastic bags telling us that, if we reformed the taxation system, we would be in recession. Eighteen months after the reform of the Australian tax system, Australia leads the world.

There is a phrase you do not hear much about in this parliament any more. I have not heard the `r' word for quite some time. Let us remind them what it was: rollback. We have not heard `rollback' for the last 18 months or so, and no wonder. It was cheapjack opportunism, better forgotten and better buried, along with the economic policy of the member for Hotham.

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr TRUSS
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for Parkes for his question. His constituents are amongst the many who have benefited from the announcements that the federal government made yesterday to provide $368 million of additional assistance to drought-stricken farmers around Australia. The package includes immediate income support and interest rate subsidies for farmers who are suffering a deprivation of rain of a one in 20 magnitude over the previous nine months. The announcement also included some assistance for small business in drought-affected areas.

answer.para: I am pleased to report to the House that farm industry and other organisations have enthusiastically embraced these new measures. The National Farmers Federation commended the government on this particular initiative as an appropriate response to one of the worst droughts on record. I was pleased to note the support, too, from the Australian Local Government Association and the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, who have particularly acknowledged the fact that, for the first time in a drought, assistance will be available for adversely affected small business. Even the New South Wales Farmers Federation was able to say some kind things—which we do not hear from them all that often—about this package. I did note that they were critical of the interest subsidies that we are providing only two weeks after they asked for precisely that kind of response from the government. So sometimes the responses that we are getting from these organisations are inconsistent.

The member asked whether there were any alternative policies. I note in response to the package that the shadow minister for agriculture in the other place dusted off the Labor Party's six-point plan as their response to the needs of drought. Putting aside the fact that many of the announcements made were actually made two months after the government had put them in place and the other measures provide very little, this demonstrates how bankrupt the opposition is when it comes to providing real assistance to farmers. The farmers of Australia need to be aware of the fact that, under Labor's six-point plan, thousands of farmers would not have received any special assistance yesterday, they would not have received the interim assistance that we have been providing under exceptional circumstances arrangements, and most of them would not even get EC support for many months.

The reality is that Labor in this House has just been an apologist for state governments who are not prepared to do anything to support the farmers in their states. If you think the farmers are doing well from state benefits, you should look at their own acknowledgments. The Minister for Agriculture in New South Wales, in his last letter to me lodging another series of exceptional circumstances applications, admitted that his government had not provided any assistance at all to the farmers in that area. Yet, he was asking the federal government to provide exceptional circumstances assistance.

The Queensland minister is now demanding that we add areas to this interim support—areas that he does not provide any support for. That is typical of Labor's approach to these sorts of issues. While the Commonwealth has provided over $1 billion in commitments to farmers and small businesses through this drought period, the combined efforts of the states total only $55 million—and that is only the promises. What they have actually delivered is infinitely less.

This government is helping farmers in need. We know the problems they are facing are genuine and real. We are looking at ways in which we can ensure that our benefits flow quickly and with the minimum of paperwork. We want to ensure that assistance is provided in a timely way to help people through this difficult time so that we can again contribute towards building a much stronger rural Australian economy.

answer.para: We now know that people are looking at trying to come to Australia by other means or other routes. They are looking at alternative possibilities, including travelling into the Pacific. talk.start.para: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Werriwa proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

talk.start.para: —In question time today, we saw another embarrassing performance by the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence. She is embarrassing to the government, she is embarrassing to the parliament and she is embarrassing to the nation. She is a minister with defence responsibilities who can barely answer a question at the dispatch box. She can barely answer a question and can barely give any sort of credible defence of government policy, and now she is a minister who has fled from the chamber rather than face an important debate about border protection and national security. She is unfit for the job; she is incapable of defending this nation. Mrs Vale may well be a very nice lady—I am sure of that—but, quite frankly, I would not want her defending my street let alone defending our country. I would not want her involved in the protection of our borders or our national security. She is not up to the job. She may be another favourite of the Prime Minister but she is not a favourite of the Australian people, who are looking for a competent minister who is across the brief and able to defend our borders and secure our nation.

speech.para: The truth is that Australia needs a coastguard. More than ever, we need a cop on the beat. We need an effective maritime policing capacity. In one respect, it is amazing that Australia does not already have a coastguard. We are the world's largest island—the world's only island continent—with 37,000 kilometres of coastline. We have all that coastline but no coastguard. It is a major deficiency in our border protection strategy and a major deficiency in the nation's security. It is even worse than that: not only do we not have a coastguard but our nearest neighbour to the north, Indonesia—the world's largest archipelago—does not have a coastguard either. It is no wonder that our part of the world is so vulnerable to the drug runners, the gun smugglers and the pirate fishermen; and we are vulnerable to people-smuggling over the medium term.

It also needs to be said that the coastguard is an effective part of a strategy against terrorism. There is no doubt that terrorists look to nations with porous borders. Terrorists are attracted to nations that do not guard their coasts; they are attracted to nations with porous borders. We need a coastguard on so many fronts. We need the cop on the beat to deter the gun runners, to deter the drug smugglers, to combat the pirate fishermen, to fight the terrorists and to deter the people smugglers over the medium to longer term. This is an important part of Australia's national security strategy.

The truth is that the Howard government has gone soft on border protection because it has the wrong border protection strategy. You cannot be strong and effective on border protection unless you have the right strategy. The government has a strategy that, quite frankly, is uncoordinated and unsustainable. It is unsustainable on the basis of cost. The government's strategy is to have Navy frigates patrolling our Indian Ocean territories and waterways at a cost of $1 million a day. So it would take just two frigates operating for 300 days in a year to meet the full cost of Labor's comprehensive national coastguard network. The government's strategy is unsustainable. The government's strategy is ineffective. The government has gone soft on border protection because it has the wrong strategy. We need a coastguard to make up for the current arrangements, which are hopelessly inadequate. They are inadequate on the basis of cost. How can anyone defend a strategy that has Navy frigates acting as patrol boats at a cost of $1 million a day? It is cost ineffective. It is one of the most inefficient things you can do with our valuable Navy resources.

The Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence was in here today demeaning the Navy by saying it is little. In her world, it must be little and very expensive. She has the frigates out there at $1 million a day. It is also true to say that the current strategy is a poor use of operational resources. We have Navy personnel who have to jump 10 metres into the water to get asylum seekers out of the water. These boats have not been built for this purpose. Morale is falling. There is no doubt about that. The minister can deny it and talk about what is happening in the Gulf, but she should have a talk to the sailors who are out there on the frigates patrolling the Australian coast about the drop in morale. They have been trained for a war-fighting operation and not to act on border protection patrol boats. Morale is falling, and we are losing the skills of a war-fighting Navy. If you take our Navy and dedicate it to the wrong purpose—a purpose for which our sailors have never been trained—you will lose expertise, you will lose skills and you will lose morale. The minister can talk about an operation up in the Gulf, but the truth is that in our own backyard morale and skills are falling.

The other problem we have is that the Coastwatch arrangement is a dog's breakfast. It is totally uncoordinated and unfocused; it is an absolute dog's breakfast. The truth is that we can do much better, and that is the purpose of Labor's positive solution of establishing an Australian coastguard. Why do we need the coastguard? We need the coastguard because of the findings of the Australian Illicit Drug Report. They are that Customs seizures amount to just one per cent of the heroin required to satisfy the Australian market—that is, 99 per cent of heroin crosses our borders undetected. If you had a concern about safety on our streets or about heroin peddlers in our suburbs, you would have an Australian coastguard to defend our borders and to stop the rush of heroin into this country. We need a coastguard also because of the problem of illegal hand guns. It is estimated that there are 100,000 illegal hand guns circulating in Australia, and every one of them is imported illegally.

talk.start.para: —The last time Australian Customs apprehended a gun runner crossing our coastline—and it was in the electorate of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, who is making a bit of noise; he might remember the last time Australian Customs apprehended a drug runner crossing our coastline—was four years ago, in 1998, in the Kimberleys. So Customs have not been effective.
—That's right.

—He says, `That's right.' He is proud of the achievement of Customs in not having apprehended a gun runner since doing so up in the Kimberleys in 1998. That is another reason we need a coastguard. The government boasts of an agreement made last Friday at COAG to ban about 20 per cent of the hand guns in Australia. Bigger and better results would be achieved by establishing a coastguard. In the calender year 2001, Customs seized a grand total of 232 illegal hand guns. That is a bad performance. If it were not so serious, it would be a joke. They seized a grand total of 232 hand guns. Establishing an Australian coastguard could make our streets and suburbs safer, keep the guns off our streets and achieve a big result for community security. So too for the problem of pirate fishermen. If we want to do something about the pirate fishermen, we need effective border protection. We need a cop on the beat. We need an Australian coastguard.

speech.para: Of course, Labor have a solution. Unlike the government, we are not talking about these things; we are putting forward constructive policy solutions. There are four aspects to our national coastguard network. The first of those is the new hardware. Labor will commission three new purpose-built ships, built in Australia, generating Australian jobs and adding to our important shipbuilding industry. This fleet of three 80-metre ships, with helicopters, fills a critical capability gap. The truth is that, under the current flawed strategy, the Navy patrol boats are too small to protect our Indian Ocean territories, including Christmas Island, yet the Navy frigates are too expensive at $1 million a day to do the job efficiently. We need the coastguard fleet that a Crean Labor government will commission after the next election. The fleet will be headquartered at Darwin, with boats stationed at Cairns and Broome. There will be no impact on the defence budget; Navy resources will be unaffected. This is a win-win scenario: new hardware, a new coastguard fleet to undertake all these important border protection functions.

The second aspect of our coastguard network is the new personnel—250 new staff, as part of a coastguard staff entitlement of 2,000. The staff on the new boats are, of course, important, but the coastguard staff will also be posted on existing Navy and Customs patrol boats to perform surveillance and interdiction duties and also the vital maritime policing functions.

talk.start.para: —To do the job properly.

—That is right: to do the job properly, as should have been happening for years. Our new coastguard personnel will be trained using state-of-the-art technology at the Australian Maritime College at Launceston in the electorate of Bass. The third aspect of our strategy is the coastguard volunteers. John Howard says that he wants Australians to be alert to the threat of terrorism. Labor says that Australians should be alert but they should also have the opportunity and capacity to join a voluntary organisation to help make Australia safer. As a nation, generally, we do not look after our volunteers well enough. Labor's coastguard volunteers will change this pattern of neglect. We need a huge national effort to patrol and protect our borders. Labor will bring together the two existing organisations, the Royal Volunteer Coastal Patrol and the Australian Volunteer Coast Guard Association, to form a new coastguard volunteer network, a vast network of commercial and recreational vessels forming perhaps Australia's largest voluntary effort in the security and defence of our nation.

speech.para: And the potential is there. This is the potential the Howard government has totally neglected. It has given no recognition or encouragement to the coastguard volunteers. In Australia, we have 12,000 commercial vessels. We have 500,000 registered recreational boats. They should be the eyes and ears of a nation concerned about terrorism, the eyes and ears of a nation concerned about border protection and the eyes and ears of the world's largest island continent, with 37,000 kilometres of coast. They should offer the surveillance, the training and all the services that are needed to make our nation safe. Labor's policy will provide training and badging for the coastguard vessels and the volunteers, plus financial incentives—discounts on boat registration for all of the volunteers and also communication support in areas that are targeted by our coastguard strategy. The provision of $125 million is an investment in our volunteers over four years. It is the recognition and encouragement at long last that they truly deserve.

The fourth and final aspect of our national coastguard network is the new intelligence capacity. Good intelligence is the key driver of effective border protection. Currently, the Coastwatch effort is unable to direct the surveillance effort. It is contracted in by other agencies, so it cannot actually control the surveillance strategy. Labor's policy brings the coordination together and also provides an additional $30 million investment in fixed seabed array technology—that is, a seabed sonar system to increase the reach of our surveillance and national intelligence effort.

So this is a comprehensive national network of coastguard services—the new ships, the new personnel, the thousands of volunteers and the new intelligence capacity—all provided in a cost-effective way and far more effective than anything that has been achieved by the Howard government. We need to secure our nation, and it is not only Labor saying these things. Our policy has been endorsed by the people who know. The Royal Volunteer Coastal Patrol has said that it `welcomes the proposal of a single federal agency that would coordinate the safety and protection of our coastline'. It went on to say:

speech.para: And then there is the Australia Defence Association. What did they have to say about our coastguard policy? They said:

speech.para: Here is the Prime Minister talking about interest groups, but the truth is that when it comes to interest groups he is paralysed by the bureaucracy, paralysed by the sectional interest groups and unable to give this nation the border protection, the coastguard services that it truly needs. We have the support of the Australia Defence Association. It is a great shame that the assistant Minister for Defence is not even in the chamber to hear these ringing endorsements of Labor's coastguard policy. She is too scared to give an answer, she is too scared to engage in a debate, she truly has lost the plot and she gives the Australian people no confidence or security that she is up to the important task of acting as one of our defence ministers at this critical time in Australia's history. And what does Hugh White, one the pre-eminent defence and intelligence experts in Australia, have to say about the coastguard issue? He says:

speech.para: for border protection—

quote.para: ... almost anyone could operate them more cheaply than the Navy.

speech.para: That is another ringing endorsement of Labor's cost-effective, efficient strategy. We can do a lot better than Minister Danna Vale, we can do a lot better than a government that is paralysed by bureaucratic interests and sectional considerations, a government that has ignored the potential need for an Australian coastguard. It is one thing to have a minister who is regarded as a nice person, but niceness is not going to help Australia in the war against terror. Niceness is not going to help Australians to feel more secure, it is not going to get the drugs off our streets and it is not going to get the illegal guns out of our communities. Having a nice minister—a little favourite that the Prime Minister can pat on the head; the new Jackie Kelly of the Australian parliament—is hopelessly inadequate for the Australian people at this critical time. We need good policy. The world's largest island continent with the world's largest coastline needs a coastguard. That is the bottom line: we need a coastguard. I believe the proposition before the House today is a sign to the people of Australia that the Australian Labor Party are still ignoring them. Over 12 months ago, the people of Australia had a number of things to contend with in the 2001 federal election and one of them was Labor's proposition for a coastguard. It was roundly defeated. The Australian Labor Party need to understand that that defeat, that rejection of that policy, means that they should move on, cut their losses and look for something else. But, no, the Australian Labor Party are still ignoring the people of Australia. The proposition underscores the Australian Labor Party's complete desperation. The proposition also signals to smugglers that Australia would be back in business as far as they are concerned if the Australian Labor Party were ever to form government again. The people smugglers and drug smugglers would enjoy the day that the Australian Labor Party were re-elected to government.

speech.para: This proposition from the member for Werriwa also ignores the public debate that has occurred since the last election, which continues to roundly reject this proposition for a coastguard. The proposition also weakens the standing of the Royal Australian Navy, an organisation whose men and women are charged with the important task of protecting the seas around this nation. This proposition, as the Minister for Veterans Affairs and the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence rightly said during question time, also says that we will substitute three small patrol boats for the 15 boats which are currently employed in the tasks that the member for Werriwa says are not being done properly. This is not about coastguard; this is about leader guard—although, if I were the member for Hotham, I would be greatly concerned if the member for Werriwa mounted a defence of my leadership. People in my own electorate are wondering why the Australian Labor Party continue to ignore, after being told time and time again, the fact that this proposition for a coastguard simply does not stack up; that it will take away important resources from the Royal Australian Navy and it will take away the important task that the Royal Australian Navy performs. People cannot understand why the Labor Party do not get on with the business of backing the government's efforts with regard to border protection.

The opposition's continual insistence on bringing back a coastguard policy for border control is simply recycling ideas that have been rejected. They still do not understand that effective border protection strategies are already in place at this time. The rest of Australia has moved on, but the Labor Party continue to hold on to what was in their minds prior to the last election. They do not realise that they lost and that they need to move on in every possible way, including policy development. It is almost one year since we were promised a 1,000-day-long reform—a reform which would have matured after the next election is due. People in Australia will have to wait for two elections before they see a reformed Labor Party. At the end of the day, Labor still have a long way to go in developing workable policies to deal with unauthorised arrivals. The market has made its choice, but the Labor Party ignore what the market has had to say. In contrast with these untested policy experiments that are proposed by Labor, the Howard government's strategies are working. We have in place a comprehensive, coordinated strategy dealing with border protection, yet the opposition want to impose another layer of bureaucracy—something else to trip up everybody on the high seas. They want to change boats midstream. The proof that the Howard government's strategies are working is that there have been no boat arrivals on the Australian mainland since August 2001 and no boat arrivals in any Australian territory since 9 December 2001, which sounds awfully like a year ago yesterday. The Howard government have a system which is comprehensive and is working.

The mantra of `coastguard' is something that the Labor Party seem to shout every time they need a lifeline or a circuit-breaker in contemporary political debate. They feel themselves to be sinking into irrelevance in public debate. The Labor Party are divided on all these issues. The member for Fremantle has made well known her position on Labor Party policy and policy development on the front bench. She cannot even guarantee that she will contest the next election as a Labor candidate unless other policy changes are made at the ALP conference next year. The member for Werriwa is trying very hard to defend the constant exposure that his leader has had on this particular issue. His leader is being buffeted by waves of discontent within his party, muttering about what the Labor Party stands for. The `Friends of the ABC' faction is alive and well—that is, the `Anyone but Crean' faction. In raising this proposition today, the member for Werriwa is quite deliberately weakening his leader.

The effort to combat the people-smuggling trade is ongoing. It draws on the combined resources of a number of different agencies, including my department—the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs—the law enforcement community, the intelligence community and the defence community. The government's approach comprises three main elements. It is worth repeating them for the public record. The first is the prevention of the problem by minimising the outflows from countries of origin and the secondary outflows from countries of first asylum. The second is working with other countries to disrupt people smugglers and to intercept their clients en route to their intended destination, while also ensuring that people in need of refugee protection are identified and assisted as early as possible. The third is the development of appropriate reception arrangements for unauthorised arrivals who reach Australia, focusing on the early assessment of the refugee status of each person and the prompt removal of those who are not refugees or who are refugees but who cannot access effective protection elsewhere. This is working. This program, this coordinated effort by the government, is working in the area of border protection and does not need the sort of interruption to the process that the Labor Party is proposing. It does not need the sort of signal that is being sent to people smugglers and smugglers of other items which come to Australia—that is, that if the Labor Party were elected again to the government benches, they would be back in business and big time.

In September last year, the Howard government introduced significant legislative changes to border control and the management of unauthorised boat arrivals. I need to revisit all that happened in the lead-up to the last election, because it seems to have escaped those opposite. The government has also enacted legislation to limit grounds for the judicial review of visa related matters in Australian courts. This measure addresses the problem of unsuccessful asylum seekers who are using court processes as a means to deter their removal.

Customs officers already have the powers that they need to do the job. They can board ships, question, arrest and carry firearms. They can pursue and stop ships on the open seas and they can seize vessels. Customs officers and the Australian Customs Service are well aware of the range of measures they have at their disposal and are well aware of their own efforts and the success of their efforts. Labor are completely ignoring these efforts and the experience of officers on the ground today doing that important job and gaining real yards in the area of border protection. This is another uncosted policy. The Australian Labor Party in opposition will, of course, continue to promise a range of measures that, at the end of the day, they know they will never have to implement—measures that would be financially irresponsible if for some reason they were ever re-elected to the treasury bench.

This coastguard would be more costly. It is an irresponsible, wasteful and reckless proposal. It would create a new bureaucracy with all the overhead costs that that entails. The proposal to transfer patrol boats from Defence and vessels from Customs is short-sighted and dangerous to national security. Defence needs to retain all of its patrol boats, which are critical for its training and development regime. Even more stupidly, under the Australian Labor Party proposal Defence and Customs would in fact need to purchase new vessels to pick up on the non-Coastwatch work that their vessels would be doing. This is a stupid and reckless proposal and it concerns me that after all of the years of debate on this matter, after all of the opportunities the people of Australia have had to judge this and after the views of so many other people involved in the Australian community who comment on these sorts of matters on a daily basis, the Australian Labor Party still do not get it. They still do not get the fact that, after September last year, when the debate in Australia homed in particularly on these issues, the then Leader of the Opposition, the member for Brand, put up a proposition for a coastguard as an alternative measure for border protection to deal with the government's already effective strategy, which was introduced as a result of all of the things that were happening to Australia and which was endorsed by the people of Australia. It is interesting that the member for Hotham, the member for Werriwa and several others—and there were only a few, and in fact it was interesting to watch so many members opposite leave when the member for Werriwa started speaking and to note that there is not a universal view on the other side—are still keeping alive this ridiculous proposition.

It is interesting to note that Mike Carlton on Sydney radio 2UE on 27 November interviewed the Leader of the Opposition. I will quote some of the highlights from that particular interview, where Carlton understood very well the absolute lack of support in the Australian community for this. The transcript is as follows:

quote.para: CREAN: I'm talking about the Indian Ocean, the blue water activity—

speech.para: he was talking about patrol boats and the potential for a coastguard. It continues:

quote.para: CARLTON: We have patrol boats in the Indian Ocean. Where'd you get that idea?
CREAN: Um, these—what they do is to send the frigates out into the deep water operations and they cost a million dollars a day, Mike. A million a day.
CARLTON: We have ... patrol boats all over our Coastguard. I don't know where you got this idea that they can't operate in deep water? That's just nuts.

speech.para: It goes on:

quote.para: CARLTON: Would you ... go down to the Southern Ocean in an 80-metre vessel in the height of winter?
CREAN: All the advice that we've had is that they can.

speech.para: I tell you what: they would want to have a good union because it is going to be pretty cold down there in the Southern Ocean in the middle of winter. This is the sort of nonsense proposal the Australian Labor Party are endorsing in this proposition today. It continues:

quote.para: CARLTON: Hmm. I can't see it working, I've got to tell you but I admire you, at least you've got a policy on something—

speech.para: so Carlton recognises that the Australian Labor Party do not have many policies, but at least they have a policy on something—

quote.para: but it just seems to be utterly wasteful duplication of the maritime and military skills we have.

speech.para: If Mike Carlton could give better advice, I am waiting to hear it. He gave great advice to the Leader of the Opposition last week and Simon Crean still does not get it. After the interview, Carlton summed it all up. He said:

quote.para: Thanks a lot. Simon Crean, the Leader of the Opposition. Well look, it's a nice feel-good idea, a Coastguard to patrol our seas and oceans, cop on the beat—he obviously likes that phrase—but it's half-cocked, half-baked.

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —They are all saying, `Hear, hear!' Carlton continued:

quote.para: Where do you get the crews? They don't come overnight. The Navy is at full stretch recruiting and keeping its own people. To use the Navy phrase you have to raise 'em, train 'em and sustain 'em—that doesn't happen overnight. It's— you know. The patrol boats themselves, 80 metres—yes, good-sized ships, twice the size of the patrol boats we've got—but Simon Crean thinks our existing patrol boats can't go into blue waters, that's rubbish. Absolute rubbish. They're there all the time, that's all they do. Whether these 80-metre Coastguard vessels he's talking about could handle the Southern Ocean in winter, I doubt very much. It's tough enough for the bigger frigates to do that. Well, what sort of armament would they have? A gun up the front, he said. Well he didn't know much about that, either.

speech.para: The proposition put by Mike Carlton really says it all. Just last week the Leader of the Opposition was given absolute sound advice by a well-established, highly credentialled and highly experienced media commentator. Mike Carlton is someone with experience in other parts of the world as well as here in Australia, someone who calls a spade a spade, and without any doubt he said that Emperor Crean was completely naked on the question of a coastguard.

Yet today we have the member for Werriwa coming in here in support of his leader—I do not think so. At the end of the day, this proposition has been put forward by the member for Werriwa to add further embarrassment to the member for Hotham. This is all about the Australian Labor Party, without any doubt and in a blatant way, promising everything that sounds good. This is `a feel-good proposition', as Mike Carlton said last week—a nice sounding, feel-good proposition. But Labor are showing the people of Australia, the Navy, the people involved in the Customs Service, the people involved in the everyday hard work of proving the great result that we have had over the past 12 months—and they are also showing the people-smugglers—that if they were elected back to the treasury bench there would be confusion, not coordination, and bureaucracy aplenty but not any depth to the services provided. Their policy is soft on sovereignty, on border control and on costing. The Labor Party proposition is also showing that they are somewhat soft in the head because, after some 15 or 16 months of public debate on the proposition of a coastguard, the Australian Labor Party still have not got the message. This proposition today, initiated by the member for Werriwa, is rejected outright by the government because it does not work. The Australian Labor Party need to wake up to the fact that that is the case. I look forward to them spending the Christmas period properly understanding the reality that they should be confronting, and that is that they have lost three elections on the run, and the people of Australia have spoken. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I think we have heard just about everything in this place now. We have had the Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs stand up here and talk about defence matters and matters to do with national security. It is like a scene from a movie. We looked for the Minister for Defence and we looked for the assistant minister for defence, but who did we get? We got the minister for citizenship. We may as well have got the minister for child care or the minister for anything else. We wanted a serious debate with the government in relation to this policy. The minister got up here and quoted Mike Carlton. Who is Mike Carlton? Is he an expert on defence matters? Is he an expert on national security? Is he an ex military officer? Is he anyone who has any experience in dealing with matters to do with national security? The answer to those questions is no.

speech.para: The member for Werriwa, who has responsibility for this in the shadow ministry, quoted the Australia Defence Association, who have endorsed Labor's policy. He quoted the Australian Strategic Policy Institute, who have supported Labor's policy. He quoted the Royal Volunteer Coastal Patrol, who have also endorsed Labor's policy. The minister for citizenship came in here, quoted Mike Carlton, and said that Mike Carlton is against Labor's policy and therefore it is not a good thing. I say to you, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, that on our side—on the side of this good, decent public policy—we have all the people who know what they are talking about. On the government side we have a minister who does not have portfolio responsibility for this area. He came in here and read a speech from a couple of years ago that he pulled out of a dusty old drawer in his office, and he read it off without any proper analysis of what Labor's policy has to offer.

talk.start.para: —And then he scampers off!

—I have just been advised that he is scampering off. I wish he would stay because he might learn a thing or two. In public life the test of how serious you are about something is the resources you are prepared to commit to it. Under our policy—our fully costed policy—we have allocated $612½ million over four years to underscore Labor's commitment to border protection. It is all well and good for people in public life to stand up and say, `I'm for education', `I'm for defence' or `I'm for health', but the real test is how much you are prepared to put behind that commitment. The Labor Party have put more than $600 million behind our commitment. We are serious about this policy, we are serious about border protection and we are serious about it for a lot of good reasons.

speech.para: When you talk about maritime policing, you are talking about things that affect people's lives. You are talking about people smugglers, gun runners, drug smugglers and illegal fishing, and you are also talking about terrorists. These things are all very real risks to Australians. These are things that affect people's lives, and that is why we are concerned about them. That is why we have put in place this comprehensive policy to deal seriously with this important security matter. The one thing to never lose sight of when you talk about border protection is that it is not about false nationalism, it is not about jingoism and it is not about some of the stuff the hooray henrys on the other side go on about. It is about people's lives. On this side we are concerned about the impact of illegal importation of hand guns, illegal fishing, people smugglers and other illegal activity that takes place right now without any fear on the part of those responsible that they will be caught and brought to account for their actions. Right now maritime policing is a very vague concept. Who is involved, who is responsible and who has enforcement powers are very grey areas. We are about tightening that up and giving people real authority and the real resources they need to tackle this important issue.

The member for Werriwa—the shadow minister for community security, who has carriage of this for us—made a few important remarks in relation to the appropriateness of the resources the government are putting towards this task. We are about making sure that the government resources put towards border protection meet the task. Right now inappropriate government resources are being put towards this task, and it is just not working. It is not just the Labor Party who says it is not working: people in the defence community, people involved in national security and people involved in the Volunteer Coast Guard all accept that the current arrangements are not sustainable. They are not working effectively and they come at an extremely high cost to government. The reason is simple: they are using the wrong gear for the job. It is as simple as that. This has a substantial impact on the personnel involved. These people signed up to the Royal Australian Navy with the understanding that the Royal Australian Navy was used for war fighting in Australia and had a primary defence role. That is what those brave sailors understood when they signed up to be part of the Royal Australian Navy. Now they are performing a range of tasks which have nothing to do with what they have been trained to do or the functions they have set out to discharge.

We are about letting the Royal Australian Navy get on with the business of defence and putting in place a proper Australian coastguard to deal with issues of maritime policing. We understand that when you have a problem you need to think seriously about the resources you need to bring to dealing with that problem. The government seems absolutely incapable of understanding that when you talk about border protection you are not talking about defence. When you speak to people involved in this area, one thing comes through loud and clear: people are not happy about the existing arrangements, in which the Royal Australian Navy is used for this function. We are serious about letting the Royal Australian Navy get on with defence because we think the defence of Australia is an important priority and should not be diminished in any way by involving the Royal Australian Navy in other matters. What could be more important than defence? What could be more important than letting those sailors and that expert staff deal with matters to do with the defence of our country? We say: let those people do that work, and put in place a professional maritime police force to act as an Australian coastguard to make sure that matters to do with border protection are taken seriously and dealt with effectively.

I want to address the volunteer component in the time I have left in this debate. This is about saying to citizens in Australia that we understand they are serious about border protection and that we are too. We are going to make it possible for those citizens who are concerned about border protection to play an active role in enforcing border protection in our country. This is not a policy which has been arrived at without talking to people. The Labor Party has spoken to the Royal Volunteer Coastal Patrol, the Australian Volunteer Coast Guard, the government agencies involved and other groups which are involved in the volunteer coastguard community. What people have said to us very clearly—and it was mentioned in the endorsements which were read out by the member for Werriwa—is that they all support the idea of having a properly resourced Australian coastguard. Everyone else, except for the government, can see that if you have 37,000 kilometres of coastline you need a coastguard. It comes as no surprise to anyone that with 37,000 kilometres of coastline we are detecting only about one per cent of the illegal drugs that come into this country. That affects our communities, the places where we live. This is why so many people in Australia will be keen to participate in a volunteer border protection effort.

We are serious about those people who want to volunteer to be a part of the border protection effort. To underscore how seriously we take their volunteerism, we are going to resource it. There are a few important things which make up that support. We are going to sit down with the people who are involved in those volunteer coastguard agencies—the Royal Volunteer Coastal Patrol and the Australian Volunteer Coast Guard—and we are going to ask them to develop the charter for the new coastguard volunteer organisation. We are going to ask people who are involved in recreational fishing and tourism around the coastline, and also commercial fishermen, to participate in the coastguard volunteer patrol movement. We are going to ask those people to give us the intelligence which they have in relation to finding out where the ships are and where there is illegal activity. We are going to make it possible for those people to contribute to the volunteer effort and the professional effort involved in making sure that we have effective border protection in our country.

We are going to make sure that those people do that not just based on our saying: `You do this and that's all well and good, but we're not going to resource it properly.' What we are going to do is give those people a financial incentive as well for participating in our program. That is going to be contributed to them through discounted boat registration and also through assisting those people with new types of communications technology which will make their task easier. We are serious about border protection on this side of the House. We stand with the Australian Defence Association, the Royal Volunteer Coastal Patrol, the Australian Volunteer Coast Guard and every other thinking person in Australia who understands that with 37,000 kilometres of coastline Australia needs an Australian coastguard. (Time expired)

talker.name: Gallus, Christine, MP
Mrs GALLUS
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —What do we have this time from the member for Werriwa? The hoary chestnut that is the coastguard. Let me see, how long has the idea of the coastguard been around? Way before your time, Mr Deputy Speaker Jenkins, and way before my time. For 50 years the idea of a coastguard has come and gone. It has gone for a very good reason: it does not actually hold water. The idea itself sinks. It was raised originally in the 1950s, believe it or not. A Liberal government in the 1950s said, `Maybe we should have a look at a coastguard.' They had a look at the coastguard and they said at the end of it, `We don't need it.' We did not need it in the 1950s and we do not need it now. What Labor need, of course, is a policy. Desperate for a policy—any policy—they trawled through all the old ideas they could find and then, with sudden inspiration, the member for Werriwa looked around and said, `I've got one: it's a coastguard. Boy, we have got it. Let's show the Australian public that we are as good as anybody else and we can come up with a coastguard.'

speech.para: Unfortunately, there are more than a few problems with the idea. First of all, to exclude the way that it was brought up as an old idea, what about duplication? This is what all the experts who have looked at it have said: `We have a Navy and we have Coastwatch. We do not need duplication of services. We do not need duplication of personnel, we do not need duplication of administration and we do not need to wear the extra cost to achieve nothing more.' What we have now is an extremely good set-up. For the benefit of the member for Werriwa and for Junior here, whose seat I do not remember, we will go through what we—

talk.start.para: —He didn't call you `Senior', did he.
—I would be glad to be called `Senior'.
(Mr Jenkins)—Order! The parliamentary secretary will refer to members by their titles.
—Perhaps, Mr Deputy Speaker, you could refresh my memory as to the title of the young man at the table.
—He is the honourable member for McMillan.
—For the information of the member for McMillan, we have a Customs—
—You don't hear me calling you an old woman.
—I have no objection if you want to call me an old woman.
—Order! The parliamentary secretary will ignore the interjections and the honourable member for McMillan will cease interjecting.

—I am very happy to go with the title of `old woman' if that is what you wish to call me. That is about the level of sophistication of the opposition, to refer to people as `old women'. I can wear that if that is what you want to call me. For your information, member for McMillan, we have a Customs National Marine Unit which operates a fleet of eight 35-metre Bay class vessels, capable of providing up to 2,400 sea days per year. In 2001-02, officers boarded more than 240 vessels. Customs Coastwatch has a fleet of 15 aircraft and two helicopters. It operates 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. Coastwatch currently has access to the intelligence of the Australian Federal Police, the Australian Customs Service, the Australian Defence Force, the Australian Fisheries Management Authority and the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs. Both the National Marine Unit and Customs Coastwatch work with our Navy, Air Force and Army on two programs. Are you listening, member for McMillan? You might actually learn something here. Those two programs are Operation Relex, a program to detect, intercept and deter vessels carrying unauthorised arrivals, and Operation Cranberry, a program of air, sea and land surveillance to detect illegal activities such as smuggling and fishing.
—This is supposed to be a debating chamber, not a reading class.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, can I comment that, while the member for McMillan was making his speech, I did not make one interjection.
—Everyone else did.

—I believe I made one short interjection during the member for Werriwa's speech. Mr Deputy Speaker, could I ask that you enforce the same courtesy from the opposition as we gave to them. It would really assist. Let us have a look at this idea that the member for Werriwa has come up with. Do you know what it reminded me of? Tommy the tugboat! Instead of Tommy the tugboat, what have we got? We have Collie the coastguard, with its flotilla of little volunteer rowboats, rowing around the Pacific, rowing around the Indian Ocean, saying, `Oh, what can we see out here from our little fishing boats?' This is your idea of Australian security. This is your idea, instead of using the sophisticated system we already have—the Navy, Coastwatch and all that goes with it, and the Customs services and all the vessels. It is your idea to add this third ridiculous service, which is Collie the coastguard and its flotilla of little volunteers. Is that really what you think Australia's defence needs? Can I also remind the member for Werriwa, if you are talking about Australia, Australia's—
—You really should dry out, Chris.
—Could I ask the Deputy Speaker what the member for Werriwa meant when he said I should dry out?
—Order! It would assist the chair if the honourable member for Werriwa would withdraw that remark.
—The member for Hindmarsh is slurring her words, but I am happy to withdraw it.
—The honourable member should withdraw without any additions.
—I withdraw.

—Thank you to the member for Werriwa for his gracious withdrawal. It is extremely gracious of you after suggesting that I was standing at the dispatch box, having drunk too much. It was a delightful withdrawal from the member for Werriwa. Can I go back to the whole question of this MPI today, which is the need for an effective border security strategy. Let us have a look at what happened between 1989 and 2001. There were 13,400 people who arrived in Australia between 1989 and 2001. In 2000-01, there were 4,137 boat arrivals. But, under coalition policy, there have been no boat arrivals on the Australian mainland since September 2001.
—Right; that's a policy that works.

—This is the coalition's policy, and it works. This is the Pacific strategy. This is the strategy that this rabble of an opposition wants to get rid of. This is the strategy that works, and what does the opposition say? `Let's get rid of the Pacific strategy. Instead, we'll bring in Collie the coastguard and the flotilla of little volunteer boats.'
—That's Attila the Hun.
—Throwing out the Pacific strategy, what will we have instead? We will encourage the boat people, the people smugglers to bring people into Australia—
—You'll have to correct this Hansard.
—Can I say, Mr Deputy Speaker, the personal abuse that is coming from the other side is an example of what a low rabble that side is.
—An absolute disgrace!
—Yes.
—At least we're sober.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, the member for Werriwa said, `At least we're sober,' implying, I think, that I am not sober. Could I ask him to withdraw?
—Order! The honourable member for Werriwa will withdraw—formally, please.
—I'm not far wrong, but I withdraw.
—Order! I have warned the honourable member not to have additions.
—I withdraw.

—Can I say, seriously, that I take increasing offence to that. The implication there is typical of the nasty, mean-minded mouth that is the opposition in this place. It is a rabble that cannot come up with a policy; a rabble that cannot come up with an idea; a rabble that, to come up with a policy, has to go back to a 1950s idea from the Liberal government—indeed, a hopeless opposition. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the amendments be agreed to.

speech.para: The Telecommunications Competition Bill 2002 was passed by the Senate yesterday with a number of amendments made by the government, the opposition and the Australian Democrats. The government is of the view that this piece of legislation should not be held up, as this would increase regulatory uncertainty for the telecommunications industry. Accordingly, the government believes the House should accept the amended bill. The government amendments aim to improve the proposed accounting separation framework which will be imposed upon Telstra. Firstly, Senate amendment (28) requires that all reasonable steps be taken to ensure that a special Telstra direction is given within six months of the commencement of the bill. The special Telstra direction is one that relates to Telstra's wholesale and retail operations. It requires the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, the ACCC, to exercise its powers to make rules requiring Telstra to keep and retain particular records, prepare reports based on those records and deliver those reports to the ACCC.

Secondly, amendment (28)(3) sets out the procedure that must be followed before the minister can make a special Telstra direction. The minister must publish a draft of that direction, invite people to make submissions on the draft direction within a specified time limit and consider any submissions that are received before making the direction. Thirdly, there are some minor technical amendments consequential to these amendments: Senate amendments (25) and (27). Fourthly, Senate amendment (26) clarifies that the minister may only give a direction to the ACCC to exercise its powers under this part in a way that means that the minister would not be able to give direction to the ACCC not to exercise its powers under these sections. Fifthly, Senate amendment (26)(1B) enables the minister to give a written direction to the ACCC requiring it to prepare a specified kind of analysis of the report and to publish the analysis within a specified period after receiving the report. Senate amendment (8) enables matters in an instrument to be incorporated by reference.

The government amendments—Senate amendments (1) to (5)—also refine the amendments to the preselection provisions in the Telecommunications Act so that the ACCC will make the threshold decision on which services should be preselectable, but the ACA will determine the preselection requirement for those services, including exemptions from the requirements. Senate amendment (9) provides a right to seek merits review by the Australian Competition Tribunal in relation to access disputes that were notified to the ACCC before the introduction of the bill in the House of Representatives on 26 September 2002.

The government amendments also include some minor technical amendments. Senate amendment (18) ensures that provisions relating to the expiry time of anticipatory class exemptions and individual anticipatory exemptions are similar. Senate amendments (21) and (24) amend provisions relating to special access undertakings 152CBA and 152CBF to make it clear that the reference to active declared service is a declaration in the ordinary sense, under 152AL(3), not the deemed declaration that results from the proposals in the bill, under 152AL(7). Senate amendment (20) is an amendment to proposed subsection 152AL(7) to clarify that, if a special access undertaking is subject to limitations, the service specified in the undertaking is deemed to be a declared service and is therefore subject to the standard access obligations only to the extent that the service falls within the scope of the limitations.

In addition to the government amendments, some non-government amendments were passed by the Senate. While the government does not believe that these amendments are necessary, it does not consider that they detract from the significant overall benefits that will be achieved from the passage of the bill. Therefore, the government believes that the House should accept these amendments. These amendments include an amendment which means that telecommunications carriers will continue to have an obligation to lodge industry development plans. As a consequence of this amendment, a further government amendment was made to the bill to improve the exemption and verification process for industry development plans. This amendment allows the industry regulator, the Australian Communications Authority, to exempt certain specified kinds of carriers from the obligation to lodge industry development plans. Senate amendments (10) to (14) to part 3 of schedule 2 require the ACCC to hold a public inquiry before a declaration under section 152AL of the Trade Practices Act expires. Amendments to parts 11 and 12 of schedule 2—amendments (15) to (17), (19), (22) and (23)—remove the requirement that the ACCC have regard to the views of the minister in its consideration of anticipatory exemptions and special access undertakings.

The government considers that the bill as amended will provide a boost to competition by making the telecommunications competition regime more timely, effective and accountable. I therefore recommend that the House agree to the bill as amended.
Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I will be brief because the opposition support these amendments to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Structured Settlements) Bill 2002. This will provide consequent benefits both for the injured person, who will have a guarantee of a steady stream of income, and for insurers.
