speech.para: These amendments are quite different and they apply to different sections of the bill but, for reasons of convenience, as discussed with the shadow minister, it is appropriate, given the time constraints, to handle them together. The government opposes amendment (9), which was moved by the opposition. It would allow the injured person or his or her legal representative to purchase a tax-free annuity or deferred lump sum. This replaces the requirement in the bill that the defendant or his or her insurer must agree to purchase the annuity. The government believes that requiring a defendant or his or her insurer to purchase an annuity in order to qualify for the tax concessions contained in this bill is desirable for a number of reasons. The tax exemption provided by this bill is intended to encourage the take-up of income streams in place of lump sum compensation. This has the potential to place downward pressure on settlement costs and therefore on insurance premiums. This benefit could be lost if the injured person could choose whether or not he or she purchased the annuity with what was essentially a lump sum compensation award.

The approach of the government ensures that the annuity is used to meet expenses arising from injuries rather than for a different purpose. Further, under the amendment moved by the opposition, there would need to be administrative arrangements established to ensure that annuities are purchased with the funds received. The opposition amendment introduces the potential for an injured person to agree to purchase an annuity but not to follow through, despite his or her initial intentions. Requiring the defendant or insurer to make the final purchase ensures that only funds received in compensation are used to purchase the structured settlement, rather than other funds. Requiring the defendant or insurer to make the purchase also encourages financial planning beforehand. It enables settlements to be reached with the defendant to take into account longer term considerations.

Requiring defendants to purchase annuities has worked well overseas and is considered best practice. The requirement is supported by the structured settlements group, which represents both defendant and plaintiff based organisations. For these reasons, the government does not support the opposition amendment. In the circumstances, my friend opposite might be prepared to reconsider the position of the opposition.

Amendment (13) was moved by the Australian Democrats in the Senate. It will not come as any surprise to the House that the government also opposes the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats. This amendment would require insured persons to obtain independent financial advice before entering into a structured settlement. However, there is no definition of an independent financial adviser in this context, so the provision would be difficult to enforce. The nature of the advice to be sought is also poorly defined. As it stands, each case would require a decision about whether the advice was independent and whether it was financial advice before adherence to the terms of the law could be determined. Furthermore, it is not clear what the consequences would be if the injured person failed to obtain independent financial advice. Because of the position of the amendment in the bill, it is not clear whether the intention is that this should mean that the exemption is denied. For these reasons, the government does not support the amendments circulated by the Democrats and carried in the other place.

talk.start.para: —Both of these amendments are suffering from what is called the `not invented here' syndrome—that is, if the government decides it cannot agree to amendments because they were not its idea, it comes up with the most convoluted arguments as to why it should not be the case. I accept that there are people who have been seriously involved in the longstanding and quite correct campaign in support of structured settlements who disagree with Labor's amendment in principle. I do not agree with them, but I do accept that. However, I have to say that, although Labor were not passionate about the Democrats amendment—we supported it in principle, but it was not ours—the government was really straining to come up with an argument that warranted voting against it.

speech.para: I want to say something in support of both amendments, particularly that which we initiated, but I want to make it clear right at the beginning that we have said from the outset that our commitment has been, since long before the last election and long before the crisis became publicly perceived in the areas of medical indemnity insurance, public liability and related matters, that we wanted to see structured settlements in place. It was our policy at the last election, and we will do nothing to interfere with it. So we will not be pursuing these amendments in the Senate in any way which runs the risk of holding up the bill. We want the bill to pass. It is a great pity it will not be a slightly better bill; nevertheless, structured settlements is a very positive principle and we welcome the government belatedly on board for the proposition. When we proposed it in the lead-up to the last election, they thought it was a bad idea and proposed not to do any such thing. It is another case of `not invented here'. I sometimes feel slightly guilty: if we had not proposed it, the government might have done it a lot earlier. If we had not proposed the amendment, the government might have considered the proposition more favourably—but there is this `not invented here' syndrome that gets in the way of good policy from time to time.

With regard to our amendment—and I will be brief because it has been debated both here and in the Senate—I think the government has the economics of this wrong. The proposal that the opposition put forward would have enabled an injured person or their legal representative to buy a tax concessional annuity as part of a settlement. Essentially what we are talking about is equality of rights to put offers on the table at the time of the negotiations. One of the primary roles of government in a market economy is to make sure that people who get involved in negotiations have some sort of equal bargaining power. This proposition would have allowed it; the government's proposition does not. Our proposal would have ensured that the uptake of structured settlements was encouraged on its own merits rather than because of any inherent and structured unfairness in the bargaining process.

We have taken on board representations that people have made to us about how it would be simpler to remove the timing concerns from the debate by restricting the purchase of such annuities to the time of settlement—we have accepted that. We think the amendment would have substantially improved the bill, enhancing its policy intent and encouraging the use of structured settlements in a responsible manner that protected the revenue, struck a more responsible balance between the competing interests and actually showed some understanding of the underlying economic principles that drive this proposition. I think it is a pity it will not be adopted. I suspect that sometime in the future it will be. But the most important thing is to get structured settlements in place; so we will not persist.

I will be very brief about the Democrats amendment. As I said, it was not our proposition; it was theirs. We supported it; we voted for it; we support it in principle. The government has argued that it cannot be made to work in practice—and I listened intently to the parliamentary secretary's explanation. I am sure it was a brief he was given by someone else, and he put it to the best of his ability here.

talk.start.para: —He put it pretty well.

—I am sure that you think so. I do not hold him responsible for the quality of the argument. He was the advocate with a lousy brief, and we have all been in that position from time to time in this place. It does not seem to me to be too difficult to make the details work but, as I say, I am relaxed about the proposition. It is certainly not central to the principles that drive the bill. It is a peripheral matter and should not be allowed to get in the way of the central principles. (Extension of time granted) While I think it is a pity that the amendments are not being taken up, the bill itself and the principle underlying it are so overdue that we will do nothing to impede the passage of this bill.

speech.para: Question agreed to.

debateinfo.title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (EARLIER ACCESS TO FARM MANAGEMENT DEPOSITS) BILL 2002

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 5 December, on motion by Mr Slipper:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —In rising to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Earlier Access to Farm Management Deposits) Bill 2002, I make it very clear from the outset that the opposition will be supporting this bill. It is a bill which amends the qualification conditions in the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 for taxation concessions under the Farm Management Deposit Scheme. The opposition has been calling for such action on the FMD scheme for some time now. For example, on 19 November, the Labor Party released its national drought plan—the six-point plan—and one of the points that we raised then was the proposition that there should be exceptional circumstances relief for farm management deposits. So it would be the height of hypocrisy for us, having advocated it and the government now having come to the party, not to support that which we previously advocated. It actually has in its origins something of the matter relating to the last debate, where we advocate a proposition, it finally comes to fruition through the government taking what we see as a belated initiative and so we support the initiative.

speech.para: I will now look at some of the background. The FMD scheme allows eligible primary producers to set aside pre-tax income in profitable years to establish cash reserves to help meet costs in low-income years. Primary producers are allowed to claim a deduction when they make a farm management deposit and then, when an FMD is withdrawn, the amount of the withdrawal is included in their assessable income in the withdrawal tax year. This allows income smoothing by primary producers, to allow them to make provision for bad years out of the income of good years. As I recall, it is a principle that was established through income equalisation deposits in the agricultural sector and that has been extended to other taxpayers, and properly so, over the years—mainly in the period of the Hawke government—to artists, composers, performers, production assistants and sportspersons to average their income over a number of years.

This is a sensible principle and it applies not only to agriculture; there should be income smoothing potential for occupations which have an intrinsic volatility of income. In particular, the Labor Party have long supported measures to address genuine cases to this effect in the area of primary production. In 1992, the current Leader of the Opposition, when he was Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, introduced farm management bonds, which were the predecessor of the current Farm Management Deposit Scheme. He said at that time:

quote.para: Income smoothing and the creation of reserves can be useful tools in risk management. Mechanisms such as tax averaging and Income Equalisation Deposits (IEDs) have important roles to play in financial management ... The Government will ensure that the entire package of income taxation and associated measures is providing both correct and consistent signals to farmers to encourage sustainable and efficient management systems.

speech.para: I think that is a pretty good summation of the underlying economic public policy principles in this area. It was our policy in 1992 and it remains our policy now.

I will now turn to the substantive provisions of this bill. It has to be recognised that, through operating programs such as the Farm Management Deposit Scheme, the Commonwealth is forgoing a certain amount of revenue compared with what would otherwise have been collected. This means, of course, that we have to take great care to ensure that only genuine cases qualify for such provisions. The primary integrity measure in the FMD scheme as it stands is that, to be eligible for the tax concession, no part of the deposit is allowed to be withdrawn within 12 months. We are moving to change that integrity measure; so, while I support it, we have to proceed with great caution. I want to outline it in a little bit of detail so that, in any future debates, the basis on which we are prepared to make this exception is very clear. At the moment, the only exceptions to this rule occur if the owner dies, becomes bankrupt, ceases to be a primary producer, or where there is a transfer to another financial institution.

The principle underlying this integrity measure is sound. The genuine use of such a scheme is for long-term provision for bad years. It is not about allowing artificial manipulation of incomes to switch income from the end of one financial year to the start of the next. Having said that, we have discovered, from the recent awful experience of the current severe drought, that this integrity measure has plainly been too restrictive. Responsible farmers who put money aside last year in reasonable expectation of the circumstances they might confront, and have subsequently been hit by drought, have been unable to access their money without a retrospective tax penalty. That was never the intention of the scheme.

The legislation will allow the tax concession to be maintained despite withdrawals being within the 12 months, under certain circumstances—and it is important that we define these fairly carefully. Firstly, it provides an exception to the 12-month waiting period for access to FMDs for persons in exceptional circumstances declared areas; secondly, it allows part of an FMD to be withdrawn within 12 months provided the remaining amount of the deposit is $1,000 or more and is retained in the account for at least 12 months; and, thirdly, it allows FMDs to be held in accounts of any term provided the amount is not withdrawn within 12 months from the date of deposit. The third point deals with a different problem from the one that we are primarily dealing with, but it is also valid and we support it. I note that the changed conditions regarding exceptional circumstances and partial withdrawals will apply from 1 July 2002. The changed conditions regarding term limits for deposit accounts will be backdated to the commencement of the FMD provisions on 2 January 1999, because they are so overdue and have been needed for almost four years.

As I noted earlier, the FMD reform plan is welcome, but it comes only after sustained pressure from the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow minister for primary industries and resources on this issue. On 19 November they jointly announced, as a key point in Labor's national drought plan, an FMD relief plan for those in exceptional circumstances areas. Labor's policy was to improve the Farm Management Deposit Scheme by committing to:

quote.para: Providing flexibility in accessing Farm Management Deposits to allow farmers in EC-declared areas to withdraw deposits within 12 months, without penalty, in this financial year.

speech.para: This is almost identical to what has come forward from the government, so we are pleased that they have shown sufficient flexibility to take up our proposals in this important area. The proposed amendment to the laws protecting the tax concession for short-term FMDs is also welcome, but its adoption is even more belated than the EC proposal. According to evidence given to Senate estimates last month, the government has known about legal uncertainty over the tax status of short-term farm management deposits since July 2001 but failed to act. This was grossly irresponsible behaviour at a time when all farmers who had rolled over FMDs within 12 months of deposit since 1999 were facing potentially massive tax bills from a potentially unfavourable tax ruling. We are pleased that this issue has now been clarified through a legislative amendment, but it is overdue. We also consider that clarifying the conditions regarding partial withdrawals is a sensible extension of flexibility in FMD arrangements. Accordingly, Labor will be supporting this bill.

I want to note a concern—similar to a concern I have expressed before—regarding the costing information that has come forward with this bill. We continually find with this government that the House is having to make decisions without being treated to the courtesy of a decent effort to provide costing information. It is a very arrogant approach. Of all the portfolio ministers in any government, you would expect the Treasurer to be the one who would pay due attention to the revenue impact of measures and ensure that the parliament is properly informed about them. After all, it is the Treasurer's responsibility.

talk.start.para: —He is not interested.

—Consistent with the increasingly cursory treatment he is giving his day job—as my colleague the member for Lowe says, he is not interested; he is merely waiting for the Prime Minister to declare his innings closed—we have seen an increasingly cursory treatment of the costing—

—You wish he was not! We have seen an increasingly cursory treatment of costings of measures in his portfolio. For example, we had the extraordinary spectacle of a consolidations measure costing a billion dollars being dealt with in a mere 50 words—that is $20 million a word. Then we had the demergers measure costed before us simply as `unquantifiable', due apparently to the difficulty in estimating the extent of behavioural change induced by the measure. The nominal cost of that measure was put in the region of a billion dollars, but the government did not see fit to provide a proper account of this expenditure to the House of Representatives. So it is part of a continuing pattern of behaviour. What do we find on this occasion? It is quite extraordinary. It says:

quote.para: ... apart from a timing effect, the overall cost of FMDs in the forward estimates will not be affected.

speech.para: But it is precisely the timing effect that costs the money. That is what is the cost to the Commonwealth. If we are changing the timing effect, we are changing the revenue. We are not stupid; we can work that out. You owe us the courtesy of telling us what the effect of that will be. It is precisely the timing effect that constitutes the tax concession—that is what is good about it; and that therefore seems to be a pretty flimsy excuse for not providing a proper costing to the House. The tax expenditure by the Commonwealth on this program is now very substantial. On 20 November this year the Prime Minister said:

quote.para: As at the 30th of June last—

speech.para: that is, 30 June this year—

quote.para: 43,000 Australian farmers had deposited over $2 billion dollars in the scheme.

speech.para: I continue to quote the Prime Minister, who went on to say:

quote.para: This reflects an approximate cost to the Commonwealth of $500 million in foregone tax revenue.

speech.para: So if the government can work out how much the program costs overall and if that is driven by timing effects, it does not seem to me too difficult for the government to meet its obligation to tell the parliament how much the measures in this bill will cost. When the debate is concluded by the parliamentary secretary I would very much appreciate him giving the House, the parliament and the people of Australia the courtesy of telling us what this is going to cost before we vote for it. Every citizen would want the parliament to know what proposed measures are going to cost before they are voted on. We support the proposition; we are not going to obstruct the proposition, we are going vote for this bill. But perhaps we should not have said that in advance. We might have got more courteous treatment if we had held out, but that would not have been very responsible. We are going to support it, but dealing with us in this way does not encourage us to support measures in the future.

As I noted previously, on 19 November the Labor Party announced its six-point national drought plan which contained these FMD measures that have now been taken up by the government. In addition to that, we committed to changes to cut through the red tape, to help farmers protect core breeding stock, to address feed grain shortage concerns, to stop the buck-passing and squabbling that drives everybody so mad about Commonwealth-state relations in this and other areas and to get rid of duplication and target programs to help those in need. The government has made a half-hearted attempt to move in the same direction but it still has a long way to go. We would greatly appreciate the government adopting the rest of the national drought plan, not because it would be good for us—it does not make any difference to us—but because it would be good for the nation, particularly for the farmers and communities affected.

But we should perhaps not be surprised that the government has been tardy in acting on drought relief. After all, the Treasurer took a very long time to be convinced that the drought was even a serious economic issue. In July, when he was asked directly about whether the GDP would be affected by the worsening drought, he replied:

quote.para: ... agricultural production is not a large part of Australia's GDP. So, the effect that it will have will affect that proportion of GDP that is made up of agricultural production.

speech.para: You can see him waving his hand dismissively in the press conference and saying, `That was clever! I got through that question at the press conference very cleverly.' But beneath the veneer of clever acting there is no substance. He simply missed the essential economic reality—which has come home to him now—that the flow-on impacts from this particular sector are very important for the rest of the economy. Apart from the dismissive attitude that the Treasurer had in July to the profound social concerns for so many businesses, families and communities, he missed the economic point, which is his ultimate responsibility. By the time of the release of the Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook last month, the inescapable reality of the budget numbers had forced him to change his tune. The MYEFO noted that the current disastrous drought is likely to reduce economic growth for the whole country by as much as three-quarters of a per cent of overall GDP. To give you an idea of scale, that is actually a reduction of one-fifth of the budget forecast growth for this year, or nearly $6 billion. There were people screaming out, trying to tell the Treasurer in July that it was a big problem, but he would not listen.

The MYEFO also said that total farm production is projected to decline by around 17 per cent in 2002-03, with much greater declines in grain production. It is clear that, by any measure, this is a drastic and severe impact on the national economy. But the Treasurer missed it. It is another example of that arrogance and complacency that led him to miss the slowly emerging train crash of the HIH collapse, the crisis in public liability insurance, the breakdown in corporate governance and accountability, the explosion in household and credit card debt and the clear signs that housing prices are rising unsustainably. In each instance, the Treasurer has either failed to see it or initially dismissed it and then, when it had finally become a crisis, he has acted belatedly. In each of these cases, a Treasurer who was concentrating on his job would have seen the signs early and headed the issues off before they became profound national crises. The Treasurer did not cause those crises but he failed to act early enough to head them off.

These days the government talks a lot about pre-emptive doctrines; it talks rather too loudly and rather inappropriately about them. Maybe it should concentrate a little bit more on some pre-emptive action domestically to head off threats to the domestic financial security of ordinary Australian working families. This sort of real domestic responsibility is very important at the current time. Questions over the investment outlook, along with the high level of debt and the weak budget position, leave the economy particularly vulnerable if the government's assumptions about the breaking of the drought and the strength of the international economy prove too optimistic.

It is a cause of continuing concern to me that, in the Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook report, the government's projections about economic growth and its consequential views about the budget are based on some very risky assumptions. To be fair, they are very explicit assumptions—as they should be. You do not have to dig in the document to find them; the Treasurer and the Treasury have been quite up front and have explicitly stated what their assumptions are—and some of them are the only assumptions they could have made. For example, they have made an assumption that the drought will last only for this season. It makes no sense in an economic forecasting document to make any other assumption, so I am not in that instance critical. I simply say it is, however, a risky assumption. It is the only one that could be made, but we all know that that means there are serious economic risks out there.

The forecast about the international economy is certainly on the optimistic side of the collective opinion on how the international economy might go. I sincerely hope it is correct; it is very important for Australia that it is. The assumptions about housing are not only optimistic; today's figures make them look a little bit premature. With Christmas coming and Australian families under financial pressure—thanks to high debt levels and the high taxing policies of the Treasurer—it is vital that economic growth continues at a healthy level, so I hope all those assumptions come to pass. Even so, we will see the economy slowing. With all those assumptions coming through, it should start to pick up by next financial year. Let us all hope that is true. Particularly, let us all hope the assumption that this drought will not be long lasting is true, because it is having such a profound impact on so many Australians.

I was recently out in the Dubbo area, in the Riverina and down in Mildura. While some of those areas, because they are based on irrigation agriculture, are actually still looking very green, out west of Dubbo there are some areas of prime agricultural land that I have never seen looking as they do. I have seen bits of Australia looking like that because I have been in the desert, but I have never seen what are renowned areas of great agricultural production in this country in such devastated condition. I have been in droughts. I grew up in Western Australia, and many of the farming areas are not so much drought prone—although droughts can occur anywhere—as very dry farming country. Yet, the area I saw was a shock to me even though I have been travelling in rural Australia for most of my life. Let us hope that, for human as well as economic reasons, the assumptions about the drought breaking are correct.

What I really want to emphasise in concluding, and in coming back to the bill, is that we have to have the Treasurer focused back on the job. He has to focus on applying the kind of whole of economy and whole of portfolio scrutiny he gets paid to apply and on providing the sort of economic leadership Australians are entitled to expect. Rather, he has shown complacency and is marking time. We continually see the `these other issues aren't important enough to warrant my attention' attitude from the Treasurer in all of those areas I listed earlier, and we saw it with respect to ethanol in the parliament yesterday. This bill contains positive reforms to the qualifications on conditions for tax concessions under the FMD scheme and, as I indicated at the outset, the opposition will be supporting the bill. While the government has made a half-hearted attempt to adopt Labor's drought policy, it still has a long way to go. I hope it will put aside its political preferences on drought relief and implement the remaining elements of the national drought plan as soon as possible. We are pleased to see this measure—one part of our six-point plan—adopted and we support the bill to implement it.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to hear that the member for Fraser and the Labor Party support the measures in the Taxation Laws Amendment (Earlier Access to Farm Management Deposits) Bill 2002 to assist farmers, because this is one of those issues that really deserves strong bipartisan support. But, as always, politics has crept into the debate, and I have to answer some of the points the member for Fraser made. In 1993 I entered this parliament and in 1994 I became shadow minister for small business and women, and I toured extensively the drought affected areas of New South Wales. At that time, the then Labor Prime Minister, Mr Paul Keating, had no sympathy for farmers and, in fact, made a public comment that they should make provision for these events.

speech.para: I met with farming families in New South Wales that had been in the grip of a horrendous drought for four successive years. The experience of touring those areas and of talking to the men and women on the land will be forever etched in my memory. It was a very sad situation. Some of the women were going into the towns once a week, taking a shower and doing the family laundry because there was no water to shower or do the family laundry with. The women in towns like Casino and other towns in New South Wales had gathered together and done a roster so that the women had a place to go to do the washing and have a shower. They were keeping their water to try to keep their breeding herd alive so that, when the drought broke, they had something to go back to. There were many occasions when we cried together, and I was very touched by that. Even talking about it now brings out that emotion. It was a very emotional experience.

I came back to the parliament determined to try to influence government—and the opposition at that time—to recognise that drought is a feature of the Australian landscape and that we really need to have a policy that is responsive to these events. It was not until 1994, when Ray Martin and the first Farmhand project really gripped the imagination of the people, that Paul Keating and the Labor Party were shamed into doing something to assist those farmers. I have to make that point.

As for economic management, I think our Treasurer has done an outstanding job of demonstrating economic leadership. The Treasurer, the Prime Minister, the Leader of the National Party and Deputy Prime Minister, and all of cabinet have, I think, been very responsive to the impact of this drought, which is the most severe we have seen in 100 years. They have been very responsive to the needs of Australian farmers and, indeed, the farming communities. It is not only farmers who are affected. During that trip, one of the things that was brought home to me very strongly was that it is not just the farming community that suffers during these occasions; it is the businesspeople and it is the families that live in the towns that support the farming community. The Prime Minister and the cabinet, including the Treasurer, have put together a very responsive package which addresses the needs of the whole farming community.

But drought is a regular event in Australia, and with the country in the grip of this drought right at the moment farming families all over the country are severely affected. This time it is not just in New South Wales; it is affecting my state of Western Australia. A drought of this magnitude really does highlight the importance of agriculture. On that point, I agree with the member for Fraser that it does have quite a substantial impact. With the Reserve Bank forecast of a reduction in income of $7 billion, it is not only the rural communities that will feel the effects of this year's drought. This forecast represents about one per cent of our domestic growth, and it is significant. Harvesting is not yet complete, but there are already signs that the yields will be substantially down on last year's.

The electorate of Pearce in Western Australia is not as hard-hit as other areas in Western Australia or other areas of Australia. But the further east you go in Western Australia the worse it gets, and some farmers have not even put in a crop this season. In parts of Pearce, the harvest is going to be well down on what it was last year. I have been ringing around talking to farmers, because in different areas it is a different scene. In some parts of my electorate they are having the best season they have had; but in York, for example, one farmer told me that he usually exports 2,500 tonnes of hay. This year, having just finished cropping his hay, he will export 200 tonnes of hay. That is a very big reduction. Some farmers are just starting to crop some wheat, and this year's crop looks like being down 60 per cent on last year's crop.

The shortage of grain is impacting on prices for stock feed as well. It does have a ripple effect in the community, and that in turn will affect other consumable goods and food products. Pig farmers in my electorate have sufficient water, but the price of grain is making it too expensive for them to continue to raise pigs. They are quite concerned about the situation. The high cost of feed exacerbates the plight of many farmers who run stock, and they have trouble keeping their breeding herds alive. Apart from the immediate impact of having little or no income stream now and in the immediate future, the loss of their breeders denies these farmers the opportunity to restart their operations when the drought does break.

Some relief may come from imported grain, which I believe is keeping the price of local produce at a slightly more affordable level. However, I was very pleased to hear in yesterday's announcement by the federal Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Warren Truss, that the Commonwealth will introduce a significant new measure to assist farmers to meet the cost of stock feed and to manage drought recovery. This should not be viewed as an expense but as an investment in the future, as it can take many years to develop good breeding stock.

I was also extremely pleased to read in the Prime Minister's press release on the new drought measures that there will be additional spending on top of the $360 million that was announced just recently. A further $368 million has been committed by the federal government over three years. These are comprehensive measures that will provide financial support to farmers and communities hardest hit by the drought. These new measures are, as I said, on top of the $360 million that the Commonwealth is already expecting to spend in areas that are declared exceptional circumstance areas.

The government has decided to provide six months interim income support for all eligible farmers in areas suffering a one in 20-year rainfall deficiency over nine months—that is, March 2002 to November 2002. The Prime Minister has made the point—and I think this is an important point, because some areas may not be in this category now—that should the proportion of farmers affected in like manner in any other state reach 80 per cent, then eligible farmers across the whole state will have access to similar interim income support. Eligibility for the additional support available under full exceptional circumstances support arrangements will continue to be assessed on a case-by-case basis under the existing criteria. In addition, the government will provide an interest rate subsidy on new and additional loans up to $100,000, available for two years for stock support and drought recovery. This will be available to all newly eligible farmers in the areas listed, and there is quite an extensive list. A number of those places in WA such as Jerramungup, Corrigin, Kulin, Lake Grace, Coolgardie, Cunderdin, Esperance, Morawa, Mount Marshall, Merredin and others will be eligible for support.

I was also pleased to see in the Prime Minister's press release that small businesses in exceptional circumstance declared areas will also receive interest rate relief. Small businesses in affected areas face enormous financial hardship. Again, it has a huge impact on the town if they have to actually close down—and usually they never return to the town—so that is a very welcome announcement. These measures come on the back of other major announcements by the Prime Minister, who said in his recent press release:

quote.para: The Government is deeply sympathetic to the plight of farmers and communities suffering in this drought.

speech.para: He went on to say:

quote.para: We want to work with farmers and communities in helping them deal with this drought. We will continue to talk to farmers and their communities on how the Commonwealth may support them.

speech.para: I think the key to this responsiveness has been the consultation that has taken place with the Prime Minister personally, but also with the members of his cabinet who have responsibility for these areas—the Deputy Prime Minister in particular and the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. As I said before, the federal government expects that, on the basis of current and conservative figures, exceptional circumstance funding will amount to some $360 million. The Prime Minister made it clear that, if more regions are declared, these will automatically be included and the amount will increase accordingly. In addition, the government will streamline the consideration of advice on exceptional circumstance applications to ensure that there is no unnecessary delay.

This contrasts with the lack of action by the WA state government, which is once again to be found dragging its heels in response to the effects of the drought in Western Australia. Despite the fact that it has been known for some time that the season was going to be bad, particularly the further east you get, the WA government seems completely unprepared for the adverse conditions. In a recent article entitled `WA wants funds to go direct', Chelsea Cormell said that WA farm groups are urging the federal government to bypass state governments and typically slow channels of exceptional circumstances to spend additional drought relief on direct grants. She went on to say:

quote.para: The announcement by Prime Minister John Howard that spending could increase up to five times the current rate if drought persisted was welcomed by the WA Farmers and Graziers Association. But the groups agreed systematic changes were needed as states continued to refuse to participate in cost sharing arrangements and lengthy EC processes hindered the recovery of farming communities. PGA President Barry Court said under the current system little assistance flowed through to farmers because of State red tape and posturing.

speech.para: In a press release put out by National Party of WA representative the Hon. Murray Criddle, MLC, Agricultural Region, he accused the Gallop government of `incompetence by failing to assess the effects on Western Australia's economy of the worst drought in decades'. Apparently, the National Party wanted the official breakdown on the economic and social impact of the drought, but, according to Mr Criddle, all they got from the state Treasurer was a blank look. Mr Criddle went on to say:

quote.para: ... many parts of WA have experienced three years of drought but the (WA) Treasurer hasn't bothered to assess the impact on the State's current economic position, the effects on small business in country towns, or the social effects on regional communities. We took the bureaucrats from Canberra through the Northern and Eastern wheat belt where they met not only with farmers but small business owners struggling to meet high interest payments and overdraft accounts because of the downturn.

speech.para: He continued:

quote.para: We were delighted that the Federal drought package included Centrelink assistance for business operators and workers who have been laid off or had hours reduced but we are disgusted that the Gallop Government has virtually left the regions to fend for themselves.

speech.para: By contrast, the Prime Minister and cabinet have been to visit some of the drought affected areas, have put together a package of measures and have responded in a very timely way to this crisis.

Apart from the commitment to exceptional circumstance assistance, the Prime Minister announced additional measures on 27 November. These included a couple of million dollars of funding for personal counselling services in drought affected areas. This is very important because we know that, despite the fact that the farming community are a very stoic, tough breed and can usually work through their problems, when people are hit hard like this over a long period of time—and it sometimes comes on the back of frost or frost comes on the back of a drought—there is a limit to what people can endure. I believe counselling services are very important in rural areas during this time.

Ten million dollars is to be put through the Natural Heritage Trust for environmental work in drought areas. This will target work that protects the land, water, vegetation and biodiversity resource base from the effects of drought, and will assist recovery. One million dollars is to go to a pest and animal management grant. This is an important drought management and recovery measure. Feral animals in particular can overgraze land which is in difficulty, and it does not recover or does not recover very easily. The government put $5 million into this year's Farmhand program and $1 million into the Country Women's Association Emergency Aid Fund to supplement the Farmhand program.

In addition, the measures in this bill will assist farmers in exceptional circumstance drought declared areas to access farm deposits earlier than they would otherwise be entitled to. The Farm Management Deposit Scheme allows eligible primary producers to set aside pre-tax income in profitable years to establish cash reserves to help meet costs in low-income years. These farm management deposits complement other risk management strategies available to primary producers, such as developing fodder and water reserves, financial planning and diversifying their production systems. Primary producers can claim a tax deduction when they make a farm management deposit. When the farm management deposit is withdrawn, the amount of the withdrawal is then included in their assessable income in the withdrawal tax year. Currently, no part of the deposit can be withdrawn within 12 months, except in circumstances outlined in the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. These include the death of the owner, bankruptcy or where a person ceases to be a primary producer or transfers the funds to another financial institution. Unless these circumstances exist, the funds will not be treated as a farm management deposit from the time the deposit is made. In recognition of the particularly tough drought conditions, the government seeks to amend this legislation to provide an exception to the 12-month waiting period for access to FMDs for persons in exceptional circumstance declared areas. That will allow part of an FMD to be withdrawn within 12 months, provided the remaining amount of the deposit is $1,000 or more and is retained in the account for at least 12 months. It will allow farm management deposits to be held in accounts for any term, provided the amount is not withdrawn within 12 months from the date of the deposit. The changes to the Farm Management Deposit Scheme are part of an important range of measures being taken by the federal government to assist farmers through one of the most crippling droughts on record.

As I said before, many people are affected. This is the first time, since I have been here, that a government has given particular recognition to workers in these areas. I was pleased to see that the Prime Minister, in his press release, recognised that there will be increasing unemployment, even though it may be of a temporary nature. The government is keen to ensure that those who temporarily lose employment are kept in touch with the work force and are able to remain in their communities. Again, experienced work forces are important in farming communities. If some assistance can hold them together and get them over this temporary period, it would be a very important measure. This demonstrates that the government has done its homework, recognises what these communities need and has gone through the consultative process with people in rural areas to make sure that this package of measures to assist farmers will hit the right target.

The government will introduce a number of special measures to assist job seekers in drought affected areas. These include establishing a Work for the Dole type program in drought affected areas to develop and carry out activities that have a skill retention and drought mitigation flavour. In drought affected areas, this program will allow job seekers access to job seeker training as soon as they become unemployed and will allow employees facing imminent retrenchment access to job matching services. I want to finish with the words of the Deputy Prime Minister in his press release of 27 November:

quote.para: The entire community believed government of all persuasions should do what they can to relieve what he felt would be a “summer from hell” for rural communities.

speech.para: I completely support the measures in this bill.

talk.start.para: —I am happy to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Earlier Access to Farm Management Deposits) Bill 2002. This bill deals with substantial taxation measures which will also have economic and social effects. They will also have an effect on the integrity of the tax system. These particular changes need to be looked at closely because they may change the integrity checks that the previous bill encompassed. The core change to allow people to withdraw from the funds within the first 12 months will take away the protection that was there in the original bill, so we hope that it is soundly based. We on the Labor side think that this is well based, which is the reason we put this initiative in play before the government came up with not only this bill but anything near the genesis of this bill. Labor's six-point national drought plan was put forward by the shadow minister for primary industries and resources, Senator Kerry O'Brien, in conjunction with the Leader of the Opposition, on 19 November. I will talk to the key points in that plan later in this speech, but first I will cover the second core point in this bill.

speech.para: This bill realises what Labor put forward as a responsible opposition. We act as responsibly in opposition as we did when we were in government. When the member for Pearce commented, with regard to the former member for Blaxland and Prime Minister, that `Paul Keating had no sympathy for farmers' she was responding to what she thought was a political attack on the current Treasurer. It was ungenerous of her to put forward that political statement. I was there and I worked for the former Prime Minister at the time those statements were made. He had a bit of experience in farming and sharecropping when he was young. He certainly had experience in other areas of farming over a number of years, namely pig farming. We know that, day after day in this parliament and in the other place, the former Senator Michael Baume went through more than $300,000 of public money doing searches into the transactions and financial dealings of the former Prime Minister. How you treat farmers in difficulty is a question that Labor, when in government, tried to deal with in a responsible fashion, and I think we were successful in that.

The current shadow treasurer alluded earlier in this debate to the fact that Labor put forward drought assistance plans while in government, particularly around 1994. Although they may not have been perfect, I have yet to come across any eternally perfect set of measures a government has put in place. It is always possible to redesign, to take into account changing circumstances, to see things within a larger context or to look at public policy avenues that are innovative and simply were not thought of by people in the past. When in government, our record in dealing with drought and the economic and social effects of drought on farming people was strong.

The campaign against the former Prime Minister, and the campaign by the then opposition against our government, on these matters was reprehensible from start to finish. The member for Pearce's comments not only are ungenerous but they bring up the vast, dark stain that ran from one end of this parliament to the other—the more than a decade-long vilification of someone who gave his life and his strength to parliamentary life and to the service of the people of Australia, initially as Treasurer and then as Prime Minister. He had regard not to himself but to the public policy and governmental demands that were on him, as a minister of the Crown, and on the Australian Labor Party government that he was proud to be a part of and later to lead. That aside, Labor as a responsible opposition has put into place a plan not only for the current situation but also for the situation as it has been for a number of months now.

The government may choose to attack Senator O'Brien, as shadow minister, because he is from Tasmania and not from the mainland. He is currently from Tasmania. They might attack him because he is from Chester Hill, because he grew up in the electorates of Reid and Blaxland, because he had a city background—as I have a city background. It may be normal for the government to do as they have done in the past: attack people and say, `You shouldn't talk about any of this stuff because you don't actually come from a country seat or a country area.' But even people in the city have backgrounds. My mother's family came to Bankstown in 1925 when she was, shall we say, of tender years—about one year old. I think the last time I referred to this she corrected me and said that it was when she was about four years of age. They came from West Wyalong. Why did they move from West Wyalong? Because in 1925 it was drought affected. The severity of the drought in the mid to late twenties made life in the country impossibly hard.

You need to reflect on the fact that worldwide—Australia included—the 1920s were a period of enormous economic growth. Despite that, Australia's level of unemployment ran between five and 10 per cent throughout the 1920s. In country areas there was no assistance; you could not get any help. Even if you lived in the city, you were in a position where you were right up against it. Things were a bit better than they were in the two other great droughts that Australia experienced in the 19th century. There was the drought in the 1840s. At the end of the 1840s, the combination of the drought and the fact that not enough people were coming into the country meant that country areas were depopulated, there was not an adequate country work force and primary production levels dramatically fell in output and productive capacity.

A much more significant period of drought was from 1890 until about 1905. The great drought of the 1890s took at least until 1905 before we got a resolution of it. Combined with the four great strikes of 1890 to 1894 in a country that had no social security provision whatsoever, that made it hard for people from one end of Australia to the other to survive. There was not only a lack of work, because people had been thrown out by their bosses, but also a country that was ill prepared for the intensity of the drought of the 1890s. Why was that the case? It was because the period from the 1860s to the 1880s was the greatest period of economic development Australia has ever seen—particularly country Australia, because the harvests were incomparably good, as the seasons were incomparably good. Anyone taking up farming in certain parts of Victoria, in the Wimmera or in those areas that opened up as wheat belts in South Australia and Western Australia experienced perfect conditions year after year, season after season, for three decades, and they came to think that these conditions were just the norm. The drought of the 1890s taught them that the norm in Australia is that this is a country of drought, and drought can be extremely severe and extremely difficult.

My great-grandfather on my mother's side spent his time in country Australia as an engineer building bridges and roads throughout New South Wales. What he originally saw—a country that had been highly productive and that allowed for a large work force—was eroded to the point where it was very tough to survive in Australia. That understanding in fact informed the formation of the great trade unions, such as the Australian Workers Union, who fought for farming people, for the shearers and for those people who provided the work forces within the country and tried to get them a better deal, particularly from 1890 to 1894 at the time of the great shearer's strike and associated strikes. So Labor policy has its genesis in a period of drought. It has its genesis in a period of fighting for people who have not got much behind them when times are tough.

When we were in government in 1994, when Australia was experiencing a period of drought, we tried to deal not just with the economic impact but also with the social impact of drought. That was also done at a state level. The six-point plan that we put forward—a comprehensive plan released in summary by the Leader of the Opposition and Senator O'Brien and the more extensive point by point enumeration of that plan—went to the core problems that we saw as not being addressed at the moment. The politics of this situation and the manner in which Mr Truss, as minister, has dealt with it were fully addressed in the matter of public interest put forward by Senator O'Brien in the Senate on 13 November 2002. He made a series of points not just about the laggardness of the minister in this regard but also relating to the fact that the minister and the government had an inability to see the larger ramifications of what was staring them in the face.

This bill is effectively a Labor bill because it takes up point 2 of this national plan. We said that we should improve the Farm Management Deposit Scheme and that the government should provide flexibility in accessing farm management deposits to allow farmers in EC declared areas to withdraw deposits within 12 months without penalty in this financial year. The key to that is that, normally, in setting up any range of provisions, it is important to keep the integrity of the tax system in mind. I am sure that the secretary of the department, in giving advice to the Treasurer, ensured that the original provision was there. Why? Because this is a case similar to capital gains tax. If you buy a lot of shares, our provisions state that if you deal in those shares within twelve months you are effectively trading or speculating in those shares, and therefore you should pay your normal marginal tax rate on any profits made in that regard.

After 12 months there is a concessional rate. It is treated differently now to how it was treated in our period, but it has the same rough effect. Post 12 months, it is a different regime. The regime relates to farmers who have opened accounts. According to the Prime Minister on 20 November this year, 43,000 farmers have taken the opportunity to open these management accounts, to the tune of $2,000 million worth of deposits. The way these accounts operate normally is that the person is allowed a tax deduction on the moneys put into that fund. Until this bill passes, and it will with our support here and in the Senate, when a person withdraws the money in another year—because it has to be at least a year on, and it cannot be a good year but a year when the person really needs it—then that person pays tax on that but at a lower rate. This is about the biblical good years and bad—seven years good, seven years bad.

This goes to the point that the former Prime Minister made: in farming policy we cannot have the old National Party approach. The old National Party approach was: capitalise your profits, socialise your losses. It cannot be all one way. The minister at the table, the Minister for Children and Youth Affairs, the person coming after me, would know that his father and those other National Party members involved in pushing stuff forward—including Black Jack McEwen—fully understood that the bottom line in regard to this was that that was an epithet that could be tagged on them. It was tagged on them by Labor Party members at the time—and I think utterly appropriately. We have in fact seen it in a number of measures taken by this government—haltingly, almost blindly stumbling through—to actually attempt to bring back support from country Australia, to go over the line and press it. They are likely to go back to that policy when the farming community is in drought. We need a responsible policy with regard to this.

As important as farming is, at six per cent of our productive capacity, it is different from what it was in the 19th and 20th centuries. It is fundamental for people in provincial towns. It is fundamental for those communities that depend on our farming activity. It is also fundamental for those farming communities that depend on the feedlot industry. It is important for a range of intensive industries because, as we all know, the nature of farming has dramatically changed over the last decades. That being said, we say that responsible policy is making this change, with some care, if you have an absolutely exceptional circumstance—such as the fact that this drought qualifies as being as bad as we have had in 100 years or so, back to the great drought of the 1890s. The integrity of the system should be maintained, and that is where the Taxation Office will need to monitor this over time. In this period of great need, you need to modify and change.

We are glad that this idea we put forward is being taken up. The shadow minister has indicated that the government has dealt with one—point No. 2—and there are five to go. Of those five, there is a series—and I do not have time to go through the lot—that need to be taken into account. We have latterly had the announcement from the Deputy Prime Minister. A series of other measures will be looked at and attempted. These are the critical ones. It is no good just talking about them; we actually need to do it. The first point is to cut through the red tape. The second point we have dealt with. The third point is to help farmers protect their core breeding stock. That has been talked about in recent weeks. We were talking about this over a number of months. It is enormously important that that is done. There are practical measures that can be undertaken, and they are outlined in our six-point plan.

Further to that—and it is our fourth point—we need to address the feed grain shortage concerns. In late November, around the 14th or so, the Deputy Prime Minister raised the question of grain imports. There has been permission given—the shadow minister indicated this in his speech of the 13th—to import sorghum, because we just will not have enough for next year. What our shadow minister called for then was what we had in the 1994 period of drought: an audit of those feed stock grains. We should not just guess at the situation, not just take punt at what we might or might not need to do, but actively plan forward into 2003. Even with the hope that this drought will break in 2003, we need to forward plan in this way.

The fifth point is to stop the buck-passing and the squabbling. Today, the shadow Treasurer, and the shadow minister for primary industries and resources, Senator O'Brien, alluded to the fact that, if we are talking politics in regard to this, kicking the states to death for what they may or may not have done has been the game that both the Prime Minister and the minister in this House have played for many months now. It is not good enough to just belt the states and say, `Queensland hasn't done enough, so we'll kick them to death.' The member for Wide Bay, understandably, given it is his turf, might want to concentrate on that. It is not good latterly, because there is an election coming up in New South Wales, to say, `We've taken a fair bit of time—in some cases up to 264 days—to work out what the exceptional circumstances are in a place, and the New South Wales government is being slow.'

The Commonwealth has a responsibility not only to process exceptional circumstances applications quickly but to stop playing political games. Case after case, issue after issue in these areas, that is what the government concentrates on. You are better off to just leave that aside and to take account of the fact that there is a coalition federal government and six state Labor governments. When there was one federal Labor government and six coalition governments, in 1994, we were able to work out a viable plan together, which was in the national interest. The sixth and last point is to get rid of duplication and to target programs to those most in need. Whatever the provisions are across our rural programs, we need to look at them and say: what's been there so far? We need to look at how they interoperate and how they mix, so that we can more effectively take account of what needs to be done and so that we can more effectively support the social situation of people in rural Australia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Earlier Access to Farm Management Deposits) Bill 2002. This is a very important piece of legislation, particularly with the impact of the worst drought on record now affecting all of New South Wales and significant areas of other states. This bill aims to amend the Income Tax Act to provide an exception to the bill such that farm management deposits which have been held for 12 months or less can qualify for the tax benefits that they attract. The Farm Management Deposit Scheme enables farmers to set aside reserves in the good years as a tax deduction at that time and to withdraw that money in lean years and, of course, pay the tax at the marginal rate prevailing at that time. Normally, the tax benefits which accompany farm management deposits are available only when the deposits are held for 12 months or more. However, as I think any member of the House—even the opposition—recognises, these are not normal times or normal circumstances.

speech.para: Our farmers are struggling in a horrific drought. I was interested to hear the member for Blaxland talk about his mother's time in a drought in the 1920s. My earliest recollection in the sixties was, as a very small child, accompanying my father to shoot cattle on our property in a terrible drought. It is a very disheartening thing to get up every day and know you are going to go out and shoot cattle. At that time, we shot a lot of cows that were simply unable to support themselves or their calves. Mentally, it is a very difficult and distressing time for farmers. This initiative by the government to remove this 12-month deposit requirement is certainly a very welcome measure. It is a demonstration of the commitment of the Howard-Anderson government to Australian farmers. But, significantly, it is also time to look at what our state governments have done.

I would like to refer to the package of measures that was announced yesterday. I think that most members of the House would agree that these were sensible measures to ensure that, when the drought finally does break, there is a core breeding herd and that people are in a better position to go forward and start producing for Australia again. As the Deputy Prime Minister has said, each cow and each ewe can be seen as a production machine to first of all reproduce as quickly as possible after the drought. The measures announced yesterday for drought support include $368 million in one-off drought relief measures over the next three years. That is on top of the $360 million that has already been spent. There is six months interim income support for farmers who have suffered a one in 20 rainfall deficiency over the last nine months. That will enable all New South Wales farmers, as well as many farmers in Queensland, Victoria and other states, to access that. There is an interest rate subsidy for new and additional loans of up to $100,000 available for two years to eligible farmers. There is a similar subsidy for small businesses in areas that have declared exceptional circumstances, a recognition that those small businesses quite often suffer greatly because farmers simply are not able to spend.

Finally, there is the establishment of a drought force. This is most important. So many of the employees on farms and in associated businesses in small towns find that the farm sector just cannot continue to pay their wages. They want to stay in the area because they have friends and family there, their children go to school there and so on, but they are generally forced to leave the town that they have worked in and to seek work in large cities. But, of course, when the drought breaks—as we trust that it will—they will be needed again; hence this work for the dole scheme, Drought Force, for drought affected areas. I note that the member for Riverina, sitting here beside me, was a great proponent of that scheme. In fact, she raised it. She was one of the first to raise this very worthy concept of keeping those who are so needed and who want to stay in their small towns and their farming areas as workers, and to ensure that they are given a holding pattern, if you like, through the Drought Force arrangements so that, as soon as the drought does break, they can go back to working on the farms and in the small businesses that they were originally employed in. There will be access to job seeker training for people in those drought affected areas. Certainly, the suggestions put forward by the member for Riverina have been taken up in a very worthy way.

But what of state governments? With this very generous and sensible package to ensure that recovery from the drought happens as quickly as possible and that people are given a sensible and measured helping hand through this very difficult time, what of the states? They have given less than 10 per cent of what the Commonwealth is contributing.

talk.start.para: —Not Victoria.
—I said `the states' as a whole. I gave others the opportunity and the courtesy of hearing them out; I would like the same courtesy.
—The member for Dawson has the call. The member for Melbourne will resist interjecting.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Can I say that the majority of the states will be judged very harshly by the farm sector, and by those who make their livelihood in the farm sector, as they see the little that has come from state governments. They have constantly refused to commit to an enhanced exceptional circumstances declaration—in fact, some states have not even put in exceptional circumstances applications—and that refusal will cost them dearly. But today is the day for the Commonwealth to be proud of the drought assistance measures put forward and to be proud of this bill, which is going to enable farmers to access the deposits they have put forward.

speech.para: I would like to refer now to the comments made by the member for Fraser, the shadow minister, in this debate. For somebody who does not ask a lot of questions in the House on economic issues, he was pretty quick to criticise the Treasurer. His criticism was that the Treasurer is not concentrating on his job. That is what he said: the Treasurer is not concentrating on his job. Let me have a look at whether in fact those remarks can be substantiated. Do not forget that we are in a very, very difficult drought—the worst on written record.

So what did the Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook show? It demonstrated the continuing resilience of the Australian economy, notwithstanding difficult international conditions and the worst drought on written record. Certainly, the government revised down its forecast for growth from the budget forecast of 3¾ per cent to three per cent, which is all drought related. The cash surplus forecast for 2002-03 is still around $2.1 billion. Again, this is notwithstanding the unexpected and, in many cases, tragic expenditure, such as assisting the victims of the Bali terrorist attack, enhancing our security in the wake of Bali, a large program of immunisation in relation to meningococcal and a medical indemnity insurance package. These are not things that governments can generally foresee at all, and still we have a cash surplus forecast of $2.1 billion.

Yet the shadow minister has the gall to say that the Treasurer is not paying attention. By gee, you could not pay any better attention than getting a surplus of $2.1 billion in those sort of circumstances. It is a disgraceful slur in this debate to suggest that the Treasurer has not been paying attention. In the circumstances, he has done an exceptional job of finding the funding for very unexpected and tragic circumstances. I did not mention in the list I gave the exceptional circumstances funding as a result of the drought—$327 million over three years. What has been delivered as a result of that Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook is a lower unemployment rate than was forecast in the budget. This is going to mean savings of around $150 million. As I have just said, in the circumstances, that is an extraordinary result.

The employment growth is forecast to be 1¾ per cent in 2002-03 in average terms. The unemployment rate is going to decline through the year to around six per cent. That is a pretty good result for somebody who, according to the shadow Treasurer, is not paying attention. As I said, economic growth in 2003-04 will rebound to four per cent. That is an extraordinary result. I think that the churlish remarks of the shadow Treasurer are just that: churlish and envious. The Labor Party, when they were in government, did not pay attention to a very serious matter. There was never an intergenerational report done when Labor were in government; they did not want to look to the future.

talk.start.para: —Heard of occupational superannuation? Who introduced that?
—Order! The member for Melbourne!
—They were not interested in what was going to face our children in terms of expenditure in coming years. The Treasurer really is paying attention—
—You have done a report; we actually did something.
—Order! The member for Melbourne!

—and not just to the budget now under these circumstances but to the future as expressed in the Intergenerational Report. You are embarrassed, and so you jolly well should be. The people not paying attention were the Labor Party members. Let me tell you who is paying attention.
—The member for Dawson will address her remarks through the chair.
—Thank you for reminding me, Mr Deputy Speaker; I shall do as you instruct. Guess, Mr Deputy Speaker, who is paying attention?
—Who?

—The Australian people. Interestingly enough, the Newspoll survey of 2 December asked who is the best at handling the economy. Overall, 61 per cent of respondents nominated the government. And what is the view in terms of the ability of the opposition to handle the economy? Eighteen per cent of respondents said that they believed the opposition could handle the economy. Let me say who is concentrating: it is the Australian people. In terms of the Labor supporters surveyed, the majority—40 per cent—still believe that the government is the best to handle the economy. Only 37 per cent believe that it is the opposition. So the Australian people are definitely concentrating. Just as a point of interest, that also extends to national security—but that is not a debate for today.

speech.para: The churlish, envious, small-minded comments about the Treasurer not paying attention and not concentrating are just that: small-minded and churlish. The results in the Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook show that he has in fact not only been paying attention in these difficult and tragic times to unexpected claims on the budget through Bali, national security and the worst drought on written record but also returned in that period a surplus of $2.1 billion—and the record for unemployment shows that we will be able to bring that down to six per cent. What a result in these times.

Those who concentrate—and obviously the Australian people do concentrate—know who is doing the job. They know who is sound on economic management and they know who is sound on national security. They understand. I am not surprised that the shadow minister is embarrassed and comes in here with small-minded and envious comments. You would have to be envious, wouldn't you, of a government that, even in these difficult times, can manage to deliver the outcomes that it has. This is a government that can manage to deliver for farmers, manage to deliver for small business, manage to deliver on unemployment and manage to deliver reports for our children and the future of Australia. It is an exceptional result and the shadow minister has, I think, in a small-minded and envious way, tried to have a go at the Treasurer. Well, unfortunately for him, the Australian people are concentrating, will continue to concentrate and, I have no doubt, will continue to support a government that takes a measured and commonsense approach to the difficulties that the nation faces.
