talk.start.para: —I rise to speak this evening on the Taxation Laws Amendment (Earlier Access to Farm Management Deposits) Bill 2002 with great joy in my heart. This proposal, when put in place, seemed to offer too little to too few; however, it enabled our farmers to put aside an amount of money when their times were good in order to save for that rainy day—or that dry day, so to speak. The amendment is in response to the devastating impact that the drought is having on our farmers and on our rural communities. This widespread drought, now affecting 99 per cent of New South Wales and many other parts of Australia, appears to be the worst in 100 years.

speech.para: The Farm Management Deposit Scheme will be amended to provide an exception to the 12-month waiting rule for farmers in exceptional circumstances areas. Farmers in exceptional circumstances areas at the time the withdrawal is made are eligible to maintain the tax concession if they access the farm management deposits within the 12-month period. Under the current law, if a deposit is withdrawn within 12 months, it will not qualify for the concessional tax treatment. However, due to the current drought, the Prime Minister has announced an exception to that 12-month waiting period for access to farm management deposits for farmers in these exceptional circumstances declared areas.

The amendment to the Farm Management Deposit Scheme will allow farmers who have put away their funds in order to prepare for some of those bad times to access their money substantially tax free. Many of the farmers who put away their income within the past 12 months in the event of drought, flood or low commodity prices would never have thought that a bad year could arrive so quickly and with such devastation. The scheme as it is today was introduced in 1997 by the Deputy Prime Minister, the Hon. John Anderson, Leader of the National Party, and has been embraced by farmers, with one-third of Australian producers taking matters into their own hands. One would ask about the possibility of a similar scheme, or an extension of this scheme that is operating currently, to include battling small businesses, which are all affected by drought. Drought is everybody's problem. The Farm Management Deposit Scheme offers a commercial rate of return on deposits through 26 different financial institutions. The deposits attract tax only when withdrawn, and these deposits are tax free if taken out in poor seasons and low-income years. One could hardly say that this is a high-income year, so I welcome with great relief the changes to allow this bill to proceed.

In June 2002, more than 43,000 primary producers had heavily invested over $2 billion in the Farm Management Deposit Scheme. What an extraordinary feat it was that our farmers were prepared to forgo the luxuries and perhaps the necessities in their lives to ensure that they were providing for their own futures. It is often said in and around the chamber and in meeting rooms that farmers expect too many handouts but, when you read the articles and headlines in most of the newspapers, farmers are still saying that they are optimistic for a good season next season but that, if the rains do not come by March, they will really be in trouble. For goodness sake—as if they are not in trouble now. Week after week and day after day, the dust storms that have enveloped my region have been horrific, so much so that I have had families calling me from areas around Hay, Booligal and Mord to say that they put their children to bed with wet washers over their faces and wet sheets and then dry sheets draped around them just so that they can breathe in the evening and get some sleep. That is the type of devastation they are experiencing as they watch their topsoil being blown hundreds of kilometres away from their lands. They watch as their topsoil and swirling sands fill up their waterways. They watch as these dust storms ravage and devastate their already devastated lands and decimate their children's health and their livestock.

When you look at the resilience of farmers, you see that it has to be pretty bad before they will get up and complain. Still they say, `This is not really as bad as it could get; it can get worse.' I do not know whether I would think that things could get worse if I were living in those circumstances and I was having water carried to me day after day by contractors. The irony is that, should it rain, we will not have that water because most of our roads will be impassable—so that lifesaving water will not be able to be carried by the contractors. Right across my electorate there has been devastation unlike anything we have witnessed. Dust storms are ravaging the rich irrigation areas of Griffith, Leeton and Narrandera, right through to Wagga Wagga and Junee.

In June 2002, more than 43,000 primary producers invested in this Farm Management Deposit Scheme, so they were looking out for themselves. The figures all show what a success the Farm Management Deposit Scheme has been and how strongly it is supported by Australian farmers. New South Wales farmers alone have made around 11,842 deposits worth over $547.8 million, with the average deposit for New South Wales being about $46,256. What a significant feat. As I said, I would be delighted if something like this could be extended to some of the small businesses in my electorate, which are feeling the effects of the drought significantly. They are looking at how to maintain not only their employment cycles but also their livelihoods in areas that have been so affected and ravaged.

The biggest investors in the Farm Management Deposit Scheme in New South Wales on a sectoral basis are mixed farming enterprises such as sheep and beef with $154.5 million, followed by grain with a $142.8 million investment. Grain, sheep and beef are some sectors that have been hardest hit by the drought—the majority of the sectors in my electorate of Riverina—with crops either lost or substantially down on last year. When you look at the devastating frosts that hit us last year and in 1998, you can see that farmers who are living with the elements of the land certainly do have challenges that they have to meet every single day and that they stand up to every single day. The struggle to feed sheep and cattle is experienced on not only a weekly but also a daily basis. The sight of farmers travelling around in their four-wheel drives—barely able to keep them roadworthy—putting out farm fodder and produce for their animals is a sight that one should always take notice of.

When we look at our producers being able to access their deposits earlier without losing their tax benefits we see that we are assisting them to continue that farming and that feeding. These deposits represent an amazing $600 million in tax benefits to our farmers—significant assistance provided by this government. When farmers take advantage of this early access provision, they will not be permitted to make any further farm management deposits within the same tax year, and that is only fair. If you are going to access the deposits and get yourself a tax benefit, surely you should not be able to make deposits. My office has received a number of inquiries from constituents wanting to know if there are any options available to take their money out early without incurring tax costs. My office has been receiving these inquiries day after day. Now I am very pleased and proud that I can inform my constituents that, with the passing of this amendment bill, they can access their deposit while maintaining the tax benefit. I am sure that there is no Australian who would deny the benefits going to these magnificent farming families.

This government has recognised that many farmers who put money away before the drought struck need this assistance and need to access this much needed, well earned and well deserved money now that times are tough. We recognise this, and that is what this legislation that is before us this evening is all about. By allowing farmers to access their farm management deposits, we are helping them to survive until it rains and they can get back on their feet. Some of our electorates are experiencing a small amount of rainfall today—but sometimes, when it is so minimal, that can be an unfortunate thing. People generally think that if it rains the drought is broken—but the drought has not broken; in fact, it will be a long time before the drought is broken. Unfortunately, a small amount of rain can sometimes be worse than no rain at all, because the psyche of the Australian people seems to be that, if we get a few drops of rain, the farmers have got what they needed and they should not require any further assistance. But we all know that that is far from the truth.

Our farmers are working extremely hard. One of the qualities of farmers that continues to amaze me is their ability to keep going on with an unbelievable spirit. As I said, it has been reported in the papers that farmers are still saying that they look forward with optimism for a new season and that they feel quite confident that they will get through this. How many people would have that unbelievable spirit and resilience? To many people, it would simply be too much. However, our farmers obviously have it in their blood—they eat it, sleep it, breathe it and are committed to it. They love working with nature and with their produce, and their contribution to this nation is amazing. In my electorate of Riverina, I see the trials and tribulations caused by the lack of water that have been faced by some of my industries, such as rice growers and the horticultural industries right across the electorate who have had their water allocations slashed dramatically under new environmental proposals with a view to a water sharing plan with the New South Wales government. They are in very difficult circumstances.

I am fortunate enough to be working with the Pratt water group, who are looking to try to relieve some of these issues into the future. We are not talking about turning rivers back over mountains or drought proofing the nation; we are talking about the leadership of a fine Australian businessman, Richard Pratt, who has put forth his money—well in excess of $2 million—to assist me and my team to do a pre-feasibility study on the Riverina. We want to see how we are going to access water into the future and how we can have sustainable irrigation—not less irrigation but more irrigation—with a view to producing more for our export markets and providing much needed employment that is sustained by a very extensive, successful and environmentally conscious irrigation industry right across the Riverina.

All of these challenges are being faced by all forms of farming. Irrigation farming is facing its own restrictions, its own drought. People might look at the irrigation of the MIA in my electorate of Riverina and say, `They're water wasters.' They are not water wasters; they are producers for this nation. They are not wasting water that could be given to dryland and broadacre farmers; they are providing valuable employment, valuable production, valuable export and industry to help this nation and to help some of these areas cope at this time when they are drought ravaged. This bill is about helping all farmers, not just our broadacre dryland farmers who are experiencing dustbowls but also those irrigation industries that are experiencing devastating water shortages due to the cut in their allocation of water.

By allowing farmers to access this FMD money—which is their money that they have put in for a rainy day—they will be able to protect core breeding stock so that they can start again when the rains finally come. I was speaking with a gentleman on the phone the other night, and he said, `I have had to put off my farmhand, and my wife has had to leave her job in Hay to come home and help.' This family have not only been drought-ravaged but have had their income slashed so much that they have had to put off their farm help, and then they have had their second income taken from them so that they can both be on the farm performing duties to sustain them.

I am so pleased and proud that the Prime Minister has taken on board the suggestion and has turned it around. With Minister Brough and Minister Abbott, he has turned this into an opportunity for Work for the Dole operations to be carried out on-farm. This is a fantastic initiative that will help farmers to have vital restoration works undertaken on their properties by people who are being assisted and supported with Newstart allowance because their usual employment has been terminated. I congratulate the Prime Minister for acting on this initiative and for moving so fast to have this put in place. I believe it will provide enormous assistance to those areas to, for example, repair fences and fence off dams so that sheep will not become bogged and lose their lives. Some farmers in my electorate are feeding every single day and yet they see their stock being drowned in mud because the stock cannot get out when they go down to drink at their waterholes.

My electorate of Riverina is, like many areas throughout Australia, drought declared. Many communities are experiencing one of the driest seasons in more than 100 years of records. For Cootamundra, which has records dating back to 1889, this spring has been the third driest in its recorded history. For the two months of October and November this year, Cootamundra has received just 3.6 millimetres of rain. I notice that the member for Hume has just walked in. He is a long-time supporter of Cootamundra.

talk.start.para: —We had rain today.

—That is great news. A Cootamundra farmer was saying that, over the last five years, he has had only one good year. There was drought in 1997, frosts in 1998, a grain price collapse in 1999, one good year in 2000 and frosts in 2001. It makes you feel, `How can I assist these magnificent people?' They are suffering more defeat now, with Shepherds Woolskins being placed in an absolutely untenable position by some of the issues that have surrounded them while they have been trying to run a successful business. The dynamic small community have rallied to help this industry continue to employ its people, and they are rallying once again to ensure that they can continue with this business. We held meetings with Shepherds Woolskins yesterday, and I am looking forward to ensuring a more positive outcome for them and for everyone in Cootamundra, because they have really done it tough over the last few years. With the very best of representation that they have received, one cannot produce miracles. One cannot produce rain and one cannot prevent frosts from striking down fields and their crops.

speech.para: This government that I belong to has made me very proud. This government has continued to offer support in the form of exceptional circumstances assistance, which is expected to be more than $370 million over the next two years. That is on top of the exceptional circumstances and relief packages that are already in place. The legislation to allow early access for these deposits is further evidence of the government's support for our farmers. In all, this government will have provided over $1 billion in assistance to our farmers. I ask: how much has the New South Wales government contributed to the circumstances of our farmers in need?

talk.start.para: —Not much at all.

—That is right: not much at all. I call on them to stand up and be counted. Stand up and join forces; put your political differences aside and come on board. Travel around and look at the devastation. Feel it, experience it and do something about it. Come along with us to assist our communities—not just our farmers but our small businesses. We want to help our country Australians to keep living in country Australia. We need as much assistance as we can get. I say to this government: congratulations. (Time expired)

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —in reply—The government would like to take this opportunity to thank all honourable members on both sides who have supported the Taxation Laws Amendment (Earlier Access to Farm Management Deposits) Bill 2002. This is a particularly important bill, and the member for Fraser indicated that the opposition was in support of this government's initiative. We welcome that support.

speech.para: The member for Pearce, as always, delivered quite a thought-provoking contribution. On behalf of the government, I would like to thank her for reminding us of the importance of rural communities and the impact of drought on rural towns. This is something that the government has been mindful of in designing its relief package, including the six months income support for eligible farmers, the interest rate subsidies to farmers and small businesses in drought affected areas, measures to assist job seekers in drought affected areas, and a range of other measures. The government wants to recognise the contribution made by country Australia to the nation's prosperity, and members on both sides of the House have indicated their support for the important changes contained in this legislation.

I thank the member for Dawson, on behalf of the government, for reminding us all of the further measures announced yesterday by the Prime Minister. Quite rightly, she noted the importance of the assistance extended by this government to those job seekers in drought affected areas. The member for Fraser, although supporting the bill, suggested that income smoothing should be applied to sources of volatile income. The member for Fraser, having been a former parliamentary secretary to the Treasurer in Labor times, would know that it is a basic principle of income tax that all income is taxed the same, regardless of source. This principle ought only to be departed from in exceptional cases, such as primary production, sports people and artists. This is a principle of basic equity and, for reasons of equity, such measures should only be adopted in very special cases. I think there is probably broad support for that particular approach.

The member for Fraser also suggested that there was inadequate costing information. That simply is not accurate. These measures assist farmers in extreme financial difficulty. Farmers who qualify for the exceptional circumstances concession are able to withdraw their deposits within 12 months of making them. However, the amount withdrawn is assessable in the same income year that it would be assessed in if the farmer did not qualify for the exceptional circumstances concession and withdrew the deposit just after the 12-month period had expired. For this reason, apart from a timing effect, there is no cost to revenue. After all, the bill only affects farmers who have had their deposits in the bank for less than 12 months. The members for Fraser and Blaxland referred to Labor's drought plan, but the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry stated the situation very clearly in question time today. It is not just a case of Labor being an apologist for state Labor governments; many farmers would get very little under the Labor package—at least, not yet. The coalition introduced interim assistance and predictive modelling, and the Labor announcement was two months after the government's announcement, so it was a question of too little, too late.

The member for Riverina, in a particularly thought-provoking contribution, mentioned, as she often does, the problems of small business. She is a keen advocate in her electorate for small business operators, and all of us in this place know that small business is the engine room of the Australian economy. The member for Riverina suggested that the provisions should be extended to small businesses. I want to point out to the honourable member that the government does have other ways of compensating the rest of the community. I refer to the Centrelink arrangements which establish Drought Force, a Work for the Dole type program. It also allows job seekers access to job seeker training and allows employees facing retrenchment access to job matching services. The point I want to make is that the government does have a broad range of initiatives to assist those in drought affected Australia and does appreciate the important contribution they have made to Australia's national prosperity. I think there is a broad consensus in Australia that those people in rural Australia who work so hard to make Australia the wonderful country that it is should be assisted by the nation as a whole in these times of adversity.

The current drought is having an immense impact on rural Australia. It is one of the most severe in the last 100 years. In recognition of the particular severity and extent of the drought, the government has decided that, in conjunction with a number of other comprehensive measures, it will amend the taxation laws to allow farmers in exceptional circumstances declared areas to access their farm management deposits without having to wait 12 months. I am therefore hopeful that the government will receive the support of the House, given that the relaxation of the 12-month requirement will benefit farmers in exceptional circumstances declared areas. Members on both sides do appear to be supporting the bill.

The FMD scheme allows eligible primary producers to set aside pre-tax income in profitable years to establish cash reserves to help meet costs in low-income years. FMDs complement other risk management strategies available to primary producers, such as developing fodder and water reserves, financial planning and diversifying their production systems. Furthermore, minor amendments will also be made to the taxation laws to enhance the flexibility and operation of the FMD scheme. This is one of the initiatives announced by the Prime Minister on 27 November this year which are designed to assist rural communities to cope with the current drought. The initiatives provide additional funding to meet a number of concerns, including cash flow for farmers, pest control, environmental protection and community support for struggling farmers. The amendments will help farmers manage the cash flow impact of the drought and build on the significant funding already provided by the Commonwealth in managing the drought. In addition, the government will also streamline consideration of advice on exceptional circumstances applications to ensure that there is no unnecessary delay in the coming weeks. This is a very important initiative of the Howard government. The government appreciates the backing of both sides of the House. I commend this bill to the chamber.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: Mr SLIPPER (Fisher—Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration) (8.28 p.m.)—by leave—I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.

Bill read a third time.
Debate resumed from 20 February, on motion by Mr Abbott:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The opposition will be opposing the second reading motion. We do not believe the Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Termination) Bill 2002 is necessary. Insofar as it is pushed, we will be moving amendments in the committee stage to reduce from 12 months to six months the period of exemption the government proposes with respect to the right of casual employees to pursue unfair dismissal actions. That is the primary issue in this bill. I will explain the reasoning for the opposition's position. Essentially, our reasoning relates to a concern regarding the growing extent of insecure employment in our community, and casual employment makes up a substantial bulk of that insecure employment. Essentially, the government's approach is a one-sided approach of scapegoating employees—and, when we are talking about casual employees, we are talking about probably the most marginalised and vulnerable employees in the community—and claiming that the mere fact that they have rights is an impediment to employment and an explanation for lower rates of permanent employment.

speech.para: We say that, if you are taking away rights from a citizen—in particular, from those who are the most marginalised and vulnerable—you have to do so with good reason. The government have not made out their case. In taking this approach of victimising or scapegoating these vulnerable employees, they are failing to address a very concerning trend in our work force—that is, the extent of casualisation or insecure employment generally. In terms of casualisation, figures suggest that about one-third of the Australian work force are casual employees. Casual employees do not have the rights of traditional employees, which I will refer to in a second. To give an indication of the emerging trends: in the last decade, 87 per cent of new jobs paid less than $26,000 a year and half of those paid less than $15,600 per year. That is less than the minimum wage, which suggests that a substantial number of the jobs created are casual or at least part time; they are certainly less than full time.

It is very difficult to get a precise handle on what is happening, partly because the government has declined to conduct an Australian Workplace Industrial Relations Survey. The last one was undertaken in 1995. We say it is imperative to do that, because the emerging trends are concerning trends. You have to bear in mind that the whole work force seems to be fragmented into two tiers. In the first tier are those persons who have special skills, training or qualifications. They are engaged as a core work force. Surrounding that is a second tier, a peripheral work force. That peripheral work force is growing—it is now about one-third of the Australian work force—but those in it are engaged as and when required to meet peak demands of the market or seasonal factors, as has always been the case with respect to casual employees. That is a very transient or short-term underemployed work force.

Insofar as that represents one-third of the work force—and, from all indications, a growing portion of it—it is significant for two reasons. The first is from the point of view of what it indicates about the distribution of wealth and opportunity in our community. From one perspective, the wellbeing of people in this peripheral work force is quite irrelevant to the economic wellbeing of the nation—that is, we could have a very successful economy with these people who exist in this peripheral work force not travelling well, being underemployed and having incomes of less than $15,600 a year. But, if you are looking at it from the point of view of the long-term liveability of the society—aside from the morality that applies to individuals in that category—and if you are looking at it from the point of view of the society we want to create, you are looking at a society that is already very unequal in terms of access to resources and opportunities and which is going to become increasingly unequal.

To make that proposition is simply to state the obvious: if you are a casual employee or an otherwise insecure employee on a fixed term engagement, you are not going to get a car loan let alone a housing loan and it is most unlikely that you are going to have access to superannuation. When you are looking at how our society is emerging, if you do not have the opportunity to grab a foothold on the exponentially increasing housing property market, you are going to be left behind. Not only are you going to be left behind; your kids also are going to be left behind. On the trend of the work force, intergenerational poverty is staring us in the face. One-third of the work force is now in this category. I would accept and concede that a portion of that one-third in casual employment would probably be in second jobs, that they would probably be in households where there is a primary income earner. Nonetheless, a significant portion would be there as the sole income earner. They will not have access to the property market, nor will their children. If we sit down and look at this trend now, we have an opportunity to say, `We can do something about it.' That is the first thing, which is from the point of view of the society we want.

The second thing is from the point of view of the future economy that we want. I think we realise here in Australia that there is a fundamental difference between the opposition and the government on this point: the opposition continually says that it wants a high-skilled, high-paid work force but, if you look at the trends in the workplace, the government, at least for this peripheral tier, is quite happy to see a low-skilled, low-paid work force. When casual employees are in this peripheral tier, it is not in the interests of the employer to provide a lot of resources for training and upskilling, encouraging skills enhancement, because they are on the periphery. It is just silly from the point of view of an employer to devote resources to people who are a transient work force. We are looking at a situation where a third of the work force is not being provided with the skills that are required for us to sustain an ongoing, productive economy. Obviously, if in any endeavour a third of your work force—and that is what is suggested on the basis of the current figures—is not receiving that necessary training and upskilling, you are putting in place an impediment to the future wellbeing of your nation.

For the purposes of scene setting, I would like to acknowledge those points. They are vitally important to a consideration of this issue. Why? Because this bill will fundamentally, in itself, encourage employers to engage casual employees for a period of 12 months rather than for a shorter period. I think an analysis of the propositions that I have put to date would suggest that it is in everyone's interests—clearly, the individuals, the society and the economy—for us to sit down and look at what we can do to encourage employers to engage employees on a permanent basis, not on a casual or part-time basis.

From the point of view of individuals, we have seen what has occurred. A well-known case recently was the metals casuals case of 2000. In that case, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission received evidence from a number of casual employees—as well as from economists—describing the effect of this insecure employment on their lives, their families' lives and their wellbeing. Clearly, in many instances they are engaged by the hour. They are there at 20 minutes to nine at night and they do not know whether they are going to be there at 10 o'clock. They cannot phone up to tell their kids when they are going to be home. It is at the whim of the boss, according to the demands of the workplace. They do not get annual holidays, long service leave or, most likely, superannuation.

talk.start.para: —They get a casual loading.

—They cannot acquire property. They get very basic training at best. An interjection was made that they receive a casual loading. Yes, they get a casual loading, but it seems that that casual loading is itself not a disincentive to employing casual labour. Indeed, if you look at casual rates of pay, including the loading, they are still below permanent rates of pay. Why? Because of the very nature of casual employees, they do not have the capacity to collectively bargain. They do not have that security in their position to say to the employer, `Hold on. We're going to have a stop-work meeting to consider our position. We're not happy regarding the terms and conditions of employment that have been offered to us.'
—That's nonsense, and you know it.
—The member for Hume again interjects.
—I know, because I have worked there and you haven't.

—The figures speak for themselves. If you look at the rates of pay for casual employees as against those for permanent employees in industries, even considering the loading, their rates of pay are still below those that permanent employees are able to secure. Because permanent employees have the security, they have the ability to negotiate and they have secured those benefits. I say to the member for Hume and to the House that casuals are on the whole very marginalised and vulnerable employees. We cannot forget that, because what are we doing in debating this bill? The debate is about taking away a fundamental Australian right—the right to a fair go before you lose your livelihood. That is something we should be reluctant to do to any Australian, particularly those who are the most marginalised and vulnerable of Australians.

speech.para: Again, what is our concern? Our concern is the very effect that it has on the society that we want to be and on the economy that we want to have, but in terms of the consequences of trying to get a rule, or at least a culture, in Australian workplaces for someone who has been a casual employee engaged on a regular and systematic basis with an expectation of ongoing employment. I am not talking about a situation such as fruit picking where someone may be involved in a rotating situation for a period of seven or nine months, with no expectation of ongoing employment in an establishment. I am talking about a situation where someone is employed on a regular and systematic basis for a period of six months with an expectation that that relationship is going to continue. The metals casuals case found that it was fair and reasonable that there be a presumption that those people be offered permanent employment. Bob Herbert, the Chief Executive of the Australian Industry Group, whom I have a lot of time for—I think he is a particularly balanced person, representing his industry group more effectively than any other organisation because of the balance that he brings—said in respect of the decision in that case:

quote.para: There has been no adjustment to casual employment for 26 years. Certainly, there will be some murmurs among employers over the increased loading rates—

speech.para: I interpose and note the member for Hume's previous interjection—

quote.para: but, in reality the AIRC ruling simply brings casuals to roughly the same pay and condition levels as their full-time colleagues.

speech.para: I put that quote from Bob Herbert of the Australian Industry Group to my learned friend who interjected earlier. It is recognition that they were in a disadvantaged bargaining position. That is an industry group saying, `A six-month tour and this additional loading was an appropriate thing to aim for.' Indeed, that is what we say.

Now we come to the question of how we came to be debating this bill. We came to be debating this bill as the result of the decision of the full court of the Federal Court of Australia in Hamzy v. Tricon International Restaurants trading as KFC. In that decision, the full court of the Federal Court of Australia held that a 12-month exemption from the right of employees to seek remedy for unfair dismissal was not consistent with that provision of the act which enabled the minister to make regulations exempting employees from those benefits or that right if they were engaged on a casual basis for a short period of time. The Federal Court said 12 months was not a short period of time. In presenting their case—and this is significant—the government went into evidence using this argument that they persist with. It is an argument we will be prepared to engage in, to analyse the substance of it. I will do the best I can to look at it in the time available. The court specifically rejected evidence presented by the government that unfair dismissal laws are an impediment to employment. The court specifically rejected evidence presented by the chief government witness, Professor Mark Wooden, a research fellow of the Melbourne Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research, known as the Melbourne Institute. I ask the House to recognise the name of the Melbourne Institute. The court specifically rejected that evidence. Indeed, the full court of the Federal Court said:

quote.para: It seems unfortunate that nobody has investigated whether there is any relationship between unfair dismissal legislation and employment growth. There has been much assertion on this topic during recent years, but apparently no effort to ascertain the factual situation.

speech.para: The court suggested how that could be done. Effectively, since about 1983, some federal awards have had protections against unfair dismissal. The court said, `Why hasn't a comparison been done of those industries or employers covered by awards that have that benefit for employees with those industries where there is no similar benefit, looking at employment trends in that sector?' No-one has done that.

In answer to a question on notice that I asked on 14 October—but that was answered on 3 December—the minister said that he took on board the comments of the Federal Court of Australia in Hamzy's case, asking why someone had not looked at this effectively. The minister said in his reply to me, `We asked the Australian Bureau of Statistics to look at the issue. They said that they would have impediments to using empirical data for the purpose and they suggested a survey approach.' The minister's answer refers to the 2002 Yellow Pages Small Business Index Survey. It then refers to a further study, done through the Melbourne Institute, which reported on 29 October 2002. I want to spend some time discussing that report, because we think the findings of it are flawed and that they were the result of a methodology that itself was flawed. This is of concern because we are talking about rights.

It must be said that Mr Harding, Assistant Director of the Melbourne Institute, acknowledged that there had been two recent surveys. One was the July 2002 Yellow Pages small business questionnaire. That survey indicated that 5.6 per cent of firms mentioned that the following were a barrier to hiring new staff: employment conditions, unfair dismissal, industrial relations and safety and health. Grouped together, they make 5.6 per cent, so we would assume that unfair dismissal itself, being a factor in that grouping, would be less than 5.6 per cent. That would be consistent with an earlier survey reported by Don Harding, the 1995 Australian Workplace Industrial Relations Survey, which referred to only 1.4 per cent of respondents mentioning unfair dismissal laws as a discrete impediment to taking on new employees. Mr Harding said, `We need to prompt employers on this issue to get their response.' With respect to Mr Harding, I submit that the prompting went further than was reasonably fair to get an accurate outcome of the views of employers. For instance, in the interviews conducted with businesses of fewer than 200 employees, I recall that there was an instruction to an interviewer trying to quantify the cost of complying with unfair dismissal laws. The instruction to the interviewer read:

quote.para: If response is that it is hard to quantify costs prompt by asking for best estimate. If response is that costs vary from year to year ask for a cost in best year and cost in worst year and take midpoint. If a range is given code midpoint of the range.

speech.para: These are very broad prompts. Indeed, if you look at the figures obtained, you will see that the outcomes reflect such broad prompts. For instance, if you take the finance industry, one of the industries specifically examined, the businesses surveyed are broken up into groupings based on the number of employees: one to five, six to 10, 11 to 20, 21 to 50, 51 to 100 and 100 plus. You would assume, if that methodology were accurate, that there would be a consistency through those figures, perhaps even a sliding scale. But, when you look at them, they bounce around all over the shop. For instance, using that methodology it was found that, for businesses with one to five employees, the average cost is $45 per employee; with six to 10 employees, the average cost is $755 per employee; with 11 to 20 employees, the average cost is $0 per employee; with 21 to 50, the average cost is $348 per employee; with 51 to 100, the cost is $17 per employee; and with more than 100 employees, the average cost is $8 per employee. There is not even a sliding scale there. I suppose you would assume that the bigger the establishment, perhaps, the lower the cost. But, if you look at that trend, they bounce around throughout those ranges.

Indeed, when looking at industries as a whole, the cost for an employer in respect of the wholesale industry is $44 and the cost in respect of the accommodation industry is $1,087. There is no logic in these figures. If you look at the prompt that I have indicated pushed these responses, you can see why there is such a wide deviation. Overall, the figure per employee went from a cost of $30,000 in one response to zero in others. Despite the massive variation, Mr Harding averaged out, by some miraculous calculation—adding them all together in an omelette and picking out a potato—the figure of $296 per employee then multiplied this by the number of employees and came up with the cost to the community of $1.3 billion. With respect, that is poor research.
What are the consequences of that research? The research is used as justification for taking away important rights. Mr Harding recognised those rights in his report. On page 13 he says:

quote.para: The central purpose of the UFD laws—

speech.para: unfair dismissal laws—

quote.para: are to encourage firms to engage in fair, and transparent human resource management procedures when dealing with workers whose performance is unsatisfactory.

speech.para: That is not something that we, in the 21st century, would think is undesirable. He goes on to say:

quote.para: It is clear from the data that the UFD laws have caused firms to implement the two main practices that are considered to be part of good human resource management of poor performers namely, provide a warning, and provide an opportunity to respond ...

speech.para: He refers to a table and then continues:

quote.para: It is also clear that the UFD laws have encouraged firms to provide workers who are about to be dismissed with reasons ...

speech.para: He refers to another table and then says:

quote.para: something that is widely viewed as central to fairness.

speech.para: And it is: we are talking about the fundamental concept of a fair go all round. We are talking about taking away from very marginalised and vulnerable workers this concept of a fair go and their access to the right for a fair go. We would want to do this on figures, and I surmise that there is no way that Mr Harding will ever be appearing in a court of law to face cross-examination on his methodology nor on the figures obtained through that methodology. They just do not substantiate the propositions that the government has advanced. In fairness to the media, their analysis of the document came up with that comment. In summary, on the issue of exempting casual employees, fundamentally you are encouraging employers, by the very nature of this legislation, to keep people on as casuals for 12 months rather than make them permanent at an earlier period, namely six months. That is essentially the proposition that we are advancing.

There are two other issues that I will touch on briefly. The first is the proposed exemption of employees on a fixed term basis. There have been decisions on this matter in the Federal Court of Australia, and as a result we are content not to oppose that exemption. The Federal Court has applied, we believe, practical reasoning. If there is a fixed term arrangement and that arrangement itself provides for a method of dismissal or termination of the engagement, the court has been prepared to say that it is not a fixed term arrangement but that it is an ongoing employment arrangement. On the basis of those authorities, we are prepared to accept that proposition.

The other issue, which we will be opposing, is the proposition to lock in and index court filing fees. We are very concerned by the locking in of court filing fees and suspect that the government wants this to be an impediment to people bringing claims. The fact that someone cannot afford a filing fee is no measure of whether the claim is worthy. We believe that the appropriate way of imposing a filing fee is by way of regulation so that parliament can review that regulation and disallow it if they regard the filing fee as inappropriate. But to entrench it and index it, we believe, is an exceptional thing to do. From our research, there is no precedent for that occurring. Court filing fees are universally set by regulation not by legislation, and there is no reason to depart from that. We are trying to come up with a balance but we think the government has gone too far. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —What we hear from the Labor Party is always predictable. From the time you walk into this place you know that they are going to come up with the same old diatribe centred on their ideological view of small business. The member for Barton's contribution was no exception to the rule. The Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Termination) Bill 2002 was introduced into the parliament on 20 February 2002. The bill was referred to the Senate Employment, Workplace Relations, Small Business and Education Legislation Committee on 19 March 2002. The committee received 30 submissions in relation to the five bills before it, including this bill, and held public hearings on 2 and 3 May 2002 in Melbourne. The committee reported on this bill on 15 May 2002.

speech.para: This bill will amend the Workplace Relations Act 1996 to restore to business broad protection from termination of employment claims brought by short-term casual employees. I know a little bit about that, because I have been on both sides of the fence: I have undertaken short-term casual work and I have employed short-term casuals. I will come to that later. The bill will also move provisions imposing a filing fee for dismissal applications from the regulations into the act and will provide for the fee to be indexed annually in line with the CPI. The bill is aimed at assisting those businesses that rely heavily on the use of casual labour to continue to operate smoothly without fear of falling foul of the unfair dismissal laws. Adding more risk and uncertainty to the employment of casuals will have a detrimental effect on employment. There is absolutely no question about it. Businesses, especially small businesses, should not be deterred further from engaging staff, especially casual staff. It brings to mind a number of conversations that I have had not only with small business people in my electorate but also with others that I have dealt with in the past in my capacity as an employer working for a large export establishment and, prior to that, as a casual.

When the unfair dismissal laws were first brought in, people were telling me about incidents that occurred in their businesses with regard to unfair dismissal claims that had been brought against them and how the system was being manipulated. On a couple of occasions some business people who employed between two and 10 employees had had vexatious claims made successfully against them. One employer told me that he had warned one of his employees about the employee's constant use of marijuana in his employment and about what it was doing to him in terms of putting him at risk regarding safety issues in the plant and in the workplace. Despite his warning this employee on a number of occasions and finally finding a quantity of marijuana in the employee's locker and dismissing him, he faced the consequences of the unfair dismissal laws. He paid out a significant amount of money and had to re-employ the person.

As a follow-on this employer made a deliberate decision to restrict the number of outsiders in his business and to employ as many family members as he could in the interests of protecting his business and keeping it viable. That is an example of the harsh reality of small business and how unfair dismissal laws create problems for small business in the real world. I know that that is difficult for people like the member for Barton to understand, being a person with a legal background and coming out of the trade union movement. I have been employed as a casual and as a full-time employee and I have worked as a person hiring others, in a very similar situation. I can understand why he is out of touch with reality and, more importantly, why the ALP has this fixation on subjecting small business to unfair impositions.

Businesses, particularly small businesses, should not be deterred from further engaging staff, especially casual staff. These staff help employers to meet the peaks and troughs that business demands, and that is the very point I am making. This government is about creating jobs, and that is the principal aim of this bill. A survey of small businesses issued by the Society of Certified Practicing Accountants in March this year showed that 42 per cent of small businesses did not feel that they were confident that they knew how to dismiss staff in line with the unfair dismissal laws. If they contact me, I can certainly give them some good information in relation to that. Yet 76 per cent of CPAs believed that small business did not understand the laws. The survey results confirm that understanding. The figures highlight the onerous complexity of the laws, with 62 per cent of small business and 81 per cent of accountants believing that the unfair dismissal laws require them to follow a complex process. The complexities of the law would be added to if business had to extend the minefield of unfair dismissal laws to short-term casual employees. This was a description used by the CEO of the Small Business Clinic in an advice column in the Daily Telegraph on 25 June 2002.

There are also technical reasons for the introduction of the bill. The bill will exclude casual employees from making claims for unfair dismissal or unlawful termination unless they have been engaged with a particular employer on a regular and systematic basis for 12 months and have a reasonable expectation of continuing employment with the same employer. That will vary from industry to industry. In the Hamzy v. Tricon International Restaurants decision on 16 November 2001, which the member for Barton referred to, the full Federal Court declared regulations that had the same effect to be invalid. The issue in the Hamzy case was whether the exclusion of short-term casual employees from federal unfair dismissal laws was valid on highly technical legal grounds. The substance of the regulations was not at issue. The regulations excluded short-term casual employees from accessing termination of employment remedies unless they had been working for the employer on a regular and systematic basis for 12 months and had a reasonable expectation of continuing employment with the same employer. The full Federal Court said that they were not valid on a technicality. The Hamzy case was decided on a technicality—that is, the regulations went further than was permitted by the regulation making power in the act.

Replacement regulations were put in place as soon as possible—in fact, from 7 December 2001—after the Hamzy decision, and they now operate. All the bill is seeking to do is restore the law in relation to short-term casuals to what it was assumed to be before the full Federal Court's decision. The full Federal Court's decision was an interesting decision. It was in line with many of the decisions that come out of the courts from time to time which the general public get rather irate about because they are interfering in issues and making decisions based on ideological views in many instances—as is the ALP. In many instances the courts are making decisions on the basis of manipulating the laws of the land outside what the public perceive to be their interpretation of the law.

I was interested to read the media release from the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry on 14 March 2002, which was headed `12 month unfair dismissal exemption for casuals is essential for jobs'. This was a statement by Lyndon Rowe, the Acting Chief Executive of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. He had this to say:

quote.para: Enacting the Government's legislation unamended does no more than retain the status quo that has applied for the past five years.

Let it be said plainly—if the Senate forces any lesser period than a 12-month exclusion for casual employees then the Parliament will have increased, not decreased, the burden of unfair dismissal laws on employers.
That would be a ridiculous outcome, given that the unfair dismissal debate should be about reducing the problems that these laws create for fair-minded employers.

speech.para: The press release talks about the watering down of the five-year-old law and what it will do. It says:

quote.para: For the past five years an employer could employ a casual and not be at risk of a federal unfair dismissal claim during the first 12 months of employment.

speech.para: Quite correctly, it goes on to say:

quote.para: The Government and the Parliament, not the courts, make public policy on unfair dismissal laws. Court decisions are not a substitute for balanced public policy on an issue as important to jobs as unfair dismissal laws.

speech.para: I know the mainstream community would agree wholeheartedly on that in relation to court decisions affecting not only employment but, more importantly, various other issues in the community on which the courts have come under attack in the last 12 to 18 months. The press release ends by saying:

quote.para: The 12-month exclusion is part of an established policy balance in unfair dismissal laws. For the past five years the Senate did not disallow this law, contained in regulations.

speech.para: I think that pretty well sums it up.

On the issue of the follow-on from the Federal Court's decision, it is interesting that the ALP does not seem to grasp the situation that applies out in the real world, which is this: in order for a worker to be sacked, they have to have a job. The ALP should be concerned with job creation measures, not measures that add to the uncertainty of the unfair dismissal laws or that contribute to the idea that they are a minefield. The ALP obviously has no commitment to the wellbeing of small business—and I made reference to that before. The ALP is demonstrating a lack of understanding of small business and the need for flexibility to cater for legitimate business needs. I think that is the crux of the matter. This is clear from the comments of Labor, best summed up by Kim Beazley's comments in an interview with Maxine McKew on Lateline on 4 December 1996. He said that unfair dismissal:

quote.para: ... in the end has got nothing to do with small business—nothing to do with youth unemployment ...

speech.para: That sums it up, as I said, very succinctly.

For over 10 years the casual exclusion has operated. It operated under Labor when the period in the exemption was six months. It has been a 12-month exemption since 1996. Business has operated on the basis that it can engage short-term casuals without invoking the complexity of the unfair dismissal laws over that period. The bill merely regularises a situation that changed because of a legal technicality. It is not about any alleged exploitation of casuals. It is returning to a situation that has prevailed for years. Employers have traditionally used short-term casuals to balance the peaks and troughs in workloads, especially where there is seasonal employment. ABS data supports this conclusion. Around one-third of all casuals do not work regular hours. Further, 44 per cent of casuals described their working pattern as casual relief work. That is absolutely right.

The Australian Hotels Association had something to say with regard to unfair dismissal laws. And why wouldn't they be concerned about it? They are concerned about it because they employ more than 250,000 Australians in their industry. More importantly, they employ an enormous number of young people, who work on a casual basis to subsidise their income when they are going through university. Rural and regional hoteliers employ a number of people who are using casual work in hotels and in clubs to subsidise their full-time working conditions outside the home, to get those little extras, to add to the small luxuries of life that they enjoy from time to time.

As I said earlier, this nonsense—words about insecure employment, rights being taken away from individuals, the casualisation of the work force, the reference to special skills and training, the peripheral work force, the distribution of wealth in the work force and, finally, intergenerational poverty—used as an argument against the unfair dismissal laws, is just another indication of how the Australian Labor Party have never been in the position of balancing a profit and loss sheet in a small business or of lining up at the gate or at a packing shed, like I have, to undertake casual work. I might add that I have been paid reasonably well for casual work, except on piecework, where you had to justify the amount of money you got by the poundage or volume of the commodity that you had picked or packed on a particular day. It was not that bad in terms of the payment, because you were subsidised through the casual loading for holidays and normal award employment conditions.

There always was and always will be a very real desire by people who are in the casual work force, if they want to make something of themselves in life and make themselves totally self-sufficient, to continue to go to a particular industry organisation and work as a casual in the hope that, at some stage or another in their lifetime, they will be able to pick up a permanent job. They understand that. They do not have to have regulations from politicians to make them understand that. This is no reflection on my parliamentary colleagues, a significant number of whom, on both sides of the House, have come out of the legal profession but people do not like politicians who come from that sort of background telling them, as casual, ordinary, working battlers out there in the Australian community, how they should be acting as casuals in the work force. More importantly, those who are honest—and that is the bulk of them—do not go into the casual work force to make use of and abuse unfair dismissal laws. Most of them do not use them. It is only the slackers, as I call them, who want to make a quick buck and who have the handout mentality that we have in the community today who abuse the unfair dismissal laws.

I take great delight in having the opportunity to speak on this particular bill here tonight because I think the government, by introducing this sort of bill into this House, is going in the right direction in terms of making sure that we do have and continue to have low unemployment in this country. I can understand why the Labor Party are out in the wilderness: because they do not understand what is happening out there in the real world. It does not matter whether you are talking about unfair dismissal laws or any other issue in the mainstream community: the mainstream community knows they have nothing to offer and knows that the Labor Party are obstructing us in everything that they do. All the community is looking for from the Australian Labor Party is some assistance to enhance the good work being done by the coalition in reducing unemployment rates and making employers feel safe and secure in their role of employing people. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: — The Howard government and the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations have determined that they are going to continue to persist with denying certain categories of Australian citizens the kind of recourse to legal remedies that the average person in the community would believe in as part of the notion of a fair go all round. I spoke earlier this year on the so-called `fair' dismissal bill, and tonight I want to make some remarks about the minister's Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Termination) Bill 2002. Let me begin by saying that what the minister describes as being fair is quite contrary to the commonly accepted notion of fairness in Australian communities.

speech.para: In the earlier bill, the Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Dismissal) Bill 2002 [No. 2], the minister wanted us to believe that fair dismissal somehow meant depriving a whole class of employees of any recourse under law against harsh, unjust and unreasonable grounds for termination. That exclusion was to apply to anyone who, by chance, happened to work in a business of less than 20 employees. Now we are being asked to stretch our minds to believe that fairness will now mean, if the minister has his way, that termination without legal remedy for unfair dismissal could occur in a situation where a particular employment relationship existed—that is, where the short-term employment, as defined by the minister's bill, is less than 12 months. So we see a second attempt to deprive Australian citizens of recourse to legal remedies. I think it runs very much against the fundamental tenets of our legal system in Australia, which historically has been predicated on the notion that all Australian citizens are equal before the law. The battlers understand quite clearly the implications of the minister's doublespeak. They see it as being of Orwellian proportions. How is it fair, in any person's language, to deny workers who happen to work in a small business recourse against unfair dismissal? To deny to those casual employees who have an employment relationship of less than 12 months any recourse under the law is really beyond me.

What the minister fails to appreciate is that the import of this bill would have the most negative consequences on the most vulnerable workers in our community. It places those who are precariously employed, often in small business and often non-unionised, in the most vulnerable of positions. Of course, if the minister had his way we would see a double whammy, because there is, as we all know, a very high correlation between casual employment and small business. So it would be a case of double jeopardy for many of those workers who happened to be casual and in small business if this government were to have its way. We have to commend the efforts of those in the other chamber who over the years have maintained the line that the issue of unfair dismissal has to be treated on the basis of the principle of a fair go all round.

Back in 1995 the government's AWIRS survey reported that small business employed a higher proportion of casuals than all other workplaces—21 per cent of small businesses compared to 17 per cent of all workplaces. As we know, and as others have referred to in the debate on this bill, under the Howard government we have seen an acceleration of the trend to casualisation. Precarious employment is growing astronomically and job insecurity is rampant in our community. It is difficult to be precise about the exact number of casual workers who would be affected by the scope of this proposed exclusion, but a large number of people out of the two million currently casually employed would suffer the negative impacts of the government's proposals. It should be of concern to everybody in this chamber that Australia has one of the highest rates of casual and precarious employment of any developed OECD nation. The most recent figures I have seen show that the number of casual employees has grown from around 16 per cent in 1984 to anywhere up to the 30 per cent mark today.

I know from my own experience that a significantly larger proportion of women than men are employed as casuals. About 60 per cent of all casual workers are women. So it is this group of very vulnerable workers, predominantly women, who will bear the negative impacts of this bill. The intent of the bill is to deny the so-called short-term casuals access to federal unfair termination remedies. I think it is a terrible tragedy that this government is hell-bent on winding back the scope of federal unfair termination laws introduced under the Keating government back in 1993. I think it is to the great credit of the former Labor government and the efforts then of the member for Kingsford-Smith that working people, especially the most vulnerable, had protection at the federal level under a near universal regime regulating wrongful and unfair dismissal.

It is true that, in accordance with the International Labour Organisation convention at the time, exclusion applied to workers engaged on what was then described as a `casual basis for a short period'. As we know, and as the member for Barton has pointed out in the debate on this bill, the 1996 changes to the regulations, which increased from six months to 12 months the period of engagement before redress could be sought, came to a head in the Hamzy case. The challenge to the validity of the regulations was upheld by the full Federal Court decision back in November 2001, but again the minister moved quickly to restore the exclusion. In effect, he is now seeking to have those regulations incorporated into the act itself.

What are the arguments that are advanced in favour of this proposition? We heard a lot in the earlier debate on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Dismissal) Bill 2002 [No. 2] that if we were only to carry the bill then nirvana would appear and there would be all these new jobs created. That is a great hypothesis but one built on no substantial body of evidence—which even the recent decisions of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission have made very clear. Then we were told that the figure was 52,000 jobs. At least in the case of this bill the minister recognises that employment-creating arguments would be absolutely untenable and unsustainable and so, to his credit, he has not used them. He cannot use them because, even when the Keating government introduced its reforms back in 1993, the reforms never acted as a brake on the growth in casual employment. The regulation of wrongful dismissal in the federal jurisdiction has never acted as a brake on employment growth.

As I said earlier, I think the real dilemma that we are facing is how we, as a nation and as a community, deal with the increased casualisation that is feeding the growing insecurity. If anything, the current exclusion of casual employees—that is, those who have been working for a particular employer for less than 12 months—is potentially open to be used in a manner which would further accelerate casualisation and precarious employment. It would open the door to the possibility of unscrupulous employers churning staff through their enterprises as a means of circumventing access to remedies for unfair dismissal.

There is a range of views as to why casual employment is growing at such a fast rate in our nation. There is no doubt in my mind that the whole tenor of the industrial relations changes—in particular, the stripping back of the awards system and the deregulation that we have seen both in the labour market and in the laws governing the employment relationship—has led to this very serious situation.

An analysis done by Mark Woden has shown there has in fact been a marked growth in the incidence of casual employment at new workplaces and firms. Mr Woden did not draw any specific conclusion as to why this was occurring, but let me put it to you that the accelerated growth in the casualisation of new workplaces and firms is the result of employers' deliberate decisions to circumvent their employees' access to unfair dismissal jurisdiction and to avoid the payment of many existing entitlements that apply to permanent employees. If this bill were to see the light of day, it would provide a strong incentive to many employers to churn and to continue to employ casuals for less than honourable reasons. In his second reading speech, the minister argued:

quote.para: The exclusion ensures that businesses have the flexibility they need to hire short-term casuals without worrying about dismissal proceedings if it turns out that the employee is not needed permanently.

speech.para: If that were a genuine concern, employers would be able to use the probationary period exclusion as their defence. What is the defence for casual employees in the 12-month period? There is none at all if this bill is not rejected. There is no balance.

I was sorry to hear some of the comments made by the member for Hume when he argued that the ALP are out of touch with the realities of life for people in the small business sector. I do not think we are; I think we are making conscious efforts to address the needs of the small business sector. We had a range of very constructive amendments to the Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Termination) Bill 2002, which, regrettably, the minister has chosen to reject. You cannot have flexibility just at the employer's whim without understanding that, in doing so, you are denying rights to a whole group of Australian citizens who deserve the widest possible protections. There is no balance in this bill. While I and the Labor Party accept the notion of probationary periods, in our view it is unjust for Australian laws to be passed that provide flexibility and protection to employers at the expense of their employees, which is precisely what this bill seeks to do. Let me quote the minister's own words:

quote.para: After the court decision, as an interim measure, the Government made replacement regulations giving employers the widest protection possible within the parameters of the Hamzy decision.

speech.para: The minister is unashamedly on the public record saying that the regulations were made to give `employers the widest protection possible within the parameters of the Hamzy decision'. He goes on to argue that the bill that he has brought to this House validates the operation of regulations found invalid by the Federal Court.

The member for Barton has well explained Labor's amendments to this bill. In essence, the amendments provide for a maximum period of exclusion of six months or for a lesser period of exclusion that is contained in an award or certified agreement. This position is totally consistent with previous practice under a Labor government. In the years of that practice, the sky did not fall in and the laws did not operate in any way to curtail the growth and flexibility that short-term casual employment provides.

Of course, the ability of employees to negotiate a lesser period of exclusion would provide unions with an opportunity and incentive to increase their coverage among casual workers by negotiating more favourable conditions for them. A strong argument can be advanced that, in view of employment trends—the growth in casual employment and the fact that workers continue to be classified as casuals long after they should have been deemed permanent—they ought to have the same rights as all other employees.

Historically, industrial relations practice has defined casual employment as employment that is informal, irregular and uncertain. A study has confirmed today that casual employment is no longer informal or irregular, but it certainly continues to be uncertain. A 1997 ABS report indicated that one-third of all casuals continue to be employed as casuals beyond a 12-month period. The same survey indicated that almost 50 per cent of casual employees surveyed in the study were in jobs that had lasted over two years, but they were still considered to be casual employees. `Long-term casuals' is a big misnomer that is creeping into the lexicon; you are casual because you are there on an informal, irregular basis, as historically has been the practice. Anyone who continues to be casually employed beyond a 12-month period is being employed in a way that circumvents the kinds of benefits and protection that come with permanent employment.

The end point of this argument could well be that you remove any casual exclusion on the basis that a three-month probationary period should apply to all. But, on balance, Labor's amendments to this bill are a midway point—that is, that the maximum period of exclusion be six months while at the same time providing the scope for improvements to the six-month exclusion through negotiated outcomes either through the award system or through collective bargaining or certified agreements.

I am hoping that the minister will give consideration to the constructive suggestions that have been advanced by the shadow minister, the member for Barton, although I fear that the minister's agenda is driven more by rhetoric and ideology than it is by real issues that are applied to real people. I do not think there is anything fair about any of the proposals and bills that have come before this House that go to the issue of the rights of employees who are faced with unfair or unjust termination. The Australian community believes in a fair go all round. Regrettably, on every occasion that this issue has been debated, the minister's approach has been driven much more by the political agenda than by an agenda that enshrines the notion of a fair go all round and balances the legitimate interests of employers with the legitimate rights of people who work for those employers.

In conclusion, I urge the government to give serious consideration to the arguments advanced by the member for Barton on behalf of the Labor Party. I ask the minister to recognise that this government's repeated efforts to deny rights of equality before the law to Australian working people, particularly those who are most vulnerable and who are precariously employed, is not a principle that is accepted by the Australian community at large.

talk.start.para: —It is with pleasure I rise tonight to speak to the Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Termination) Bill 2002. Labor's disgraceful record on these workplace relations measures shows its lack of policy when it comes to creating jobs and supporting small business. Creating jobs and supporting small business are the principal aims of this bill. The bill will restore to businesses broad protection from termination of employment claims brought by short-term casual employees. It will also move provisions imposing a filing fee for dismissal applications from the regulations into the act and provide for the fee to be indexed annually in line with the consumer price index.

speech.para: The bill is aimed at assisting those businesses that rely heavily on the use of casual labour, including tourism businesses in Port Stephens, Dungog, Gloucester and the Great Lakes areas. The bill will assist those businesses to continue to operate smoothly without fear of falling foul of the unfair dismissal laws. Adding more risks and uncertainty to employment, especially for casuals, will have a detrimental effect on employment. Businesses, especially small businesses, should not be deterred further from engaging staff, especially casual staff. These staff help employers meet the peaks and troughs of business demands. Put plainly: this government is about creating jobs. Yet despite all those commonsense and good policy reasons, the ALP is still saying no to helping small business on this legislation. We all know that small business is like the engine room of the economy. There are over one million small businesses in this country, and this is where around 80 per cent of jobs growth in Australia has been created.

By refusing to support these measures under fair termination, Labor is once again failing to support small business. The ALP's record—or lack of a record—for helping small business is an utter disgrace. During the 13 years of Labor, small business was hit with the worst economic recession since the Great Depression; record small business interest rates of over 20 per cent; high inflation; massive government borrowing and national debt, which accumulated to $96 billion in Labor's last year of office; record unemployment, peaking at 11.2 per cent when Kim Beazley was employment minister; record business related bankruptcies; and a $10.3 billion deficit left by then finance minister, Kim Beazley. Small business was left with an industrial relations system that was dominated by deals between big unions, big business and big bureaucracy; a centralised award system that restricted flexibility; and a job-destroying unfair dismissals law which, according to the Council of Small Business Associations, prevented small business from creating at least 50,000 extra jobs.

Labor gave small business no protection in fair trading laws. Every time there was a call for fair trading reforms for small business, Labor commissioned yet another review. Labor had 17 reports, reviews or inquiries during its 13 years in government, but it did absolutely nothing. Labor consistently increased taxes. It introduced a capital gains tax, a fringe benefits tax, increased company tax, a compulsory superannuation tax, a compulsory training tax, automatically higher indirect taxes and higher fuel excise tax. Just look at what Labor did to provisional tax, which had an uplift factor of eight per cent in 1995-96. This adversely affected small business cash flows that should have been retained in the small business to assist with servicing of loans, increasing employment and/or supporting investment.

Now we have a situation where the ALP has the chance to do the right thing by small business and really help them with unfair dismissal laws. But what is the ALP doing? It is doing absolutely nothing. It is not doing a single thing. It is not even giving the Australian public an alternative view on small business policy, because the fact is it does not have one. But even if the ALP does not want to listen to the views of this government on creating employment and helping small businesses, it should be listening to the business community, like the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry. The chamber is the peak council of Australian business associations and represents over 350,000 businesses. Let us look at what the chamber had to say about unfair dismissals. In a media release in March this year, the chamber said:

quote.para: The Federal Government's legislation that continues to exempt casual employees from unfair dismissal laws during the first 12 months of employment must be enacted by the Parliament unamended.
It would be wrong and opportunistic for the Federal Opposition to hide behind last year's Federal Court decision to water down the 12-month exclusion.
Enacting the Government's legislation unamended does no more than retain the status quo that has applied for the past five years.

Let it be said plainly-if the Senate forces any lesser period than a 12-month exclusion for casual employees then the Parliament will have increased, not decreased, the burden of unfair dismissal laws on employers.
That would be a ridiculous outcome, given that the unfair dismissal debate should be about reducing the problems that these laws create for fair-minded employers.
A watering down of the five year old law will add more risks and deterrents to the employment of staff, in this case casuals.
