In the interests of jobs, especially in service industries, that should not be allowed to happen. Such an outcome would fly in the face of public statements by the Labor Party that it is sympathetic to easing the impact on business of unfair dismissal laws.
For the past five years an employer could employ a casual and not be at risk of a federal unfair dismissal claim during the first 12 months of employment.

Those that advocate a less than 12 month exclusion need to explain clearly to all employers, including small businesses, why they intend to increase the right of casual employees to sue employers for unfair dismissal.
Employers totally reject the argument that a less than 12-month exemption is required because of last year's Federal Court decision.
The Federal Court decision invalidated the former regulation for technical legal reasons, not on policy grounds.
The Government and the Parliament, not the courts, make public policy on unfair dismissal laws.
Court decisions are not a substitute for balanced public policy on an issue as important to jobs as unfair dismissal laws.
The 12-month exclusion is part of an established policy balance in unfair dismissal laws. For the past five years the Senate did not disallow this law, contained in regulations.
There is no case whatsoever for the burden of federal unfair dismissal laws to be expanded.

speech.para: If the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry can see this, then why not the ALP? The plain and simple reason is: too few of them have ever been in small business, have ever had their own money on the line, have ever taken the risk, have ever extended themselves in this direction.

This is just one example of business putting on the record what they think of unfair dismissal laws, particularly for casual workers. But let me tell you of another. A survey of small business issues undertaken by the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants in March this year showed that 42 per cent of small businesses did not feel confident that they knew how to dismiss staff in line with the unfair dismissal laws; yet 76 per cent of CPAs believed that small business does not understand the laws. The survey results confirm that understanding. The figures highlight the onerous complexity of the law. Sixty-two per cent of small businesses and 81 per cent of accountants believe that the unfair dismissal laws require them to follow a complex process.

The complexities of the law would be added to if business had to extend the minefield of unfair dismissal laws to short-term casual employees. This description was used by the CEO of the Small Business Clinic in an advice column in the Daily Telegraph on 25 June 2002. So here you have two clear examples of businesses saying to the opposition, the Democrats and the Greens that unfair dismissal laws are not working and that there needs to be change. Small businesses are saying that to create jobs they need certainty when it comes to unfair dismissal laws. But Labor, the Democrats and the Greens still are not listening. Here is another example. The Australian Hotels Association said in a media release in November last year:

quote.para: Casual employment is at the cornerstone of flexible workplace practices and, for industries that experience significant peaks and lows, it is an essential tool in successful business management.
The erosion of the flexibility of casual employment will simply hurt the chances of many young Australians to get their first break into the workforce.
Industry uncertainty is the last thing we need at present. The only thing it can bring is job insecurity, while it will drive many employers to simply stop hiring casuals.
The hospitality industry has already been hard hit by the global travel crisis and had our problems exacerbated by the collapse of Ansett and the general economic outlook.
Employment is already down in our industry, which employs more than 250,000 Australians, and the effects of this judgement could be absolutely disastrous.

speech.para: The final paragraph of that release said:

quote.para: The Federal Government must act swiftly and must receive support in the Senate to fix this situation quickly before too many jobs are lost.

speech.para: Business and industry are calling out for Labor, the Democrats and the Greens to support changes to unfair dismissals and to help create jobs, but they are simply turning away They are turning away from one of the biggest monkeys on the back of small business. They are turning away from reducing unemployment levels in their own electorates and from supporting the creation of jobs.

When we look at Labor's record on creating jobs, there is no policy there. Labor claimed in the 1998 election campaign that it could reduce unemployment to five per cent, yet it produced no plan at all to get there. Instead, Labor offered 53 reviews and inquiries, as well as talkfests, task forces and meetings, as a substitute for policy. Under Labor, award wages for low-paid workers fell in real terms. Labor ministers publicly boasted about the fall in real wages, claiming it was a deliberate economic strategy. Over the life of the Labor-ACTU accord, even the low-paid workers suffered a five per cent decline in real wages. By contrast, real wages have grown under the coalition.

Labor's record on creating jobs is just as abysmal. The people in Paterson remember the high unemployment rates under Labor. And what is Labor's solution? Talking, talking, talking and more talking—never sitting down and formulating policy on creating jobs, never sitting down with businesses to discuss what environment will allow for the creation of jobs. Labor's only plan is stalling on measures which they know are right and which they know will create jobs growth for small business. If Labor members opposite cared about the unemployment levels, they would support this bill that takes the monkey off the back of small business and spells out job creation within small business.

As I said earlier in this debate, the problem is that Labor does not understand small business. Most of their members have never been in small business or worked in small business. They have been the slaves of the union movement. I would like to conclude by quoting a friend and colleague, Joe Hockey, the Minister for Small Business and Tourism. He summed it up quite simply when he said:

quote.para: If you want to know what the Labor Party does to small business look no further than Western Australia. Small businesses are closing up. Small businesses are sacking people. Small businesses are not able to operate seven days a week to earn the money that is going to sustain their families and the families of their employees. The Labor Party is against small business. The coalition is for small business.

speech.para: I do not know where the Labor Party thinks jobs come from. Government should be about only the planning framework, but it is small business that creates jobs and it is the owners of those small businesses that put their money, their investment, their risk on the line to create those jobs. If we want small business to create jobs, we need to remove the barriers. One of the greatest barriers put to me by the people of Paterson is that, once they have taken on an employee—and it has happened on many occasions—they have been marched off to the unfair dismissal courts when they sought to terminate that person. They usually terminate people because the work has disappeared and they cannot afford to keep that person on. So here we have the double whammy: they cannot afford to keep them on but they cannot afford the cost of going to the tribunal.

It is not just the cost of attending and defending; it is the cost of the loss of a day's work. A lot of these people are small mum and dad businesses comprising one or two people, and time away from work means time they are not earning income. So quite often they settle just to get rid of the matter. If it were the members opposite and their money, their hands in their own pockets paying for this, how would they react? That is why the Labor Party cannot understand what this bill is about, that it is about taking the monkey off the back of small business and creating job opportunities by removing a barrier—a barrier that these people have never had to experience because they have never been in small business. They have never taken the risk and they have never put their hard-earned money and their family security on the line. That is the problem with the Labor Party. What we have here are union hacks, party officials and people who have never done an honest day's work for a living in their lives. I ask the House to support this bill.

talk.start.para: —I am delighted to speak on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Termination) Bill 2002 after the member for Paterson because what we just had was buffoonery of the highest order. The arguments he put in relation to the background of Labor Party members are absurd. We know that the minister—
—Which small business were you in?
—Which small business? Do you want to talk about my Uncle Tommy, who ran produce stores in Bankstown and in Smithfield?
—No, you.

—Do you want to talk about my mother, Kathleen Cecilia Hatton, born in West Wyalong in 1924, who moved to Bankstown in 1925? For 25 years she ran the Bambi day nursery at 6 Meredith Street, Bankstown, where the Australian Taxation Office is.
—Is she in parliament? No.
—My family history is in small business.
—What about you?
—They were people owning small businesses and people working for small businesses. Sixty per cent of the work force in this country work for small businesses, including members of my family.
—Why don't you support it?

—You have had your go, pal, so cut the interjections. What we have here is a broad-brush approach by the government, inappropriately and inexpertly trying to run an argument about Labor's background in small business. I have discussed the matter directly with the minister and he said very simply that he is only talking about Labor's experience in the Senate. That is all. He has not canvassed the experience in here because it is not as easy an argument to make. He talked about Senator Barney Cooney being the only person with small business experience in the Senate. He was a lawyer. Not that Barney is not a good bloke, but he was a lawyer. That was his small business. Look along that whole front bench on the government side. What have you got? Farmers—either small, medium or large businesses—and lawyers littering the bench from one end to the other. Sure, some of them ran small businesses, but they were particular niche businesses. They are not entirely representative of the people in my electorate, which is littered with small business people who, whatever government is in power, are impacted upon by that government.

speech.para: I want to speak about the experience of people in the Labor Party and their families—because I would expect that the general context in which people operate is the context in which they grow up. They come to understandings throughout their lives, not just from their personal experiences but from the experiences of their siblings, their parents and their grandparents. Those things inform their childhood and their period of growth. Certainly in my case those experiences have had a profound influence. For 25 years, assisted by my Auntie Gwen and my grandmother, my mother ran a small business in Bankstown, a childminding business. It was not a business that demanded no skills or few skills or just a pleasant face at the door while you were doing things. The care and maintenance of young children—because it is not just care but maintenance and helping them to grow in place of the parent, because carers are in loco parentis—is an important thing to do.

My mother's experience was also as an Army typist in the Public Service during the war. Most of the experience of my uncles was in small business. Tommy was a manager in a produce store in Bankstown, which I worked in, and ran his own shop in Smithfield. My uncle Eris Dooner ran a shop for people in Bankstown and moved to Armidale, where he has been an extraordinarily successful businessman for over 35 years, running Armidale Home Furnishers. He has done exceptionally well. I mentioned in the House the other day another small business man in my family, Lennie Dooner. I could mention my Uncle John, who was primarily a carpet layer for the whole of his life but who also had a series of other businesses. He is well known to the former Minister for Finance and Administration, John Fahey, as a friend. They both live in Camden and know each other well. I could refer to my brother Anthony, who again spent a lifetime in small business, in carpet laying. He was originally apprenticed to John, then he ran his own business.

The nature of our work force in the past—the way people either chose to work for themselves in small business or to work for others in small business—in that more than half a century of my experience, was such that you could be pretty sure someone wanted to run a business and was able to establish it successfully and keep it going through relatively good economic times, taking the hits with the bad. For those people who worked for these small businesses in the past, the level of casualisation in the work force was relatively low. We are in another economic era now compared to 30 or 40 years ago. You have only to think of the period from 1950 onwards and what has happened to the structure of the work force and the impacts of that changed structure to determine what response is necessary from this House and the approach that needs to be taken. Through the eighties and nineties, the pressures to casualise the work force were very strong. Labor's approach, in government and out, is that, if you have massive structural change and massive institutional change in the economy, you had better have some answers as to how you accommodate that. We have realised that casualisation of the work force is a significant matter.

When you step outside this building when we close down this joint from 11 o'clock tonight, you will be lucky to find six Comcar drivers who are permanently employed. A couple of years ago, you would have come across 12 of them. If you go back a couple more years, there were 23. Prior to that, when we were in government—and our lot are not without sin in terms of what we did to belt Comcar around the head—there was a strong history of permanent employment. It is not so now. There are six permanent drivers in Canberra, six in Sydney, six in Melbourne and six in Brisbane, and we will no doubt get to a point when there will be none. The people who work just outside this place for Comcar have been casualised. The government have said, `We don't need the services all the time.' They have run a campaign within and outside Comcar to say, `We don't need all of that; we just need you as and when we need you—on call.' Apart from those who are employed on a permanent basis, those who are employed on a casual basis will be affected by this bill. If they do not get a guernsey for more than six months—or for the legislative bottom of 12 months—they could be in a position where, overnight, they get the bullet, and they will have no recourse.

The shadow minister ran a series of arguments. He has run them previously with regard to other bills we have had before us. This bill had its genesis in February 2002. Before tonight we have had only three people talk on the bill: one, the minister; two, the member for Grey, I think, in a cognate debate in about May; and, three, in June the member for Fowler was able to speak. So we have had the minister and a couple of other people. Tonight we have this one piece of legislation which deals with part of what the government seeks to achieve, and we know the whole box and dice that the government tried to get through under the member for Flinders. We know that this government are all about dismemberment; that is, dismemberment of the original Workplace Relations Act into 12 different bits. They have run one bit through—the `unfair dismissals' which they turned into `fair dismissals'. That is the Orwellian doublespeak that underlies most of this legislation: turning something that is into something that should be perceived as that which it is not. They have run a series of bills to try to get elements of the original package through, and they have not succeeded.

Why haven't they got Labor Party support, Democrats support or Greens support for what they want to do here? It is because there is a fundamental recognition that, if the work force is fundamentally changed, if you cannot go outside and find more than half a dozen permanently employed Comcar people, there is a basic structural change. You might find that, in the other departments—in, say, Joint House—people have been casualised or are under the threat of casualisation because of increasing changes. Walk out the door and down to DFAT and to the other government departments around the place; you will find that the idea that you should contract out to those outside has had a great run since 1996. The impact of contracting out is that permanent jobs in the federal Public Service are lost to private industry. What often happens when you contract out—which is the normal way of doing things now—is that people who are casualised, who are in a dependent relationship for a short period of time, get the work. We have seen this move right through industry.

You can understand the normal economic and the cultural imperatives that move business—small, medium and large—towards casualisation. It is not as if any of this is new. Through the eighties and nineties the moves were very strong, but those moves have been validated time and time again by this government since 1996. The underlying rationale is that the cost of holding employees is too high. Manufacturers in the seventies and eighties said, `All of that is too hard, so we'll just whip off to Malaysia or Indonesia and set up a factory there because you don't have to worry about conditions like long service leave, super or anything else. You can pay low wages and you can run it that way.' We know that, in the globalisation model, that has happened with almost every major advanced manufacturing country on the planet. They have sought low wages and few conditions and they have continued to build the strength of their economies on transferring labour to countries where costs are low.

Given that there has been a strong movement towards that, the dismemberment of people's expectations of their employment has happened in the community at large. For a member of parliament—and it is not the most secure job on the planet—at least the tenure is, if we run three years, three years. There is that possibility. But it is different for people who are working for us as casual Comcar drivers or for people who have been turfed out of CSIRO. The driver I had the other day had been in CSIRO for 25 years, and he is out of there because they have made adjustments and they have cut down. One thousand people have been thrown out of CSIRO by this government latterly—

talk.start.para: —They haven't. They are increasing their numbers.
—Hang on, Minister. I will answer you. Rather than have the minister interjecting, I would be very grateful if you could protect me from him, Mr Deputy Speaker.
(Mr Jenkins)—Order! The minister will cease interjecting and the honourable member for Blaxland will ignore the interjections.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The minister and his government are attempting to play catch-up. They knocked off more than 1,000 jobs in CSIRO. The government's innovation statement was an attempt by the Prime Minister in particular to gather to himself the chief government scientist and the scientific community around Australia. It was a desperate act to grab an agenda won from the Labor Party. We were out there before with a forward looking scientific agenda to try to repair the damage that has been done by this government to the scientific institutions in this country. We did this to repair the damage done not only to CSIRO but also to our other government departments with research and development backing, including to some CRCs that have been knocked over—although generally they have been protected—and to repair damage done to a range of industries by the government thinking they should deal themselves out of the game.

speech.para: One of the ways of cutting their costs is to offload people. They have decided that science and innovation is fashionable. They have decided to increase the numbers because they flattened them in the first place—in 1996, 1997 and 1998—to achieve major budget savings. We have a government that is in the business of outsourcing, a government that is in the business of casualising and a government that is in the business of ensuring that that mode of operation continues. It leaves employees in the uncertain position of not knowing where the next job is coming from, how they are going to support themselves and their families or even whether they can put together a family in the first place. They have to juggle a series of different casual jobs which might run from a week to two weeks or from three months to six months, and they have to put together a package of them because finding permanent work on a full-time basis is not as easy as it was in the past.

The situation opening up for people in the 1960s and the 1970s—when I left school—was a paradise in work terms compared with what people face now, because there was still the certainty that you would be able to run with whatever you finally picked up. In the period prior to that we had the whole apprenticeship experience, with people aged 14, 16 or 17 changing careers, doing different things and then locking themselves into a career. All of that has gone. We know that, we accept it and we have to adjust to it. But we also have to accept the fact that if the economic forces are such that the permanent jobs are casualised down then you need to take that into account. The brutality of an ideological approach which says, `If you happen to be forced into a position where you've got a casual job, you will have no protections' is of no use, and that is what the explanatory memorandum lays out. That is what it says in the outline of this bill; that is what it says in schedule 1.

Let us look at who is affected by this: employees engaged for a specified period of time—there are plenty of those short-term contracts around, and a hell of a lot since 1996 compared with the number prior to 1996; employees engaged for a specified task; employees who are on probation, as long as the length of probation is three months or less or reasonable having regard to the particular employment; casual employees engaged for a short period, short-term casuals—maybe some of those Comcar drives outside; trainees who are employed under particular types of traineeship agreements or who are employed under a traineeship for a specified period; and non-award employees who earn more than a particular rate established in the Workplace Relations Regulations. That list corresponds to the list of employees currently excluded from the operation of the termination of employment provisions by regulation 30B—and so on.

That is the hit list. They are people who, as a result of this legislation, are going to be determined to try to react to three cases. The first is Hamzy v. Tricon International Restaurants, and the Federal Court appeal in relation to that case. The second is the metals case before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in 2000. That was a very interesting case, and it has not got any broader than that. The shadow minister detailed part of this case in his speech. The decision by the commission brought up to date the situation of casuals within the metals industry. It was pretty much out of date—more than a quarter of a century. Where did it bring them up to? This is not in terms of what any arbitration commissioner said; not in terms of what any Labor politician, either backbencher or shadow minister, said. What did Mr Bob Herbert, from the AIG, have to say? He is the most influential spokesman in the metals industry, from the employers side, that you could find. He said:

quote.para: There has been no adjustment to casual employment for 26 years. Certainly, there will be some murmurs among employers over the increased loading rates but, in reality the AIRC ruling simply brings casuals to roughly the same pay and condition levels as their full-time colleagues.

speech.para: You might ask what is wrong with that. If, after a quarter of a century, you are going to bring them up to reasonable parity, what is wrong with that—unless you think they should be in a `Thailandised' state; unless you think they should be battered down in terms of the conditions available to them? When the current Prime Minister was Treasurer of the Commonwealth—as he was in 1974, and in 1977-78 after the death of Phillip Lynch, and he remained Treasurer until 1983, when the Liberals were flicked—he actually had the trifecta: double digit unemployment, interest rates and inflation. No Labor Treasurer has ever achieved that trifecta. We might have had one or two, but we did not get all three. This bloke has spent his entire prime ministership running away from that. Question time after question time the Treasurer slyly alludes to Labor's record, but it is really a belt at the Prime Minister, who is attempting to assuage his conscience over what he has done.

Having a detrimental impact on employment in small business or across industry is not a good thing. You cannot escape the economic cycles. We have been pretty good at that recently, because the foundation laid by Labor in entirely reconstructing this economy in the 1980s and 1990s has been incredibly strong. But it is not good enough to distort the record of Labor's employment achievements. The member for Paterson did that in this House; it is the one thing I have not alluded to in terms of what he did. It is an entire distortion to argue that Labor's record in that regard is poor. Equally, time and time again following his ministers, there are attempts to make an argument that Labor brutalised people in terms of their real wages.

There was an accord. There was an agreement that if you were going to create more jobs then you needed to spread the load and the pain. That basic push put Labor in a position where we could create a record number of jobs, far beyond what this lot has done. And this government has created far more casual jobs than Labor did relatively. We have a proud record in regard to that. We have a proud record in sensitively handling the issue of casualisation and trying to make sure that people were not belted into the ground. We were also willing to face reality and not drill people through the head when it came to the question of small business and the difficulty people had with unfair dismissals. The original legislation was changed; it was dramatically modified. This government's legislation, effectively, is no different. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I note the member for Blaxland is still in the House. I wonder how the businesses owned by the member for Blaxland's relations would have coped with an unfair dismissal claim if they had employed casuals? My parents run a very small orchard; they have for many decades. They grow cherries, and the cherry season is very short—perhaps a couple of weeks. For decades, they have employed casual workers. Usually, it turns out that it is the first job a person has ever had. In fact, since the Second World War, they have employed waves of new migrants to this country on a casual basis, and it has often been the first job that those people have had in Australia. My parents are very proud of that fact. They still do employ many new migrants to this country on a casual basis in the cherry picking season in the Adelaide Hills. But I know that, if they were subjected to a dismissal claims regime, they would not employ anyone; they would do it themselves. My father is 79 and my mother is 73, but they would do it themselves.
—They must be pretty agile.

—They are very agile. So who loses? They would lose, of course, but so would the workers; so would these waves of new migrants who have come to Australia and who are employed, probably for the first time, in the Adelaide Hills, picking cherries. We are talking about winners and losers here, and I am trying to find out who is the winner.

speech.para: Let us look at the bill that is before the House tonight. I believe the Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Termination) Bill 2002 is another legislative instrument of the Howard government that is intended to achieve the dual objectives of more jobs and better pay for Australian workers. Six years after the Liberal Party re-entered federal government, the benefits of workplace relations reform are obvious. Over 950,600 new jobs have been created. More than 9.3 million Australians now have a job. The unemployment rate has crashed to a seasonally adjusted six per cent nationally, the latest figures being at their lowest level in two years, while the participation rate is at a historically high level. Unfair dismissal claims have fallen by 48 per cent as a result of three-month probation periods on new employees and restrictions on unscrupulous lawyers. Real wages for the lowest paid workers have risen by nearly nine per cent, and industrial disputation has fallen by a third. In the further pursuit of these objectives, the Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Termination) Bill 2002 amends the Workplace Relations Act so as to ensure that the laws concerning the termination of employment do not act as a disadvantage to Australian businesses or as a disincentive to the employment of Australian workers. As such, it is legislation that will be of obvious benefit to Australian businesses, their employees and the unemployed who so desperately want the reward, both financial and moral, of work.

The specific spur for this bill was a decision taken by the Federal Court in November 2001 to rule as invalid regulations excluding short-term casual employees—the sort of people my parents employ—from making unfair dismissal claims. The basis of this Federal Court decision, in the case of Hamzy v. Tricon International Restaurants trading as KFC, was an interpretation of the breadth of the regulation making power of the Workplace Relations Act. As a consequence, the longstanding practice by which casual employees were unable to access the dismissal claims system—unless their employment was on a regular and systematic basis for a period of at least 12 months and the employee in question had a reasonable expectation of continuing work with that same employer—was threatened. In turn, a significant barrier to the employment of short-term casual workers was inadvertently raised by the court, to the detriment of those seeking this kind of flexible work and the employers who wish to employ them. This is of particular importance, given the increasing preference of workers for this kind of employment. Figures presented to the Federal Court have indicated that 25 per cent of the Australian work force—over two million people—is casually employed.

As a remedy to what I think was an unfortunate situation generated by Hamzy v. Tricon International Restaurants trading as KFC, the bill before the House restores the prohibition on short-term casuals accessing federal unfair dismissal laws. It repeals the previous regulations so that their provisions can be written into the act itself. It retrospectively validates the regulations in question, and includes in the act a requirement that applicants for relief under the federal unfair dismissal laws lodge a $50 filing fee. This latter requirement will supplant a fee presently imposed by way of regulation. In short, the bill permanently restores the law governing the termination of employment of short-term casuals to that which was understood by the government, the parliament, employers and employees prior to November of last year.

The principle that short-term casual employees should not be able to access unfair dismissal laws was established under the Labor government in 1994. It has been strongly supported by this government. The principle was articulated in the coalition's election policy and was supported by the electorate. Some members opposite would like to claim that there is a bias in the workplace reforms initiated by the coalition government. Because they are still locked into some sort of 19th century Marxist interpretation of relationships as wholly class based, they cannot conceive of economic activity as being anything other than a zero sum game. As such, in their eyes policy apportions shares to the pie. They can say nothing of the size of the pie. Because some in our media are still stuck in the same Marxian time warp, there is a constant danger that this erroneous interpretation might be communicated to the public as fact.

It is to the great relief of this government, and to the citizens of this country, that we have in the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations an articulate, thoughtful and comprehending advocate of 21st century reform. In the context of this debate, I am reminded of a speech given by the minister to the Industrial Relations Society of Queensland earlier this year—an excerpt of which appeared in the Financial Review—in which he articulated the industrial perspective of this government. He said:

quote.para: This Government has tried to give employers a fair go, not because we see them through rose coloured glasses but because, in the end, that's usually what's best for most workers. We want to change the unfair dismissal law, not because we think workers should be liable to capricious sacking but because a few hard cases do not justify this handbrake on small businesses' ability to create new jobs. We want secret ballots before strikes, not because we want to disempower workers but because we oppose union officials using them as reluctant pawns in political campaigns.

speech.para: The minister also said:

quote.para: We're against compulsory union levies, not because unions should lack the standard capacity to charge a reasonable fee for a genuine service but because making workers pay for something they didn't request and don't necessarily need is a scam.

speech.para: This is the key. This government understand that both workers and employees have a stake in commercial success. They share a mutual interest in the health of their business enterprises. This bill recognises that the decision by the Federal Court last year jeopardised the interests of employees and employers. We want to put matters right. As such, this bill ought to receive the support not only of this side but of all members of the House. I commend this bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —I am delighted to be able to rise this evening to support the Workplace Relations Amendment (Fair Termination) Bill 2002, which has been proposed by the minister. The amount of interest shown by the opposition in this matter is rather less than expected, which has caused me to rise to my feet rather earlier than I had otherwise anticipated. But it is a pleasure nonetheless.
—We could get the bill now. I've a couple I'd like to get through.

—If the minister is suggesting that the matter be now put, I am happy to support him. As he knows, I have tremendous respect for both his judgment and his leadership in relation to matters of legislation and everything that concerns ordinary Australians—
—And the bill?

—and particularly the bill before the House. Nothing is more important to the effective working of an economy than good industrial relations, because nothing is more important than keeping our workers in jobs and our businesses in business. The reason this bill ought to be supported is that it achieves that outcome. This is the first opportunity I have had to speak on the reform program which has been at the heart of the coalition reforms since it came to office in 1996. I was elected just some 12 months ago, but I have taken a particular interest in industrial relations law. I have followed with intense interest the progress of reformist legislation in this area since 1996 because I have a strong belief that reform of industrial relations law is absolutely necessary as a fundamental plank, as a precondition and as a starting point for successful government in the modern era. That has been a position expressed by others and perhaps most eloquently by the Prime Minister himself as late as today during question time. But it is true and it is worth repeating, and I repeat it because I strongly support it. As I have this opportunity to speak for the first time on the workplace relations legislation, I will take some time to review the principal act, the Workplace Relations Act, and illustrate how this bill will enhance the existing programs of the government in achieving good outcomes not just for industrial relations but for the economy generally.

speech.para: Firstly, let me focus on the Workplace Relations Act itself. It is, as the title suggests, an act concerning the workplace. That may seem a simplistic comment but it is an absolute truism about the direction of industrial relations since 1996 and since the introduction of the basic statute, the Workplace Relations Act, by the former minister the Hon. Peter Reith. Why is that so? The reason it was such a fundamental and important change is that industrial relations have been a critical issue for parliament in this country since Federation. It has been a matter that has been at the heart of the difference between the two principal parties, in government and in opposition, since 1901. The reason it is so important is that the focus in this statute is not upon an industry, not upon an association, not upon a trade, not upon an employer federation and not even upon a broader focus such as the impact on an economy but, rather, upon the workplace. That is the fundamental and paradigm shift in this legislation which I believe has been an important part of the reform program since 1996 and of which the government and the coalition can be very proud. Others also have outlined the actual outcomes in terms of good consequences for both the workers and the businesses of Australia.

The second aspect of the bill which is very important can also be taken from the title, and that is the fact that it concerns relations. It is a bill which concerns the relations between the employee and the employer. It does not concern a broader context. It is not a fight between capital and labour. The fight between those fundamental interests and those Marxist categorisations—the socialist concepts of the past—are now arguments of the past.

talk.start.para: —That is what you think.

—It is, therefore, very important that the focus of this statute since 1996 has been without demur from the opposition—until a short while ago when I heard from the member for Watson. The focus of modern industrial relations legislation should be upon relations, not upon worker interests or capital versus labour, as in the hoary old concepts of 19th century economists and outdated sociological theorists who no longer have any relevance to the answers for the modern world. The third aspect of this legislation which has proved very important is the fact that it covers an economy. It is comprehensive, and that is terribly important.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I want to speak about multiculturalism in Australia, and I am pleased to see that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs is here. Multiculturalism in this country has had a ripple effect throughout the world. It has struck me that there have been some extraordinary success stories both here in Australia and internationally and I would like to take the opportunity tonight to bring some of them to the attention of the House. To me, these are the jewels of Australia's multiculturalism. They show how successful we have been in nurturing our people, no matter where they have come from. These success stories do not sit easily with some of our current policies and attitudes, exemplified by the way we are treating many asylum seekers.

speech.para: We are largely a nation of migrants sourced from every corner of the world. While migrants from Europe—mainly from the British Isles—form the largest group, we have in the past welcomed people from lands and cultures that are very different from the European. Unfortunately, it seems this is no longer the case. We now live in a world of suspicion and fear; we treat many of our fellow human beings who want to come here in search of a haven as if they were criminals or worse. I think it is timely to look at some of the more interesting and successful results of our willingness to take in people from parts of the world that are very different from Australia.

My colleague and friend the member for Grayndler last night mentioned Hazem El Masri, the Canterbury winger who is, of course, of Lebanese descent. What an amazing young man he is. Not only is he a brilliant footballer but he is a respected member of his community and a wonderful ambassador for people of the Muslim faith in Australia in particular. There are also people currently in other countries who were born in Australia, or who may have lived here for periods of time, who are now contributing in significant ways to their current home. Abdul Khaliq Fazal spent 30 years in Melbourne. Now he is a minister in the Afghan government. He regards himself as an Afghan and also as an Australian. He understands both cultures. The value of having such a person is almost immeasurable. There is Ung Huot in Cambodia, who served as co-Prime Minister with Hun Sen and was previously Foreign Minister of Cambodia. He was formerly an engineer with Telstra in Sydney. He has dual nationality: he is an Australian and a Cambodian.

I have met people who have served in the Lebanese parliament who grew up in Australia and were Australian citizens. I have met MPs in Iran who spent many years in Australia as students. And, Mr Speaker, that is mentioning only people involved in our profession. There are many writers, academics, artists and talented people whose lives have been shaped by both their country of origin and their country of choice. If Australia had embraced a narrow, purely assimilationist policy, this two-way flow may not have ever occurred. I have chosen these examples deliberately because of the geographic locations. These people are not in Europe or of Europe but in countries that are, in varying ways, quite different from Australia. Some of them live in trouble spots. All of them have challenging jobs to fulfil. But all of them have experienced life in this country and all of them have their own experiences of life here which have helped them shape their attitudes.

Multiculturalism enables us to recognise and appreciate the many different cultures in Australia, to embrace those differences and to respect and defend each other's right to be different. I am very proud of what true multiculturalism in Australia has achieved. I hope that we will continue to be a welcoming nation to those who need care and a safe place to live. Experience has shown that multiculturalism is not a one-way street. It is not just about people coming here; it is also about people leaving here and taking with them an appreciation of our way of life, which I hope makes them better able to face the challenges in their chosen careers elsewhere. We have been a great success. We should not forget it; we should rejoice in it.

At Christmas we should remember those things that make us Australians, but more particularly we should remember that we must try to give shelter and help to those who need it. We should remember those people who came here and went out from this country again and have done great jobs in the world. The few people I have mentioned tonight are great examples of that, and we should not forget it. They have made us proud and we should be very proud of them.

talk.start.para: —The parliament should be aware of some strike action that has delayed important works being undertaken as part of the upgrade of Sutherland Hospital, which provides important health care services to the people of my electorate. Led by members of the CFMEU and other unions, including the New South Wales Plumbers Union and the Electrical Trades Union, workers have walked off the site on three—possibly four—Fridays in a row. Recently I was made aware that workers on the site had walked away from work on two Fridays in succession due to the fact that the water supply to the site had been temporarily cut off. Work had also stopped on the third Friday, although it is not clear whether the stop-work was also over the issue of water.

speech.para: I am not aware of the reasons why water provision to the site was temporarily cut off; however, I presume it would be due to the fact that it was necessary in order to perform certain procedures elsewhere on the site. You would assume that this is a fairly normal occurrence in and around a major construction zone. We are all familiar with having our water supply cut off at home when work is occurring in the street. In fact, only last week my electorate office's water supply was temporarily stopped due to work on the Kingsway. In the case of Sutherland Hospital, I understand that on both occasions, within a very short time of the water being cut off, a CFMEU delegate had arrived at the site to request that all work cease immediately due to occupational health and safety concerns. In each case the delegate's argument was that the safety of workers was endangered by having no running water directly available on the site. On each occasion it has been brought to my attention that the delegate called a union meeting, after which all workers left the site, including those who were not affected by the lack of water access. I am further told that, on each occasion that the water was turned off, it was back on again within three to four hours. While this is a considerable amount of time, it hardly amounts to an occupational health and safety risk. Surely arrangements can be made to provide workers with water from elsewhere once it established that access would be restricted for a period.

It cannot be a coincidence that the CFMEU has recently signalled its intention to campaign for a 36-hour week with all employers in the industry. Unions have a limited recourse to industrial action during the time an industrial agreement is being negotiated, so this `spoiling' action at Sutherland Hospital appears a roundabout way of pushing their case for a 36-hour week without actually calling a full-blown strike. Not only are the CFMEU using OH&S standards as a cover for pushing their agenda outside other enterprise bargaining processes but also there has been unhelpful action taken by the Plumbers Union and the Electrical Trades Union, which are also present on the site.

Of greatest concern to me, as the local member, is that the important improvements being made to Sutherland hospital have been delayed by these frivolous actions. The Carr government promised the upgrade at the last state election and have made a huge song and dance in the area about the works since they commenced. Perhaps Bob Carr and his representative in the local area, Barry Collier, could simply get going and get on to the phone to their union mates to ensure that no more industrial action occurs on this important local site under the guise of an OH&S risk. There is no question that the practices of the CFMEU in our local area warrant close investigation. The regressive sympathy tactics of the other unions also deserve condemnation. This sort of behaviour cannot be allowed to go on.

Improvements to our local hospital are being delayed by frivolous and thuggish union activity that threatens to take building site workplace relations back to the dark days of yesteryear. The improvement to Sutherland hospital is too important to our community to be misused in this way. Sutherland hospital provides all of the medical requirements—except for Kareela hospital, which is a private hospital—of all of the residents in the Sutherland Shire. It is an important centre for all of the health activities. We have an array of specialists who are located in the vicinity of the hospital. The important role that it carries out is going to be delayed by many weeks by the simple practices that these unions are employing. Unions have a specific and important role in our community, but these types of tactics must be condemned by the wider community to ensure that we have our hospital on time in the Sutherland Shire to the benefit of all community residents.

talk.start.para: —Last month the National report to parliament on Indigenous education and training, 2001 was tabled, and statements were made by the minister for education, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition as shadow spokesperson, and the member for Lingiari. There has been a motion to take note of the paper, but that has not proceeded as yet. I believe that this is a very important type of report. It enables the two houses of this parliament to take the appropriate steps by having a reference document that gives an indication of where we are at with progress in, in this case, Indigenous education. This report is a requirement of the legislation which was enacted in late 2000.

speech.para: One of my purposes in raising this national report tonight is to highlight that, sadly, it indicates the need for us to concentrate on making sure that Indigenous education is improved. The difference between retention rates for students going through to year 12 is 73 per cent nationally compared to 38 per cent of Indigenous students. This report makes a comparison about the differences in achievements of literacy levels at year 5 between the wider Australian community and Indigenous students. I was heartened that there were themes in this report which indicated that we could best progress Indigenous health by listening and responding to the Indigenous communities themselves, by enabling Indigenous communities to be involved in the decision making, by making sure that we take the skills that Indigenous students have and use them to their fullest in their education settings and by setting a curriculum that is, in turn, challenging for Indigenous students.

My purpose tonight in raising this matter is that back in May 2000 the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs tabled its report, Health is life: report on the inquiry into Indigenous health. In that report, the committee urged the then minister for Aboriginal affairs—however titled—to make an annual report to parliament about progress in Indigenous health. Regrettably, in its response to the report the government did not comment directly about such reporting. Indeed, we indicated through this report—the committee was unanimous—that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs should be responsible for coordinating the efforts across portfolios in the many facets that affect Indigenous health. Here, 2½ years later, we still have had no progress report about the state of Indigenous health. I think that is a problem.

Coincidentally, today there are reports in the newspapers of Reconciliation Australia indicating the need—it is highlighted in the article that I was reading—to concentrate on decreasing domestic violence in Indigenous communities. The cochairpersons of the body indicated that they were pleased by the progress that has been made by federal and state governments in setting benchmarks and points of reference so that we can measure the progress or otherwise. I believe that we really have to take this seriously. The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, who is in the chamber, was quoted in our report of May 2000 because he chaired an inquiry—I think it was back in the late seventies, although I might be dating him unfairly by saying that—in which he said things that continue to be apposite to now, into the 21st century.

I believe that until this place takes responsibility for discussing the plight of our Indigenous communities—through such things as the National report to parliament on Indigenous education and training or having such a national report on Indigenous health—we will not see the progress necessary to decrease the disparities between the health outcomes for Indigenous people as compared to non-Indigenous people. Finally, I am pleased to see, in an answer to a question that was put on notice by the honourable member for Lowe, that there has been instituted the Puggy Hunter Memorial Scholarships, which will enable Indigenous people to go into undergraduate studies in health, nursing and other allied health professions. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Recently, the Gold Coast City Council and a number of leaders of the Gold Coast business community, as well as a number of key bureaucrats at a Gold Coast City level, visited Canberra as part of the Gold Coast City's roadshow to Canberra. Part of the driving force behind the roadshow to Canberra was for Gold Coast City to highlight the unique challenges Gold Coast City faces as Australia's fastest growing city, as a city that has held that mantle for 30 years and, it is expected, will continue to hold that mantle for an additional 25 years. Our population growth is in excess of 15,000 per annum net. This is an incredible rate and is more than double the next fastest growing area in the whole country. Another part of the roadshow was to highlight some of the unique challenges that this rapid population growth presents to the Gold Coast council and those of us who are elected to represent the Gold Coast community. A fundamental part of that was to demonstrate to the Howard government what it could do to assist the Gold Coast community to grow, to assist the Gold Coast community to move forward and to assist the Gold Coast community and all of the businesses and people that work within it to continue to strive for the next level.

speech.para: I am delighted to stand here today as a part of the Howard government and say that the Howard government is most certainly delivering for the people of the Gold Coast. It was only yesterday that I learned that $2 million had been allocated to Griffith University to assist the university directly with respect to the provision of new infrastructure for the students that attend it. This $2 million was the result of an application put in by the administration of Griffith University for Capital Development Pool funding. Griffith was successful and indeed received, as I said, $2 million.

Today, I am delighted to have learned that the Howard government has once again delivered, although what it delivered today was an incredible boost for everyone on the Gold Coast, for all of those businesses and for all of those people that are involved in the tourism industry. Today, the Minister for Science, the member for Gippsland, together with the Minister for Small Business and Tourism, the honourable member for North Sydney, announced that the Cooperative Research Centre for Sustainable Tourism would be in receipt of funding of $26.7 million. This funding will go a long way towards ensuring that, going forward, all Gold Coasters—but not only the Gold Coast; rather, all of Australia—will benefit from exciting new research and development work on infrastructure development in tourism and also on some of the challenges that tourism presents both ecologically and in terms of the industry remaining sustainable.

I was delighted to learn the CRC for Sustainable Tourism, as a result of this $26.7 million grant that was announced today, will be able to look forward to a number of different projects that will ensure that the CRC is in a position to undertake some exciting new research and development for the tourism industry. If there is one thing that the member for North Sydney's 10-year plan for tourism and the discussion paper have highlighted, it is the need to make sure that the tourism industry has appropriate strategies in place to minimise risk but also to undertake research and development.

At present, the expenditure for research and development is less than two per cent of the total value of the tourism sector. Today, however, with funding of $26.7 million for the CRC, there will be a number of different R&D activities that can be undertaken. These will include research and development into lessening the environmental impact of tourism activities. They will also include provision and research to look at ways to increase the yield and profitability for all of those businesses that are reliant upon the tourism industry. In addition they will examine the way in which we can continue to grow jobs in the tourism sector—one of the fastest sectors to create job growth throughout Australia. Further, they will look at ways we can continue to generate increased export income not only for the Gold Coast but for all of Australia.

In short, the announcement today of $26.7 million for the CRC for Sustainable Tourism at Griffith University is a tremendous sign of confidence from the Howard government to the people of the Gold Coast, and it is a clear demonstration of the Howard government's continuing push to ensure that the Gold Coast's unique challenges and unique tourism industry are well and truly catered for. I am delighted to have been able to make the announcement today, together with the member for McPherson, Margaret May. I am sure that all Gold Coasters will join in recognising the importance of this contribution. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —In the Christian calendar, we are now in the second week of Advent, that four-week period leading up to Christmas. Christmas has never been more significant or relevant, both as a longstanding tradition within Australia and around the world and as a profound reminder of the peace and goodwill that you, Mr Speaker, spoke about to an ecumenical gathering in this House earlier tonight. Sadly, forgotten for many is the fact that Australia is a country built on Christian values. Its laws, its jurisprudence, its way of life and its being the land of the fair go—all this derives from the Christian ethos. Substitute or subrogate these idioms and you replace that Christian matrix with alternative matrices which do not afford the ideologies that compositely we call democracy. From where do the very terms `natural law' and `natural justice' flow? Where does the jurisprudential notion of universalism flow? They are from Christianity, which alone holds true to these ideologies and embeds within them every fibre of our social fabric. Modern and not so modern ideologies are not universalist. Liberalism, utilitarianism, hedonism, consequentialism and other religious creeds are all morally or culturally relativist in one way or another. With cultural and moral relativism comes loss of democracy and, ultimately, tyranny and slavery.

speech.para: So what is the significance of Christmas? Christmas is about the birth of Jesus Christ, the Prince of Peace born as a physical human being. Christmas marks a celebration of the very fact of this event, that Jesus was a real baby who was really born and who was really the Son of God. Christmas is thus about the birth of Jesus Christ and, as you know and said earlier tonight, Mr Speaker, about peace and goodwill to all mankind. In the face of the tragic events of Bali, I believe that it is also timely to reflect on the contribution of a famous saint who did much to bring true peace to our now very insecure and troubled part of the world, St Francis Xavier. During the 16th century, St Francis proselytised much of Asia, including China, India, Ceylon—which is now called Sri Lanka—Japan and the Moluccas Islands. Unbelievably, the people of these communities are now the most persecuted peoples in the world for their very faith in Christ and Christmas; yet, paradoxically, these same people are the very reason why peace still has a chance in our Asia-Pacific region.

It was St Francis who noted that the future of Asia lies in China as Asia's dominant political, financial and military power. This could not be any truer than now. In my view, the regional security of Australia will increasingly depend on China and not on the United States. It is therefore imperative that Australia and China have a true philosophical meeting of minds. The great St Francis brought with him the seeds of universalism, the rule of law, reason and other great gifts that contrast so sharply with the moral and cultural relativist religious, political and secular ideologies that plague the Asia-Pacific region today.

We would do very well to read and understand the philosophy and direction of St Francis Xavier. His relevance to Australia in these times is both immediate and direct. Nothing could be of greater importance to Australia in terms of our direct and immediate security, and the financial, social and other costs we are all bearing from the scourge of global terrorism. It is timely to blow the dust off our history books, embrace the profound positive legacy of this great saint and embrace Christmas. Christmas is not just an excuse to hold an end of year party, to have a holiday, to display tinsel or to secularise the Christmas tree—the symbol of light taken from the Roman festival of light. Christmas is not about reindeers or Santa Claus; Christmas is about Christ. The true meaning of Christmas is that Jesus Christ was born, destined to suffer, die on a cross, be buried and then rise on the third day for us. May I take this opportunity to wish you, Mr Speaker, and all the members of this parliament and its staff a very happy Christmas. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —All Australians have shared an affinity with the new state of East Timor and its people. In some cases that relationship dates back 50 years and is in response to the important support that the East Timorese provided to Australian troops, of whom my father was one, during the Second World War. Mostly it is, however, a more recent awareness and closeness born of observing its courageous struggle for independence. There is also pride in our own role in assisting the creation of this new nation in our region.

speech.para: We have watched as a friend and have assisted in a significant way that transition to nationhood. Australia's support has been multifaceted: from direct aid to our involvement in the UN led mission and, of course, the involvement of Australian military personnel in assisting the East Timorese provide internal security. I therefore think most Australians were genuinely concerned at the turn of events last week that saw up to five people killed as a result of rioting. Forging a new nation is a rare challenge and, with the background of historical strife and poverty, it was not likely to be a smooth road for the East Timorese. Nonetheless, much has been achieved and Australia, as a friend and donor, has a continued interest in assisting the process. We must always respect as paramount the democratic processes of that nation and the values which we Australians respect as the sound basis of any modern nation.

It is important, however, that we understand the motivation for the events of last week if we are to be able to offer constructive advice to the UN authorities and the East Timorese government. It would be presumptuous of me, as someone who is not an expert, to draw conclusions, although it does seem to me that addressing the dire economic situation faced by most East Timorese must be a priority. Unemployment rates in East Timor have variously been estimated at between 60 and 80 per cent. Timorese who are lucky enough to hold a job generally receive a maximum of $US6 per day, although as little as $US1 per day is not uncommon. On 19 May this year, the ABC's online news service attributed to the World Bank the finding that the average per capita income in East Timor is $US0.55 per day.

Timorese workers on subsistence wages endure poor working conditions and enjoy little in the way of security of tenure, superannuation, holiday pay or safety protections. These are regarded as fundamental rights for all Australians. Against this background, the Timorese witness the UN's staff, who earn more than $US95 per day—in many cases that is in addition to their regular salary. Employees of NGOs are also remunerated at levels considerably higher than the East Timorese. Whilst I do not argue that these salaries are inappropriate, it is perhaps understandable—if not founded on a logical basis—that the people of East Timor could develop resentment towards foreign workers. What is important is that UN staff ensure that they do not exacerbate that tension by being seen to be profligate. The model of General Cosgrove's management of Australian troops in East Timor is relevant in this regard.

I also understand that this resentment is extending to the members of the government of East Timor, who have not always understood the depth of local feeling against the Portuguese legacy and who, while earning far more modest amounts than overseas staff, receive a remuneration that provokes jealousies. Reducing poverty and developing a sound and sustainable economic foundation must therefore be the priority of the East Timorese government and its friends like Australia. That means addressing the critical shortage of economic and social capital. Until that shortage is redressed, the dominating characteristic of East Timor will be grinding poverty.

To redress that shortage of capital it seems to me, as an observer, that some of the essential elements need to include a disciplined government that does not undermine its own economy by excessive spending and an open door to foreign investment with security of title and a guarantee that nationalisation will not be on the government's agenda. Tourism, minerals, agriculture and fishing are areas of prospective foreign investment which can offer substantial employment opportunities to local people. Reducing sovereign risk will increase investment in those areas. East Timor needs a taxation and banking system that protects low-income earners and an energetic campaign of expansion of the education system at all levels. East Timor also needs a modern approach to the rights of women. I know that all Australians want to see East Timor prosper. We must never hesitate to provide assistance, both intellectual and tangible, when we are invited to do so to support the people of the world's newest nation in achieving their goals. In its first year of independent existence, we must do our best to support this recently established democracy on our doorstep.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 17 October 2002:

quote.para: (1) Following his recent visit to Tripoli, Libya, is he able to say whether the Libyan Government is considering re-opening a diplomatic posting in Canberra.
(2) What is the proposed site of the posting.
(3) When was the last time Libya was permitted to have a diplomatic posting in Australia.
(4) Has he been advised by the Department of Foreign Affairs on the principal reasons for expelling Libya; if so, what were those reasons.

(5) Is he aware of reports dated 6 May 2002 from US State Department Under Secretary for Arms Control and International Security, Mr John R. Bolton, of new Libyan programs for acquisition of weapons of mass destruction.
(6) Is he aware of further reports of Libyan programs to acquire chemical and biological weapons.
(7) Have these reports influenced the Australian Governments attitude to relations with Libya.
(8) What is the Australian Government's justification for allowing Libya to re-establish a diplomatic mission in Australia.
(9) Is the Australian Government considering opening a diplomatic post in Tripoli, Libya, following his meeting with Colonel Qadhafi's son.

talker.name: Vaile, Mark, MP
Mr Vaile
talker.role: Minister for Trade

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: As the questions raised fall within the responsibility of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, I have consulted him on the following answers to the honourable member's questions—

(1) While the Government has not received a formal request seeking agrement to Libyan representation in Australia, the Libyans have foreshadowed that they plan to seek diplomatic accreditation to Australia of an Ambassador.
(2) See answer to question (1).
(3) The Government suspended relations with Libya on 19 May 1987 when the Libyan People's Bureau (Embassy) in Canberra was also closed.
(4) The Government took this action in view of domestic and regional concern over claims of Libyan interference in the internal affairs of Australia and countries in the South Pacific region.
(5) Yes.

(6) A number of institutions have published reports regarding Libya's programs of chemical and biological weapons. For example, the Monterey Institute of International Studies has produced a report on Libya's chemical weapons program.

(7) Australia maintains diplomatic relations with a number of countries which are known or reported to have weapons of mass destruction (WMD) programs, and takes appropriate opportunities to register its concerns about these programs. During my visit to Libya in July 2002, I urged Libya to help resolve WMD concerns by acceding to the Chemical Weapons Convention and refraining from acquiring longer range ballistic missiles.

(8) The Government reviewed Australia's relations with Libya earlier this year, and, in light of international developments and national economic interests, decided on 17 June 2002 to resume normal diplomatic relations with Libya. The Government is satisfied that Libya is no longer actively involved in promoting terrorism. Libya has condemned the September 11 attacks in the United States, has signed all of the anti-terrorism conventions, and is starting to take appropriate counter-terrorism measures.
(9) No. Libya agreed to Australia accrediting our Ambassador in Cairo. The Ambassador presented his credentials in Tripoli on 11 September 2002.

subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1065)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Children and Youth Services, upon notice, on 23 October 2002:

quote.para: (1) How many citizens residing in Australia are involved in shared-care custody arrangements with ex-partners who are New Zealand citizens residing in New Zealand.
(2) In how many cases are both parents classified as low-income earners.

(3) Under the current agreement between Australia and New Zealand, in cases in which both parents are classified as low-income earners and each parent has equal custody of the children, what percentage of (a) Australian parents are required to make child support payments to the New Zealand parent and (b) New Zealand parents are required to make child support payments to the Australian parent.

(4) Has his attention been drawn to my representations to him concerning the Child Support Agreement between Australia and New Zealand as it relates to a Hasluck constituent, Mr Deon Roberts; if not, why not.

(5) Is there an anomaly in this case, whereby Mr Roberts is required to pay child maintenance to his ex-partner in New Zealand for his daughter, even though he is caring for his son in Australia; if not, why not.
(6) Is this Agreement which requires Mr Roberts to pay child maintenance to his ex-partner because he resides in Australia, anomalous and requiring urgent attention; if not, why not.
(7) What steps has he taken to address the anomaly and when will it be removed.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr Anthony
talker.role: Minister for Children and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Child Support Agency (CSA) does not have the ability to determine the specific number of Australian parents who are in shared-care custody arrangements with ex-partners who are New Zealand citizens residing in New Zealand. It would be fair to say, however, that the number of these clients would be extremely small, as only 1.9% of all Australian CSA Collect cases are where the parents both provide equal care for one or more children of the relationship. It would be reasonable to assume that less than 10 cases would fall into this category.
(2) Not known. The CSA does not separately record on any of its databases the range of incomes for New Zealand cases transmitted to Australia.
(3) (a) The CSA does not record this information, however, less than 10 cases would fall into this category. (b) Nil.
(4) I have responded in writing to a letter dated 17 June 2002 in response to these issues. A response to a letter dated 15 October is currently under preparation.

(5) and (6) The Australian and New Zealand Child Support Schemes are similar but not identical. The determination of child support payable is undertaken by the country in which the parent caring for the child resides. Where parents are both caring for one or more children of the relationship, this produces a different outcome than would be the case if both parents lived in either Australia or New Zealand.

An administrative remedy is available to parents where the assessment results in an unjust or inequitable outcome. Either parent can apply to the Australian Child Support Agency to increase or decrease the Australian child support assessment to take account of special circumstances.
(7) The administrative remedy described in (5) and (6) above is already available to parents, therefore further steps are not necessary.

(2) How many members are there in the (a) army, (b) navy and (c) airforce arms of the Australian Defence Force.
(3) What are the major equipment expenditures due to be undertaken over the next decade and why is it necessary to undertake this expenditure.

talker.name: Vale, Danna, MP
Mrs Vale
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) (a) and (b) The current level of expenditure on defence, based on the departmental appropriations and equity funding, excluding the capital use charge, is $14,270m. This equates to 1.9% of the gross domestic product.
(2) This information is contained in Chapter Five - People Matter of the 2001-2002 Defence Annual Report.
(3) The largest Defence Capability Plan projects for which expenditure is planned over the next decade include:

· AIR 6000 Phases 1A and 1B, New Aerospace Combat Capability Acquisition. The estimated expenditure of Phase 1A is more than $6000 million and the estimated expenditure of Phase 1B is $4500-$6000 million. Another phase of AIR 6000 is planned beyond the decade.
· SEA 4000 Maritime Air Warfare Capability. Estimated expenditure is $3500-$4500 million.
· AIR 5077 Phase 3 Airborne Early Warning And Control System. Planned expenditure $3,455 million.
· AIR 5402 Phase 1 ADF Air Refuelling Capability. Estimated expenditure is $1500 million- $2000 million.
· AIR 87 Phase 2 Armed Reconnaissance Helicopters. Planned expenditure is $1,858 million.
· AIR 5276 Phase R AP-3C Orion Replacement/Remanufacture. Estimated expenditure is in excess of $1500 million.
· AIR 5376 Phases 2.2 and 2.3 FA/18 Hornet Upgrade. Combined estimated expenditure for both sub-phases is $1,524 million.
· LAND 121 Phase 3 Overlander - Field Vehicle Fleet Replacements. Estimated expenditure is in excess of $1500 million.

The classified 10-year Defence Capability Plan was developed in conjunction with the Defence 2000 White Paper to provide the Defence Force with clear, long-term goals for the development of our armed forces and the funding needed to achieve those goals. The Defence 2000 White Paper provides the justification for the equipment expenditure outlined in the Defence Capability Plan. Defence 2000 emphasises the need for a professional, well-equipped force that is available for operations at short notice, and one that can be sustained on deployment over extended periods; and outlines capability goals for Defence's land, air, maritime, strike and information capabilities. The Defence Capability Plan is reviewed and updated annually to take account of changes in Australia's strategic circumstances, new technologies and changed priorities. The current review of the Defence Capability Plan is being informed by the 2002 Annual Strategic Review.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 12 November 2002:

quote.para: Are Members allowed to use their postage entitlement to circulate reply paid petitions outside their own electorate.

talker.name: Abbott, Tony, MP
Mr Abbott
talker.role: Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: In the absence of details of any particular case it is not possible to provide definitive advice.
The Remuneration Tribunal provision in relation to the Communications Allowance is as follows:

Remuneration Tribunal Determination 26 of 1998, Clause 10.3 states: `...a senator or member shall be entitled to use commercial services for the distribution of letters, newsletters and parcels and electronic services (including establishment and maintenance of web sites) at Commonwealth expense in relation to parliamentary or electorate (but not Party) business...'

The Remuneration Tribunal's capacity to determine the postage entitlements of Parliamentarians for parliamentary and electorate business derives from s.7(1) of the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973 which requires it to determine the allowances to be paid at official expense `...by reason of their membership of the Parliament or by reason of their holding particular offices, or performing particular functions in, or in relation to the Parliament or either House of the Parliament.'
The Tribunal in 1997 when asked what constitutes parliamentary and electorate business advised as follows:

`The Tribunal considered the question of defining these concepts during the course of its annual review. It has decided, however, that it would be inappropriate (indeed improper) for it to define them to exclusion. Its position on this question essentially revolves around the due reticence which all in the executive arm of government must have that they do not impede the elected arm in the exercise of its function.'
